name: Prosser, Geoff, MP
content: —I rise in support of the Tax Laws Amendment (2005 Measures No. 3) Bill 2005, which will amend various taxation laws to implement a range of changes and improvements to Australia’s taxation system. Firstly, this bill gives effect to the government’s announcement in the 2004-05 budget to encourage charitable giving in Australia from both the private and corporate sectors. Schedule 1 of the bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to introduce a number of new amendments to increase flexibility for charitable funds, ancillary funds and prescribed private funds.There are four policy changes proposed to expand concessions. The first relates to capital gains tax provisions and proposes that a capital gain or loss made from a testamentary gift—that is, a gift made under a will of property to a deductible gift recipient—will be disregarded for capital gains tax purposes, regardless of the value of the property. This effectively removes the requirement that testamentary gifts have to be valued at greater than $5,000 in order to receive capital gains tax exemptions and hence removes any impediment that may discourage the donation of testamentary gifts.The second concession relates to distributions by charitable funds. Charitable funds will be allowed to claim income tax exemptions whether they provide money, property and benefits solely to charities based in Australia, solely to charities that are also deductible gift recipients or to a combination of these charities. Currently, an income tax exemption applies to charitable funds that provide money, property and benefits either solely to charities that are located in Australia and pursue their purposes in Australia or solely to charities that are deductible gift recipients. However, the law creates an inconsistency by not allowing charitable funds to obtain income tax exemptions when they provide money, property and benefits to both types of charities. This amendment allows funds that provide money, property and benefits to both types of charities to access an income tax exemption.The third concession relates to income tax exemption for charities and will allow prescribed private funds and ancillary funds that provide money, property and benefits solely to income tax exempt deductible gift recipients to qualify for income tax exemptions where the Commissioner of Taxation has endorsed these funds as being eligible for tax exemptions. The income tax law currently only allows ancillary funds and prescribed private funds access to an income tax exemption where they are charitable funds. Charitable ancillary funds and prescribed private funds only provide money, property and benefits to DGRs that are charities or for charitable purposes in benefiting DGRs. However, not all DGRs are endorsed as charities. DGRs that are income tax exempt but are not charities include some government bodies such as public ambulance services and research authorities. Consequently, ancillary funds and prescribed private funds cannot access an income tax exemption where they provide money, property or benefits to those bodies. To rectify this anomaly, this amendment will allow non-charitable ancillary funds and prescribed private funds to benefit from an income tax exemption where they provide money, property and benefits to DGRs that are income tax exempt, whether or not the DGR is a charity.The fourth policy change proposed under schedule 1 is to allow ancillary funds and prescribed private funds that are endorsed as income tax exempt entities to be entitled to a refund of franking credits. The income tax law currently allows endorsed and specifically listed DGRs and endorsed charities and charitable funds to claim a refund of franking credits on franked dividends. The vast majority of prescribed private funds already benefit from a refund of franking credits by virtue of being endorsed as an income tax exempt charity. However, an unintended consequence of this is that non-charitable prescribed private funds are not automatically entitled to this concession. This measure ensures that non-charitable prescribed private funds will be able to access a refund of franking credits on the same basis as charitable prescribed private funds. Non-charitable prescribed private funds endorsed under the new exemption will also be entitled to a refund of franking credits.The amendment proposed in schedule 2 to this bill relates to international shipping and airline profits. It is technical in nature and corrects an unintended outcome from the recently expanded foreign branch profits exemption by the New International Tax Arrangements (Participation Exemption and Other Measures) Act 2004. The expanded exemption, in conjunction with Australia’s treaties, could have resulted in foreign branch income and gains derived from the operation of ships or aircraft in international traffic not being taxed in Australia or the country in which the company operates.The expanded foreign branch income exemption will not apply to an Australian company’s foreign branch income and gains from the operation of ships or aircraft in international traffic. This means that Australian companies will continue to be taxed in the same way as they were before the start of the expanded foreign branch income exemption. This amendment ensures that certain foreign branch income and capital gains of an Australian company are included in its assessable income. This will be implemented through a change to the foreign branch income exemption in section 23AH of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.Australia has exclusive rights under most of its tax treaties to tax an Australian company’s foreign branch profits from the operation of ships or aircraft in international traffic. This is different to the tax treatment of other business profits derived through a foreign branch. The different tax treatment for those profits reflects the practical difficulties in allocating the income and expenses between countries in determining the profits from the operation of ships or aircraft in international traffic. The expansion to the foreign branch profits exemption meant that Australia would not tax those profits derived through foreign branches in treaty countries.The amendment to section 23AH preserves the way some Australian companies with foreign branches were taxed prior to the implementation of the New International Tax Arrangements (Participation Exemption and Other Measures) Act 2004. That act applies to income years starting on or after 1 July 2004. This amendment will also apply from that time to ensure that income and capital gains derived by an Australian company from the operation of ships or aircraft in international traffic through a foreign branch do not escape taxation. The amendment applies to the income and capital gains derived through foreign branches in all foreign countries—that is, there is no distinction between listed and unlisted countries, treaty or non-treaty countries or whether or not tax was paid on the amounts in any foreign country. The Australian company may be entitled to foreign tax credits under section 160AF of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for foreign tax paid.Schedule 3 to this bill amends the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to allow disclosure of relevant information to the Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia. The primary role of the Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia is to report and investigate misconduct by Western Australian public officers and public sector agencies. The Commissioner of Taxation can release taxpayer information to certain law enforcement agencies, such as police forces and various crime commissions, if the commissioner is satisfied that the information is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been committed.Subsection 2(1) of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 includes an exhaustive definition of ‘law enforcement agency’ and includes state and national bodies responsible for crime and corruption investigation. The Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia, which was established by the Corruption and Crime Commission Act 2003 (WA), replaces the Anti-Corruption Commission in Western Australia and the Royal Commission relating to the Conduct of Western Australian Police Officers.The Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia has all the powers that the Anti-Corruption Commission had, as well as the powers of the police royal commission. The police royal commission was an eligible royal commission under the definition of ‘authorised royal commission officer’ for the purposes of section 3E of the TAA 1953. As the new Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia is not an eligible royal commission, an amendment to the tax law would be required to enable the use of relevant taxation information by the new commission. The amendments insert the new Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia into the definitions of ‘law enforcement agency’ and ‘head’ under subsection 2(1) of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to enable the commissioner to disclose relevant taxation information under section 3E of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to the Corruption and Crime Commission of Western Australia to assist with investigations into misconduct by public officers which may involve serious offences or the making of a proceeds of crime order.The fourth measure under this bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 to make a technical correction to the anomaly that allows government institutions that are charitable institutions at law to be eligible for fringe benefits tax rebateable employer status. Schedule 10 of the Tax Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Act 2004 introduced a requirement for charities, public benevolent institutions and health promotion charities to be endorsed by the Commissioner of Taxation in order to access certain taxation concessions, including FBT rebateable employer status. FBT rebateable employers are eligible for a 48 per cent rebate of the FBT amount that would otherwise be payable. This amendment will clarify that certain government institutions of the Commonwealth, states or territories that are accepted as charitable institutions at law will continue to be ineligible for fringe benefits tax rebateable employer status from 1 July 2005.Finally, schedule 5 to this bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to standardise the age criteria for dependent children in respect of whom a taxpayer may be eligible for certain taxation concessions. Currently, the dependent child age criteria vary across entitlements such that a taxpayer may take a child into account when claiming the medical expenses offset but may not take the same child into account when determining the family thresholds for the Medicare levy or the Medicare levy surcharge. A single set of age criteria will provide consistency and simplicity for taxpayers.Prior to the introduction of this bill, the dependent child age test for the housekeeper, child-housekeeper, zone and overseas defence force tax offset, as well as the Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge provisions, was a child of less than 16 years of age who was not a student; or a full-time student of less than 25 years of age. This differs from the dependent child age criteria for the medical expenses tax offset, where a dependent child is a child of the taxpayer and is less than 21 years of age; and a child under 16 years of age who is not a student; or a full-time student under 25 years of age. For the family tax benefit part A, a dependent child is an individual aged under 21 or an individual who has turned 21 but is aged under 25 and is undertaking full-time study.The amendments will adjust the dependent child age criteria for the housekeeper, child-housekeeper, zone and overseas forces tax offsets, the notional dependent child tax offset, the notional sole parent tax offset, the Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge and will standardise the definition such that a dependant is a child less than 21 years of age who is not a student. The criterion for students will remain that they are less than 25 years of age. Standardising the age criteria for dependent children will allow more families to benefit from the dependant related tax offsets and the Medicare levy and the Medicare levy surcharge family threshold. I support these five changes in this bill which will improve the Australian taxation system. I commend the bill to the House.
debateinfo: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (2005 MEASURES NO. 3) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
content: —Labor supports this legislation but has moved a second reading amendment, which I also support. The amendment condemns the government for failing to pursue meaningful tax reform, for failing to seriously address the problem of effective marginal tax rates in the 2005-06 budget and for continuing to introduce tax bills with significant errors and anomalies requiring costly and cumbersome legislative correction. Tax Laws Amendment (2005 Measures No. 3) Bill 2005 is an example of such a bill. It corrects a number of errors that have been made previously in the drafting of legislation.Just by way of example, schedule 2 corrects a very large error in an international tax bill that was introduced last year. The New International Tax Arrangements (Participation Exemption and Other Measures) Act 2004 creates a situation whereby income and capital gains from ships and aircraft of Australian companies may not be taxed anywhere, either in Australia or in the country in which the company’s foreign branch operates. That would have constituted a substantial revenue leakage, but it is not the only example. Schedule 4 relates to a ‘fringe benefits tax rebateable employer’—that is, an employer who is the beneficiary of concessionary fringe benefits tax arrangements. In this case, Taxation Law Amendment Bill (No. 1) of 2004 amended the charities law so as to ensure that many government bodies, including museums, art galleries and public universities, could get an exemption from 1 July 2005. That would cost in the order of $20 million a year. So Tax Laws Amendment (2005 Measures No 3) Bill 2005 is amending Taxation Law Amendment Bill (No. 1) of 2004, which was amending the Income Tax Act. So we are amending amendments because errors were made in the drafting.Schedule 5 is another example. It seeks to rectify a situation where the age criteria for dependent children, for the purpose of taxpayers claiming concessions in relation to their dependants, at present differ from one case to another or from one part of the Income Tax Act to another. In schedule 5 the government is seeking to standardise the age of dependency to provide a single set of age criteria which will give some consistency for taxpayers.That is a bit of the flavour of what the government is doing with these taxation law amendment bills. These bills come into the House with monotonous regularity and by and large they are amendments to deal with anomalies, problems and even earlier amendments to the Income Tax Act which were drafted in error. It is a timely reminder of the state of the income tax system in Australia. That is why the Labor second reading amendment calls for genuine reform of the income tax system.Every member of this parliament will remember the Treasurer, in 1999 and 2000, boasting how he had devised a streamlined new tax system for a new century and that this would radically simplify the Australian tax system. Nothing could have been further from the truth. When the government was seeking the support of the Australian people to form a government in 1996, the then Leader of the Opposition and now Prime Minister of Australia said that he would set a goal of cutting red tape by 50 per cent. Upon winning government, he told the Alan Jones program that the so-called ‘streamlined new tax system for a new century’ would greatly simplify the income tax system—not only simplify it but radically reduce the size of the Income Tax Act. When the government came to office in 1996 the Income Tax Act ran to around 3,500 pages and it is now at least 9,000 pages.On top of the much more complex Income Tax Act, the Australian people are now confronted with the GST, itself a very complex tax. So rather than simplifying the tax system in this country the government has made it ever more complex. I note, in yet another announcement by the government, that it is now having another go at simplifying the income tax arrangements for Australia. I wish the government well. But, on past performance, whenever the government sets a goal of simplifying the income tax system it makes it ever more complex. I look forward to the outcome of yet another process that the government has announced to simplify the tax system.I turn now to an issue which is part of the second reading amendment, and that is the failure to seriously address the problem of effective marginal tax rates in the 2005-06 budget. The main change that the government made to the income tax scales in the budget was to provide a very generous tax cut to members of parliament and to others who earn in the $100,000 to $125,000 range. That income tax cut amounts to $65 a week, but I point out that that does not include the impact of another measure which enjoyed very strong support on budget night from coalition members, and that was the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge. The abolition of that surcharge is of great value to people on high incomes—and here I talk about incomes of $125,000. If those people are making a 12 per cent contribution to superannuation, then the tax cut of $65 a week will become a tax cut of $94 when the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge is counted.Just a few days later, of course, MPs were able to achieve a pay rise. At the same time the government was putting submissions to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which, in effect, would amount to a reduction in the real value of the minimum wage. This is the fundamental reason for Labor opposing the tax cuts in the budget—because the government has skewed them so heavily towards the higher income end of the scale, leaving lower and middle income earners with a grand tax cut of $6 a week. But the problem does not just sit there. Over time, most Australians have some sense that they are being fleeced by the government. That is because they are being fleeced by the government through bracket creep.I refer to a number of occupations with which all Australians could identify, ranging from hairdressers to farmhands. In the context of the terrible drought that we have at the moment the Australian people would be interested in the welfare of farmhands. I refer to cleaners, shop assistants, receptionists, hospitality workers, clerks, factory workers, motor mechanics, enrolled nurses, machine operators, social workers and accounts clerks. What do all of these occupations have in common? They are the forgotten people. They are the people John Howard forgot in the last budget when he gave no tax cut at all to people earning less than $1,000 a week. According to official statistics, people in each and every one of these occupations earn less than $1,000 a week. As if that is not bad enough, given that they only received a $4 sandwich and milkshake tax cut in 2003—the only one since the GST came in, with no tax cut in the previous budget—in this budget they receive only $6 a week. But, using budget projections of wages growth and inflation, it is not too difficult to calculate the creeping impact of the income tax system for the forgotten people. And that is that as their incomes rise, purely because of inflation not because of real income growth, inflation takes more and more of their income into higher income tax brackets even though, in real terms, they have not earned anymore. Using the projections that are in the budget I have been able to calculate the impact of the government’s proposed tax scales over the next four years. The truth is very disturbing.By 2008-09, which is the end of the budget period, a hairdresser would be paying $17 a week extra in bracket creep simply because of the effects of inflation, not because of any growth in real income. So here is the government raking it in from hairdressers in this country who would be paying $17 a week more. That seems to be a pretty large number in the context of a purported tax cut of $6 a week. In fact, they will be paying $17 a week more. But it gets a lot worse. A farmhand will be paying $20.75 more; a cleaner, $20.30 more; a shop assistant, nearly $22 more; a receptionist, also nearly $22 more; a hospitality worker, again $22 more; an office clerk, $26 more; and—going to another category—a social worker, $31 more. That is what the government is doing—that is the caper. It is obtaining from the forgotten people, through bracket creep, the revenue to be able to fund the income tax cuts at the top and still keep the budget in surplus.It is instructive to compare that with the tax scales that the Leader of the Opposition unveiled as an alternative in his budget reply. Under those tax scales, which are much fairer, these occupations are in every respect better off as a result of the tax cuts. Most of the occupations—for example, office clerk, labourer, factory worker, motor mechanic, enrolled nurse, machine operator, social worker and accounts clerk—would have real tax cuts, not only in the coming years but by the end of the projection period. So the fundamental difference between Labor’s tax cuts and the coalition’s tax cuts is that the coalition’s tax cuts are illusory because bracket creep is larger than the tax cut that the coalition has announced.To borrow a phrase from the Treasurer, the coalition’s so-called tax cuts do not deliver a true tax cut to the forgotten people ‘not for one day or for one dollar’. Never are they ahead. In 2005-06 every one of them are behind. There is no real tax relief because the collection of revenue through bracket creep from these occupations exceeds $6, so they are all worse off. That is testimony to the fundamental difference between the coalition and Labor. The coalition is prepared to use bracket creep to fleece the forgotten people, middle-income earners, in order to pay for the tax cuts for high-income earners and to pay for the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge.In the 13 years of the previous Labor government, Labor provided seven tax cuts returning all of bracket creep and more—not necessarily to exactly the same people, but in aggregate it was all of bracket creep and more. The Treasurer in his National Press Club appearance here at Parliament House the day after the budget said that the tax cuts were all in advance of bracket indexation. That statement is highly misleading. The only reason he was able to make that point, the only feather with which he was trying to fly, was the fact that in the year 2000 the government did introduce very significant income tax cuts. But we were told at the time the purpose of those income tax cuts was partial compensation for a new, very large tax, the GST—a $36 billion tax. This is the orphan tax. It is the tax that the Howard government now says is not its own. The Auditor-General says the GST is a Commonwealth tax. The Australian Statistician says the GST is a Commonwealth tax. The Australian people say the GST is a Commonwealth tax. The only people who maintain the outrageous pretence that the GST is not a Commonwealth tax are the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and members of the coalition sitting opposite here and in the Senate.There is no real tax reform in the government’s tax arrangements. High effective marginal tax rates still apply for low- and middle-income earners, often, very commonly, exceeding 60 per cent. We hear arguments from business groups that the top marginal rate of 48½ per cent is some shocking deterrent to work and it removes incentives from people on those incomes. If 48½c removes incentives for people in a particular income range, surely 60c in the dollar is a greater deterrent. Yet the government’s tax cuts, far from constituting reform, have done virtually nothing to improve the work incentives for people on low- and middle-incomes.That is where we are in relation to the failure of this government to introduce meaningful tax reform, but it gets worse. The whole budget is predicated on the fact that in the last few years our mineral prices have gone through the roof. They have gone through the roof and now constitute the best terms of trade that this country has seen in 50 years. What we know about rising commodity prices is that sooner or later they will fall. The reason for that is that countries around the world, including Australia, will respond to the higher prices and increase mine capacity and, as a result of that extra capacity coming onto markets, sooner or later the prices of those mineral products will be depressed. What the government is doing here—apart from using bracket creep from low- and middle-income earners to pay for tax cuts for high-income earners—is using that temporary surge in national income, which is showing up to a significant extent in the taxable income of mining companies, and that temporary surge in tax revenue from mining companies to provide tax cuts especially to high-income earners in this country.The total is around $22 billion of tax cuts—not counting the superannuation tax surcharge, by the way—over the coming four years. The general economic problem that can be created as a result of that is, given that this surge in income is inevitably going to be temporary, what happens to those tax cuts when the surge in income is over? Will they remain affordable? Will the budget be put under extra pressure? The budget papers are full of references to the risk that this temporary surge in income may end even more quickly than the government’s projections suggest. So there is a real risk to the budget associated with using the proceeds of company tax to pay for tax cuts for high-income earners.That is one of the risks, but the other risk, about which I have spoken before, is that the tax cuts that will flow—to the extent that they are real tax cuts—will increase consumer spending at a time when the Reserve Bank of Australia is in the red zone and considering whether or not to increase interest rates. Labor’s critique of the government, before the last election and subsequently, is that it has committed $66 billion to a spending spree over four years. The result of this budget is that the $66 billion spending spree has become a $103 billion spending spree, and a lot of that is front-end loaded to this period now where consumer spending is already going very strongly.The risk is that the government is pouring fuel onto the flames of high consumer spending and that the Reserve Bank will, as an inflationary consequence of this, act to increase interest rates. If that happens, later in the year the $6 a week tax cut—which is not a genuine tax cut at all but the handing back of some small part of bracket creep—will be wiped out as a result of increases in mortgage interest rates. So this is not tax reform. The tax system is in urgent need of genuine reform and the government has compounded the economic risks facing this country by providing tax cuts for high-income earners at a time when the Reserve Bank is very concerned about the possibility of rising interest rates.

name: Southcott, Dr Andrew, MP
content: —The Jesuits have taken a line from the Bible to use as one of their maxims in education: to those whom much is given, much will be expected. While they use it in the area of education, it could apply equally in the area of corporate philanthropy. Australia does have a great tradition of corporate philanthropy. If you look at the art galleries and the universities around this country, you will see that many have received very significant endowments from people from the business world. Yet when we compare ourselves to the United States we see that the United States has a much more deeply entrenched tradition of corporate philanthropy.It was partly, I am sure, to encourage this spirit of corporate giving that the Prime Minister’s community and business partnerships were established, and since they have been established there have been many worthy winners of awards under that partnership. One which comes to mind at the moment is that of IT company Cisco Systems, who have had a famous collaboration with the Smith Family. It is expected that all employees of Cisco Systems, apart from doing their day job, will have an activity with this charity, the Smith Family. In 2001 Santos, in my home state of South Australia, announced that they would be endowing the University of Adelaide with a school of petroleum engineering. It was then, I think, about $25 million and was the largest example of corporate philanthropy at that time.The legislation which we are considering today, the Tax Laws Amendment (2005 Measures No. 3) Bill 2005, has five separate parts, but the first part deals with corporate philanthropy and tax concessions for corporate philanthropy. The first part deals with the removal of the capital gains threshold for certain testamentary gifts. There is an amendment introducing a new subsection, 118-60(1)(1A), into the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 which will deem any property with a value less than $5,000 as having been valued by the commissioner at a value of more than $5,000 for the purposes of the capital gains tax exemption. As a result of this deeming provision, property with a value of less than $5,000 will be eligible for the capital gains tax exemption.Reading this amendment just before speaking, it occurred to me that it is very complex. The intent of the legislation is to ensure that a testamentary gift be exempt from capital gains tax if it meets certain requirements set out in the Income Tax Assessment Act. This amendment is saying that if something is less than $5,000 the Commissioner of Taxation will deem it to be more than $5,000, because that is what another piece of legislation requires. It just seems to me that this amendment could have been written in simpler language. We have had TLIP, and there is the idea of using plain English in the tax legislation. There may be a very good reason for the way this amendment is written but, when I saw it, I thought it could have been done in a simpler way.The section referring to the ‘distributions to charitable funds’ tidies up the legislation so that charitable funds can claim an income tax exemption. Currently, it has to go either to charities located in Australia, which pursue their purposes in Australia, or to charities which have been accepted and registered by the ATO as DGRs. It has to go to one or the other. The next amendment will enable charitable funds to claim an income tax exemption if they distribute funds to both. The next section deals with an income tax exemption. At the moment, private funds, ancillary funds, cannot claim an income tax exemption if they distribute their funds to DGRs which are not endorsed as charities. We have an amendment that will deal with that.The last bit in the corporate philanthropy section deals with the refunding of franking credits. This will entitle non-charitable prescribed private funds to the refund on the same basis as charitable prescribed funds. Having said that, these are sensible amendments which arise from recommendations made by the corporate sector, who want to get more involved in the area of corporate philanthropy.The second part deals with profits derived from international shipping and airline operations. Again, this amendment is consequent on previous legislation considered in the parliament which had the unintended consequence of affecting the taxation of Australian companies involved in international shipping or airline operations. Under our tax treaties and tax law, Australia does have exclusive taxing rights to Australian companies in respect of the profits from ships or aircraft in international traffic. One of the consequences of the New International Tax Arrangements (Participation Exemption and Other Measures) Act 2004 is that foreign income from Australian companies involved in shipping and airline operations would have been exempt. This amendment addresses that.The third part of this legislation deals with secrecy provisions. It allows the disclosure of information collected by the Commissioner of Taxation to the newly established Western Australian Corruption and Crime Commission. The legislation includes the commission as an eligible recipient of relevant information collected by the commissioner.The fourth section deals with the area of fringe benefits tax. Again, this is to ensure that any institutions which are characterised as an emanation of government cannot receive fringe benefits tax rebatable employer status. This is significant. It leads to a 48 per cent reduction in the fringe benefits tax paid by an employer. It is available to charities, public benevolent institutions and health promotion charities to reduce the fringe benefits tax they pay by 48 per cent. It has been possible that government bodies of the Commonwealth, the states or territories could have been eligible for the rebate from 1 July 2005. The measure makes sure that the established legal principle remains the same—that is, institutions which are an emanation of government within the established meaning of charity at law will continue to be unable to claim this rebate.Schedule 5 is an alignment or harmonisation so that there will be a uniform age criteria for dependent children. The age at which a dependent child who is not a student will be able to be considered as a dependent child goes up to 21. Currently, the age is 16 for a number of things—for example, housekeeper-child, housekeeper’s-own and overseas defence forces offsets. The Medicare levy, Medicare levy surcharge and the medical expenses tax offset are more in line with what has been considered under family tax benefit part A—that is, 21 years for someone who is not a student, and 25 years for someone who is a full-time student.I was not able to vote on the income tax cuts legislation which went through the House last week, but I support it very strongly. One piece of unfinished business from the new tax system in 2000 was that the government were unable to get through the income tax cuts that we originally promised at the 1998 election. Last year in the budget, we were able to take advantage of the advent of Mark Latham as the Leader of the Labor Party, because he had advocated income tax cuts for people on higher incomes. We did that in 2004. It is only because of that that we were able to get the top two thresholds increased from $52,000. The tax cuts announced in this year’s budget are very significant.The Labor Party really has got this wrong. When you have steelworkers at Port Kembla who, through overtime, are in the top marginal tax rate and 48.5c of every extra dollar they earn is going to the government and not into their pockets, it really is a strange Labor Party. Labor identities like Bill Shorten have identified this politics of envy and of stopping people who actually want to work more, earn more, save more and take home more of what they earn. We should be allowed to do that. We also face a problem when there are a million Australians overseas—for many of them, coming back is quite punitive when they have worked in places like Hong Kong, with its low marginal rate of taxation, and face being taxed at 48.5c in the dollar in Australia. I very strongly support the tax cuts and I hope we will see them pass through the Senate in time for employers to get their withholding schedules right. I support the bill and I would be interested in an answer to the question I raised.

name: Brough, Mal, MP
role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
content: —in reply—I thank all of the members who have participated in this debate on the Tax Laws Amendment (2005 Measures No. 3) Bill 2005. As many members have mentioned, this bill continues the government’s program of modifications and improvements to the tax laws. The first measure outlined in the bill gives charitable funds, ancillary funds and prescribed private funds greater flexibility in the way they make donations to other funds. It does this by removing the limitation on capital gains tax exemption for testamentary gifts to charities and by giving various funds the ability to make donations to a wider range of organisations without losing tax concessions.In his contribution the member for Boothby raised some very pertinent points about the way in which the federal government, and the Prime Minister in particular, have really led the business community in this country to be more philanthropic in their attitude. As a direct result we have seen a big jump in foundations being established and moneys going to worthwhile charitable organisations. I commend all those organisations, businesses and individuals who have taken up that challenge and used the leadership displayed by the Prime Minister and the supporting policies to add to the great fabric of the Australian community.The member for Boothby also queried the reasoning behind one of the measures contained in the bill. As it stands, you can claim capital gains tax when you provide a testamentary gift when that gift is valued at over $5,000. Until this bill becomes law, gifts under $5,000 do not have that benefit. I am advised that the reason for the way the amendment is structured is simplicity, so the tax office can say that, for all intents and purposes, there is no difference between gifts, regardless of value. I hope that clarifies the member for Boothby’s question. Clearly, there is more than one way to deal with these issues. This is the way that the draftspeople have deemed to satisfy the need, clarify the law and, most importantly, provide the capital gains tax relief to those who bequeath gifts valued at less than $5,000.On the second point, by way of background, under the current law the income tax exemption for charitable funds has a very limited application. This is unfortunate, and that is why we have moved to correct this. It is only available where charitable funds distribute solely to charities that are located in and are pursuing their purposes in Australia or solely to deductible gift recipients, but there is no exemption if they make distributions to a combination of both of these types of organisations—both worthy organisations and both able to receive those gifts in totality from one organisation but not if they choose to spread their charity around. The proposed measure will ensure that those charitable funds can access income tax exemptions if they distribute all of their funds to either organisation or a combination of both kinds of organisation.Additionally, under the current law, ancillary and prescribed private funds can only access income tax exemption if they distribute funds and/or property to deductible gift recipients that are also charities. But they cannot be income tax exempt if they distribute to deductible gift recipients that are only income tax exempt. The changes will mean that the ancillary and prescribed private funds will not lose the income tax exemption if they choose to distribute solely to deductible gift recipients that are charities and to deductible gift recipients that are income tax exempt or to both, providing them with greater flexibility and, once again, ensuring that their charity dollars go to as many worthwhile organisations as possible.Finally, and in addition to the benefits outlined above, this measure will improve access to refunds of excess franking credits. The existing law allows refunds to deductible gift recipients, endorsed charities and charitable funds. Under this bill, this will be extended to ancillary and prescribed private funds that distribute solely to income tax exempt deductible gift recipients. Ultimately, the measures will ensure that the tax law operates equitably across the range of philanthropic and charitable donations. In essence, it will allow funds a greater choice in the distribution of moneys. These changes also give effect to the government’s announcement in the 2004-05 budget.The next measure outlined in this bill is technical in nature. At present, the recently expanded foreign branch profits exemption can, when viewed in conjunction with Australia’s treaty obligations, be interpreted to mean that the international shipping and airline profits derived by Australian owned foreign branches are not subject to both Australian and overseas taxation regimes. I am sure that they would be happy with that arrangement, but of course it is not suitable and, basically, would ultimately result in a leakage of taxation from Australia. That was never intended by the legislation and through this bill we are now ensuring that those amounts will be taxed in Australia consistent with Australian tax policy. I believe that the member for Rankin in his address suggested that there would be a major financial impact as a result of this having not been picked up. I can assure him that is not the case, but, if we had not moved to rectify it in this bill, it may have been the case in the future.The third measure in this bill concerns the release of information by the Commissioner of Taxation. Currently the commissioner is able to release taxpayer information to certain law enforcement agencies if he is satisfied that this is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been committed or whether it is necessary to the making of proceedings of a crime order. The proposed measure will add the Corruption and Crime Commissioner of Western Australia to the list of law enforcement agencies able to receive relevant taxpayer information from the commissioner.The fourth measure outlined in the bill concerns a technical amendment to the fringe benefits tax law. The existing fringe benefits tax law provides in effect that the fringe benefits tax rebate applies to a scientific, charitable or public education institution as long as they are not a Commonwealth, state or territory institution. In the course of updating the law relating to charities, consequential changes were made to the rebate provisions. I should clarify a matter. The member for Rankin suggested that there would be a leakage in revenue as a result of this measure. I can assure him that is not the case. If these measures were not implemented, then the cost would be in the order of $80 million or $90 million going forward, but there has been no leakage in the revenue base.The last measure in this bill simplifies the rules for concessions which are contingent on having a dependent child of a particular age. Historically, different concessions have had different age criteria. This measure standardises the dependant child age criteria used to determine entitlement to a housekeeper, child housekeeper, medical expenses and zone tax offsets as well as the Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge. The introduction of a single set of age criteria—that is, a child less than 21 years or a full-time student less than 25 years—gives much-needed consistency to the law. I guess in some small way it is a down payment on what many people are calling for: a simplification of tax laws. This does just that in these areas. Also, as the revised age criteria are more generous than the various criteria currently in place, they will allow more taxpayers to access dependant related offsets, including the concessional Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge threshold offsets and the Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge family thresholds.The member for Hunter, in his response to this bill, was also concerned about schedule 4, ‘Fringe benefits tax—rebatable employer status of certain government institutions’. I believe he stated at the time something to the effect that Labor reserved their right to change their mind in the Senate, having given it the okay in this place and voting for it—and I acknowledge his nodding of the head. This really goes to the amendments that the Labor Party have put forward here and the position they have taken on the general tax cuts. What we are really looking for from the opposition is a decision. The only decisions that they seem to be making of late are to determine not to make a decision. I know it is difficult to make a decision but that is what government is about and that is what this side of the House does day in and day out. We made a decision, for argument’s state, to give tax cuts to every Australian from 1 July this year. The Labor Party have made a decision that they are not sure whether or not the Australian public should have those, and I guess they have reconfirmed that with their statements in the House tonight on these issues.

content: —As the member for Petrie and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence rightly says, the Labor Party are very confused at the moment—and that is fine. It is fine for a political party to be confused but it is not acceptable when they want to go out and confuse the public, particularly the business community, over the tax cuts that are before us.The member for Rankin, in his final couple of statements tonight, said that the tax cuts that come into effect from 1 July this year—which the Labor Party cannot make up their mind about but say the Australian public should not have—are not tax cuts at all. That goes to what the member for Lilley has always stated: the $600 family payments are not real money. So we are starting to see some consistency within the Labor Party: consistency in not understanding that when Australian families receive a tax cut they get the money in their hand. Australian families can recognise that, even if the Labor Party cannot. While the public can appreciate receiving $600 child payments, the Labor Party cannot. I guess that is why they are sitting in opposition and are in the doldrums with the polls that have come out today. The public understand these issues. The coalition understand these issues, and we are here to ensure that we provide the best possible governance for the Australian public and in doing so we move these amendments.

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
content: —The Labor Party have made a definite decision to support the Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2005. We are always happy to make a definite decision to support a bill on two bases: (1) that we get sufficient notice of the bill, so we have an opportunity to study it and consult relevant stakeholders, and (2) that we are sure there can be no unintended consequences. You cannot determine with any great confidence that there are no unintended consequences when the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer—who is now scurrying out of the chamber in embarrassment, one would think—introduces bills and expects us to absorb them and pass them in one day in the absence of any opportunity to consult stakeholders.The minister absolutely misrepresented me in his summation on the last bill, the Tax Laws Amendment (2005 Measures No. 3) Bill 2005. The point I made in the House is that we will support that bill in this place but, given this is another rushed event and the minister’s record of mistakes in this portfolio, before giving consent to the bill in the Senate we will take the opportunity to consult relevant stakeholders. We will reserve the right to oppose that bill or seek to amend it if unintended consequences are apparent, as has been the case with so many other bills that this minister has introduced. But surely he cannot get the bill that is now before the House wrong, because this is effectively a non-controversial housekeeping bill. It raises the low-income thresholds for the Medicare levy and the Medicare levy surcharge by the consumer price index. It amends the Medicare Levy Act 1986 and the A New Tax System (Medicare Levy Surcharge—Fringe Benefits) Act 1999 to increase the Medicare levy low-income threshold amounts for individuals, families and pensioners below pension age. It will also increase the phase-in limits as a result of the increased threshold amounts.The Medicare Levy Act 1986 provides that no Medicare levy is payable for low-income individuals and families where the taxable income or combined family taxable income does not exceed the threshold amounts. The Medicare levy shades in at a rate of 20c in the dollar where the taxable income or combined family taxable income exceeds the threshold amounts. A Medicare levy surcharge of one per cent applies on taxable incomes in certain cases where high-income taxpayers do not have private patient hospital cover. The surcharge also applies to reportable fringe benefits in certain cases where taxpayers do not have private patient hospital cover. However, a family member would otherwise be liable for the surcharge where the total amount of the person’s taxable income and reportable fringe benefits do not exceed the individual low-income threshold amount. Unlike the Medicare levy, there is no shading in of the surcharge above the threshold amount.Given that this is a straightforward bill, Labor supports its speedy passage through this House and the Senate. This is important, because these measures have to be in place by the end of June this year. Whilst supporting this bill, Labor does not endorse this government’s general approach to Medicare and the health system of this country. On that basis, I move:That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for failing to accept Labor’s proposals which would increase the threshold which senior Australians do not have to pay the Medicare Levy by $442, thus missing the opportunity to increase equity in the funding necessary to ensure that:Medicare is sustainable over the long-term;the Government’s failure to fund a sustainable strategy to increase bulk billing rates will be overcome;the blowouts in the Medicare safety net, concealed from the public, will be funded; andthe Federal Government will be able to work with the states on health reform”.This government claims to be the friend of Medicare but, given the Prime Minister’s track record, we on this side of the House and the Australian community know his real feelings on Medicare. He has stated them publicly on a sufficient number of occasions for us to be sure about them. The Prime Minister can be a friend of Medicare when it is politically expedient. There is no greater example of that than during last year’s federal election campaign, when the Prime Minister believed there was so much political opportunity in supporting Medicare that he was prepared to throw any amount of money at it. He was prepared to throw at Medicare any amount of money necessary to secure a fourth term for himself.I am, of course, referring mainly to the Medicare safety net. The Prime Minister was prepared to back a blow-out of $800 million in the Medicare safety net in order to secure his re-election. We now know with certainty that the Prime Minister and his health minister, the member for Warringah, were more than conscious of the blow-out in the Medicare safety net in the lead-up to the election. They knew about it at the time of the PEFO. In fact, when the Prime Minister stood up in Brisbane to deliver his election manifesto he knew that the safety net was blowing out substantially. But what did they do? They gave an ironclad guarantee—no conditions, no caveats, no questions asked—that the Medicare safety net would remain in place unchanged.What did we get after the election? We got a different story. We got what must have been the most significant sleight of hand in the history of our federation—the biggest backflip we have seen in the political history of this country. Let me remind the House what the Prime Minister had to say on 14 April about the Medicare safety net. He said:Since the election, it has become apparent that the cost of it is going to be even greater than we thought at the time and that is the reason why we believed in the interests of maintaining it, we have to increase the safety net.Of course, he was referring to the threshold. He went on to say:Well, certainly we didn’t say we were going to increase the threshold, no, but at the time of the last election, we did not believe it was going to blow out quite to the extent that we believe it is now.Who in the Australia community believes that statement? It is on the record. We know for a fact that the government was aware of the blow-out, because we had our own health policies costed and, to do that, the safety net had to be costed because we were claiming it is a saving. We know that the government was fully aware of the blow-out in the safety net. The government deceived the Australian people and it should be held to account.What does this mean for the so-called charter of budget honesty—a mechanism which the government sold to the Australia community as a means of holding the government to account on budgetary measures? The charter of budget honesty was sold as a means of ensuring that, when a government goes to an election, its election promises can be fully costed and paid for within the budgetary context; but we now know that it stands for nothing and means nothing. There is no greater evidence of that than what happened during the last election campaign in terms of the Medicare safety net. The charter of budget honesty is just a tool of government to make things more difficult for the opposition in the lead-up to a federal election. We now know that the opposition has to be held to account under the charter of budget honesty but the government does not feel a need to be held to account.Why did the Medicare safety net blow-out? Because it does not contain any incentives. It is not a policy that any sensible government would have introduced other than during an election period or in the context of an election. By contrast, Labor has long had a plan to raise bulk-billing rates by providing GPs with an incentive to bulk bill. The Prime Minister often talks about incentives. So why not provide some incentive for GPs to bulk bill? Because, in the election context, the Prime Minister saw an opportunity to spend up big while having in mind during that whole period the opportunity to renege on his promises after the election.I will make one last point because I know the Manager of Opposition Business has a bit to say about the Medicare safety net and like matters. Last Wednesday at about 6.30 pm we gave government members an opportunity to increase the Medicare threshold, the point at which senior Australians in particular pay a Medicare levy, and that was by offering the government members an opportunity to back Labor’s low-income and welfare to work tax offset. That was a perfect opportunity for government members to do something real about assisting seniors with their medical costs in this country. In addition to that, it was an opportunity for those on the other side to do something serious about effective marginal tax rates in this country, putting incentive into the work processes and giving incentive for people to move from welfare to work.We did not have any serious debate about Labor’s amendments last Wednesday night. This is the height of arrogance from the government. All we got was the Treasurer making a rare appearance, pouring scorn on the Labor Party, the member for Lilley, the Leader of the Opposition and all opposition members, but not at any time taking the opportunity to dissect Labor’s tax package to have a look at Labor’s low-income tax offset and what it would have done for the medical costs of senior Australians in this country.In conclusion, Labor is always happy to support sensible amendments in this place as long as we are given appropriate notice and an opportunity to consult the relevant stakeholders. Where we are not given that opportunity we reserve the right to hold up bills if necessary. We have been vindicated in that approach twice in recent times. One was on non-renewable long-term contracts and the imposition of the GST on them and the other was the effect of the GST on inbound tour operators. On both occasions we were able to highlight flaws in government bills which we were expected to support and give passage to in just one day—we certainly will not do it. But on this occasion, given due notice was given and the simple nature of the bill, the opposition is happy to give it support.

name: Richardson, Kym, MP
content: —I rise today in support of the Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2005. The purpose of this bill is to increase the low-income thresholds for the Medicare levy and the Medicare levy surcharge in accordance with the consumer price index. This increase will ensure that low-income individuals and families will not be disadvantaged due to small increases in their taxable income which are no greater than the increase in inflation. This bill will ensure that the protection awarded to low-income earners is not eroded by increases in the cost of living and small wage increases aimed at keeping up with those increases in the cost of living.The Medicare levy low-income threshold for pensioners below age pension age is also being increased in this bill. This will ensure that these pensioners do not pay the Medicare levy while they do not have an income tax liability. In 2001-02 the Howard government substantially increased the pensioner tax offset to allow these pensioners to earn more before they faced a tax liability. Since then, this government has increased the Medicare levy threshold to ensure that these pensioners who do not have a tax liability also do not have to pay the Medicare levy.From the 2004-05 financial year the Medicare levy low-income threshold will increase to $15,902 for individuals and $26,834 for families. The additional amount of threshold for each dependant child or student will also be increased to $2,464. For the same financial year the threshold for pensioners below age pension age will increase to $19,252. These amendments will take effect for the 2004-05 financial year so that individuals lodging tax returns at the end of this financial year will be covered by the alterations.This is an exceptionally important bill because it ensures low-income earners are protected from the burden of having to pay the Medicare levy. Alterations such as this to the levy thresholds in accordance with CPI ensure that the protection provided by the thresholds is not eroded by the passage of time and the increases in inflation. I commend the bill the House.
debateinfo: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (MEDICARE LEVY AND MEDICARE LEVY SURCHARGE) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Gillard, Julia, MP
content: —I rise to speak in this debate on the Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2005 and the second reading amendment standing in the name of the member for Hunter, which I have seconded. The bill amends the Medicare Levy Act 1986 and the A New Tax System (Medicare Levy Surcharge—Fringe Benefits) Act 1999 to increase the Medicare levy low-income threshold amounts for individuals, families and pensioners below pension age. It will also increase the phase-in limits as a result of the increased threshold amounts. As outlined by the member for Hunter, that in and of itself is a non-controversial proposition from the government. But there are many things that are deeply controversial about our health system and about this government’s conduct of it, and they are comprehended by the second reading amendment.The first huge item that you cannot move beyond when talking about health and the Howard government is the appalling breach of trust of the Australian public that arose from the Minister for Health and Ageing, Minister Abbott, breaking his rock solid, ironclad guarantee to the Australian community, given pre-election, that post-election the Howard government would keep the Medicare safety net and its thresholds unchanged. We know that Minister Abbott has not broken his word—he has smashed it. We know there is a conspiracy which lies behind the breaking of his word, because of what Minister Abbott has said on the public record. He has tried to justify this broken promise by saying that when he gave the promise he had not the ‘slightest inkling’ that the Medicare safety net would be changed after the election. There are reasonable grounds to believe that in making that ‘slightest inkling’ statement Minister Abbott was not really being frank with the Australian community on yet another occasion. It is those matters that the opposition are pursuing and will pursue in Senate estimates, through freedom of information requests in this parliament, and in any other forum available to us until we get the truth.I went to some of these matters last night but, just to remind the House and to focus specifically on the unbelievability of Minister Abbott’s explanation in relation to this matter, there is a series of events—Labor has referred to it as the time line of deceit—about the costings of the Medicare safety net which means any reasonable person would have known that this program was blowing out fundamentally and that something would have to be done about it. I am particularly directing the attention of the House on this occasion to the media release that the minister issued on 28 June 2004 when he went out and boasted that 415,500 people had reached the threshold for the Medicare safety net. This was against a backdrop of the scheme being budgeted for 450,000 people to qualify in a full year. So by then Minister Abbott would have had to have known that if almost the number of eligible people who were supposed to reach the threshold in 12 months had already reached it in three months then there was a fundamental problem with costs. That was way back on 28 June 2004.In July 2004, the Herald Sun newspaper revealed that an internal Health Insurance Commission audit had evidence of changed billing practices among doctors and that this very HIC audit report showed that more than 3,000 patients in Victoria went onto the safety net in only one month. The audit report revealed a $1.4 million blow-out in the scheme in Victoria in June alone. Even if the Minister for Health and Ageing was not aware of this HIC internal audit report—and one would wonder how he would be unaware of such a major report pointing to cost blow-outs in the Medicare safety net—I can warrant to the House about Minister Abbott’s everyday behaviour that he certainly reads his newspapers. He reads them or perhaps someone reads them for him, but in any event he is certainly advised as to what is in the newspapers. There is no way that such a major story from an investigative health journalist, on this occasion Jason Frenkel, would have escaped his attention. Jason Frenkel is well known as a health reporter and his report would have been treated as credible.From time to time people ask themselves, ‘Where is Jason Frenkel?’ I am sure the minister has sometimes asked himself that question when he has been looking for Jason Frenkel to try to give him some completely incorrect information with which to try to get a media story to tarnish the opposition. But we do know where Jason Frenkel was in July 2004. He was writing this very important investigative piece about a blow-out in the Medicare safety net. The saga went crescendoing on, with the revelation on 27 September 2004 that the Medicare safety net had blown out to $1.3 billion. That was, of course, revealed during the Charter of Budget Honesty process. We know that in August, in the lead-up to the election campaign, there was a veritable flurry of activity within the government about this Medicare safety net blow-out.

debateinfo: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (MEDICARE LEVY AND MEDICARE LEVY SURCHARGE) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Gillard, Julia, MP
content: —It was a rock solid, ironclad guarantee. If the minister can discard one of those, anything could happen next. We do know that in August 2004 the budget area of the Department of Finance and Administration commenced a closer examination of the Medicare safety net and this involved consultation with the Department of Health and Ageing. We know that Finance officials admit that they had better data, including spending data, with which to undertake this closer examination. We know that towards the end of the month these officials acknowledged that the program was growing faster than had been estimated at the time of the budget, we know that a Finance official was sufficiently concerned to make two to three calls to the office of the Minister for Finance and Administration to speak to his personal staff about the Medicare safety net and we know that the minister for finance has conceded that he was verbally briefed.What we do not know is who then said what to whom, but we suspect, and I think on very good grounds—because the Prime Minister, the Minister for Health and Ageing and the Minister for Finance and Administration have all refused to answer questions on discussions held between them post this point—that they, their officers and departmental officials were in a cabal canvassing changes to prune back costs on the Medicare safety net. Minister Abbott knew that, and he knew the day he walked out and gave a rock solid, ironclad guarantee that there was no way in the world that it was going to come true. And we are going to keep after that matter until we rock solid, ironclad prove it to every member of the Australian community.That is not the only broken promise dealt with in the second reading amendment. It is not the only very significant broken promise that the community has already had to face in the area of health. The government promised in the last election campaign that it would give $30 million extra for better outcomes for mental health programs. But, of course, when we saw the budget we saw that the amount of new money invested in better outcomes for mental health fell $18 million short of this pledge from the Howard government. It is disgraceful.This is an important program that enables people to go to GPs who have been trained up in dealing with mental health issues. I note the Parliamentary Secretary for Children and Youth Affairs at the table—and she will be very well aware of this. For many people in rural and regional Australia, the only place to get any assistance at all with mental illness is through the local GP. This program supports GPs to provide that assistance. The Howard government promised an extra $30 million for this program and only delivered $18 million.When I made that very clear and factual point, Minister Abbott had a spokeswoman from his office out trying to deny this clear truth. She was muttering about PIPs, SIPs and EPC. You might think, Mr Deputy Speaker, that she had descended to speaking gibberish or perhaps another language, but what she was trying to suggest was that somehow this $18 million shortfall did not really matter because now—for assistance with funding that enables GPs to service the mental health needs of their patients—GPs could turn to the practice incentive payments program, the so-called PIPs; the chronic disease service incentive payments program, the so called SIPs; or the Enhanced Primary Care Program, or EPC.If Minister Abbott’s staff member was right, then when you look at PIPs, SIPs or EPC you would see an extra $18 million, wouldn’t you? Because there was going to be $30 million extra, and instead of delivering it all through better outcomes for mental health they had decided—you would have thought from this spin from the minister’s staff member—to put $18 million of the new $30 million in PIPs, SIPs and EPC. But, looking at the budget papers, it does not look to me like there is an extra $18 million in PIPs, SIPs and EPC. We will be pursuing that matter this week in budget estimates, because we think $18 million did not get delivered and we think the excuse given for not delivering it is a transparent piece of spin that does not hold up to the light of day. As the Leader of the Opposition would say, it is a spin not a spend, and not a spend on an issue that really has no humour involved in it when we know that the burden of disease in the Australian community from mental health afflictions is so acute. It is acute across Australia but particularly in rural and regional areas as people deal with huge stress factors, including the consequences of the drought for their lives and their businesses.I would note, even if this $18 million turned up in the PIPs, SIPs and the EPC—and I have absolutely no confidence that it is going to do so—that mental health professionals do not believe that this is the best way for the $18 million to be delivered. They would like it delivered through better outcomes for mental health because PIPs, SIPs and the EPC are programs for people with chronic diseases, and there are many people who need mental health assistance who do not fulfil the chronic disease criteria. They are not people who are chronically ill; they are people who are battling a mental health episode at some stage in their lives and, with appropriate care and support, will make a full recovery. The best way for them to access additional assistance is through mental health programs, not chronic disease programs. Mr Deputy Speaker, I assure you the hunt for the $18 million will continue up hill and down dale through estimates—and I do not think we are going to find it.The cutbacks for health did not end there, of course. As we know, in the budget the government made an additional $1.3 billion in savings from cutting the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. This comes on top of the Howard government hiking the price of medicines by 27 per cent on 1 January. To be fair to the government, they alerted the community to that change before the election, but they did not tell the community that they were planning to rip a hole in the PBS safety net. They did that in the recent budget by changing the safety net threshold, adding two scripts per year to the number required to reach the safety net and also saying that scripts resupplied within 20 days will not count towards the PBS safety net. This is another attack on health.The government did not tell you before the election that it was planning to take calcium tablets off the PBS, putting up the price of calcium for people on concession cards—older Australians who would have accessed calcium on the PBS at the concessional copayment rate but who are now required to pay the full price. Many of them will not be able to pay the full price; so, instead of taking calcium and keeping their bone density up, many of them will no doubt fall victim to osteoporosis—a disease that already costs this country $1.9 billion per annum in health costs and a further $5.6 billion in indirect costs. If that is a smart idea then someone needs to explain it to me, because it just seems absurd.We note that the budget does not guarantee funding beyond December 2006 for the vaccine against the deadly pneumococcal disease for Australian children. The Labor Party shamed the Howard government into this initiative, but apparently we only managed to shame them until December 2006 because there is no certainty about the funding and provision of the pneumococcal vaccine beyond that point.There must be something about the minister for health and figures, because whenever he tries to deal with figures he invariably does not manage to get the truth out or gets it wrong. I am not sure whether this is an example related to truth-telling or an error, but I feel the need to correct a statement that the minister made in this House in question time on Monday, 30 May, which simply was not right. The minister, in an answer to a dorothy dixer—he could not have been taken by surprise or startled unless something is really going wrong with the government’s tactics committee, but presumably he was being asked a question he knew he was going to be asked—about funding for rural health, claimed:... through the rural health strategy, the government is spending an additional $830 million over four years ...This is nonsense. The $830 million is reauthorised money from the 2001-02 More Doctors, Better Services program. When that program was first funded, it was funded at $200 million a year. You used to spend $200 million a year on it and now you are going to spend $830 million over four years. One does not need to know much about inflation, particularly health inflation, to know that that increase of $30 million has barely taken into account indexation. There is certainly no part of that that could be described as truly additional funding. So the Minister for Health and Ageing was not right when he tried to claim in this place that there was a new $830 million in rural health. There is not, and not one country Australian should believe for one moment that there are extra services coming their way because of the statement made by the minister on that date.I conclude on a matter also dealt with by the second reading amendment. Apart from getting all of these things wrong, the minister does not even want to think about the biggest picture issue in health—the question of health reform. This minister has had more positions on health reform than most Australians have had hot dinners, ranging from a speculative, ‘What about I take over all the public hospitals?’ to, ‘It’s all a matter for the states,’ right through to, ‘I’ve given up on public sector health reform; now I’m going to focus on private hospitals.’ Every position under the sun one could have on health reform the minister has had at least once. Some of them he has had two or three times. But, whilst he might dance from position to position, the truth is he does not get anything done.The one thing the Howard government was going to do—and it was not the minister for health who was going to do it; it was the Prime Minister—was to have Mr Podger review the health system and have the outcomes of the Podger review go to the Council of Australian Governments meeting. We were very critical of the Podger review. It was the ultimate black box review—a bureaucrat literally sitting in an office and not seeing anyone, not talking to anyone, not consulting with anyone and not asking anyone with expertise what they thought should be done next. It was the ultimate black box review, but it was the only thing going. And now we understand that even that is off the table, that the Prime Minister has indicated that the Podger review document is now cabinet-in-confidence and will not be made available to the states, and that whilst he is willing to discuss some issues in health reform there will be no system-wide health reform. That failure by the Howard government is going to continue to cost our health system over $1 billion each year in waste. It is not good enough. It is an abandonment of the single biggest thing that needs to be done in health. That is what more than 40 professional health organisations say, as do I. It adds to the Howard government’s track record of failure in the area of health.

name: Brough, Mal, MP
role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
content: —I would like to thank everyone who has taken part in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2002, including the member for Lalor, who did not talk much about it but talked about everything else, and we were kind enough to let her ramble on. This bill gives effect to the budget announcement to increase the Medicare levy and Medicare levy surcharge low-income thresholds in line with increases in the consumer price index.The members opposite, particularly the member for Hunter and the member for Lalor, have indicated that senior Australians would be better off should this House pass the Labor amendments. What they fail to tell the Australian public is that in fact many senior Australians in the financial year 2005-06 and then again in 2006-07 would in fact find themselves with a Medicare bill as a result of Labor policy if Labor went ahead and moved their own amendments as far as the tax cuts are concerned and had them accepted. So in the short term—the next two to three years—far from actually being assisted, many senior Australians would find themselves, as a direct result of Labor Party policy, with a Medicare bill that they would not have if this amendment bill passes. This is not surprising, given that going into the last election the Labor Party proposed tax cuts which would have meant that many people in my electorate actually paid more tax. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be very much aware of that. The Labor Party like to pick winners and they like to pick losers, but unfortunately they get very distressed when members of the public find that they are in fact the losers in failed Labor Party policy.The member for Lalor went on at length about the Medicare safety net. I remind the member for Lalor and those that sit opposite—and, more importantly, the public—that there is only one side of this parliament, and that is the Liberal-National coalition, that actually wants and will have and will continue to provide to the Australian public a Medicare safety net. I suggest to the Labor Party that they have a number of challenges in front of them. One is: what will the Labor Party’s policy be in regard to the safety net at the next election? Will they be endorsing the policy that the public has in fact endorsed? Will the member for Brand, the leader at the moment—
