name: Brough, Mal, MP
content: —I certainly will. This is a tax laws amendment bill and, as such, we are referring to tax laws and therefore we are in fact on message. Let the member for Lalor go on and on about anything and all and sundry, both irrelevant and of course inaccurate, but I will come back to a very serious issue. The Labor Party must confront its own demons. It must decide whether it will go to the next election supporting coalition policy for a Medicare safety net—yes or no; it is a pretty simple proposition—and whether it will maintain the tax thresholds that will pass this place and that we know will pass the other place at some time, whether before or after 1 July. They are the questions to which the public need to know answers. I guarantee you that, whoever is the leader of the Labor Party come the next election, it will not be holding the so-called principled position it is currently taking to the Australian population.This bill ensures that low-income individuals and families are not disadvantaged due to small increases in taxable income. If the thresholds are not increased, low-income individuals and families whose income had only increased in line with the consumer price index would face a Medicare levy liability where they had not in previous years. I remind those opposite, particularly the member for Lalor, that her policy, if it were implemented and the coalition policy were not, would condemn many senior Australians to having a Medicare levy liability. That is an absolute fact. These changes will ensure that these low-income individuals and families will continue to be exempt from paying the Medicare levy or surcharge.From the 2004-05 income year, the Medicare levy low-income threshold will increase to $15,902 for individuals and to $26,834 for families. The additional amount of threshold for each dependent child or student will also be increased, to $2,464. This bill also increases the Medicare levy low-income threshold for pensioners who are below age pension age. The Medicare levy threshold for pensioners below age pension age will be lifted to $19,252. This threshold has been increased each year since 2001-02, when the government substantially increased the pensioner tax offset, which meant that the level of taxable income at which these pensioners started to pay income tax also increased. The increase will ensure that pensioners below age pension age do not face a Medicare levy liability where they do not have an income tax liability.I remind those opposite that they have many challenges in front of them. Is the $600 family tax payment going to be ‘real money’ and will that be endorsed by the Labor Party at the next election? Will the Medicare safety net be policy at the next election? Will the tax cuts that the Labor Party are endorsing today, which do not come into effect until after the next election, be their policy? I am absolutely sure that their current position, like everything else, will change again and again, in the same manner that their leader has. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: N/A

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
content: —The Superannuation Laws Amendment (Abolition of Surcharge) Bill 2005 will abolish the high-income earners tax surcharge on contributions to superannuation and relevant termination payments, with effect from 1 July 2005. The tax was introduced in 1996 in the government’s first budget, at a rate of up to 15 per cent. The tax commences at a surchargeable tax income of $99,710, rising to a maximum amount of $121,075 of income. These income levels are of course indexed.This bill is to abolish the superannuation surcharge, and it is not the government’s first attempt to do so. It is interesting to note that, once upon a time, superannuation in this country was something of a privilege enjoyed only by public servants and high-income earners. It is no secret that it was the former Labor government that changed those circumstances. It was the former Labor government that opened up superannuation to all Australians and Australian families, to all workers whether they were in the public sector or the private sector. For the first time, ordinary workers in this country had access to occupational superannuation, including an employer contribution to superannuation. This not only provided significant assistance to individuals and families; it had a significant impact on Australia’s savings capacity, with knock-on effects to the current account and other key economic indicators. So it is worth beginning my contribution to this debate by reminding the House of that very important point.The Howard government then went to the 1996 election with a very important commitment: it promised no new taxes. It is a matter of history now that we got lots of new taxes after the 1996 election. It was a bit like that promise of ‘no more red tape for small business’. In fact the promise was a 50 per cent reduction in red tape for small business. I can see the member for Watson nodding his head because he is acutely aware of this broken promise.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (ABOLITION OF SURCHARGE) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Burke
content: Mr Burke interjecting—
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (ABOLITION OF SURCHARGE) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
content: —The member for Watson makes the point that they have been pretty good at building it back up to 1996 levels, with a range of new imposts, not least of which is the GST on small business. It is important to note that there was a commitment to no new taxes. But after the election of the Howard government, and in particular its first budget in 1996, it became a much different question. One of the first broken promises on new taxes was related to the superannuation surcharge, and it was on that basis that the Labor Party opposed this surcharge at the time.How ironic it is. Today I checked in the Hansard some of the comments made by government members at the time, in particular by Mr Miles, who was the parliamentary secretary to the cabinet and the Prime Minister at that time. He accused this side of the House of suggesting that someone on $70,000 was a high-income earner, as if we lacked an understanding of the way families in this country are struggling on incomes of around $70,000, $80,000 and $90,000. Of course we have a full understanding of that point. It is interesting to note the defence back in 1996 by government members of this new impost on high-income earners. Then, I think, the surcharge cut in at around $70,000. I made the point at the time that many of the coalminers in my electorate were going to be whacked by that surcharge—and they certainly have been ever since. We made all the points about this being an inefficient, unfair tax—and history has proved that. I think the administrative cost of the tax has been about 50 per cent of what it has raised, and in recent times we have seen an admission from the ATO that it is struggling to collect the surcharge from all individuals concerned.We took a highly principled stand in those days and a correct stand in terms of the efficiency of the surcharge. But what the government are asking us to do now is abolish the surcharge for high-income earners while at the same time they are directing the majority of their income tax cuts in this recent budget to high-income earners. We think that is inherently unfair. If the government want to bring in some sort of superannuation tax package that treats these matters fairly then we would always be happy to support them. But that is not what the government have done in this instance, and on that basis the opposition will not be supporting the abolition of the superannuation surcharge. This is probably a good time for me to move the second reading amendment which has been circulated in my name. Therefore, I move:That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:“the House declines to give the bill a second reading, and condemns the Government for:failing to deliver meaningful overall tax reform to underpin future economic growth;directing through this measure the largest tax benefits to high income earners while failing to deliver meaningful tax relief to those on average incomes; andfailing to reform tax measures consistent with Labor’s fairer tax package”.The really interesting thing in this debate is the basis on which this surcharge was introduced and the basis on which it is being repealed. I refer the House to the Treasurer’s budget speech of 1996 when, under the heading ‘Superannuation’, he said:Superannuation is central to encouraging self-provision for retirement. It is central to coping with an ageing population and is an important vehicle for national saving.I take that as an endorsement of the very good work Labor did throughout the eighties and nineties in creating the very system that he is talking about in that budget speech. He then went on to say:The measures I am announcing tonight are designed to make superannuation fairer.A major deficiency of the current system is that tax benefits for superannuation are overwhelmingly biased in favour of high income earners.That rings a tune we have become familiar with in recent days. He went on to say:For a person on the top tax rate, superannuation is a 33 percentage point tax concession while a person earning $20 000 receives a 5 percentage point tax concession.It seems the Treasurer believes in a progressive system when it suits him, when it applies to income tax cuts, but in 1996 he was in a sense opposing a progressive system. There is a lack of consistency emerging here. He went on to say:High income earners can take added advantage through salary sacrifice arrangements that are not available to lower income earners.The Government is remedying this situation.From tonight, a surcharge of 15 per cent will apply to future employer superannuation contributions for those whose income (including deductible superannuation contributions) is at or above $85 000. The surcharge will phase in over the income range $70 000—I was right earlier—to $85 000. It will apply to defined benefit and unfunded schemes ...And then he went on to some of the more technical detail. So it is quite clear that in 1996 the Treasurer was not seeking additional revenue to pay off government debt, he was seeking to inject more fairness and equity into the superannuation system.Just in case anyone wants to challenge this, let us go to the contribution made in the second reading debate by Mr Miles, the then member for Braddon and parliamentary secretary to the cabinet and the Prime Minister. At 10.47 am he made his contribution and he said:The superannuation system has been inequitably biased in favour of high income earners. Those high income earners have been benefiting from the concessional taxation treatment of superannuation to a much greater extent than low income earners.The introduction of the Superannuation Contributions Surcharge for High Income Earners is this Government’s response to ensure that the superannuation system is more equitable for all Australians, while also ensuring that superannuation remains an attractive savings option.The obvious question is: what has changed? Only one thing has changed and that is the government’s view, in that it is trying now to rewrite history. The Treasurer now tells us, in the context of his speech on this bill, that this was a measure to recover revenue to pay off debt. He says nothing about equity.I was delighted the Treasurer came in here last Thursday to give the second reading. That was something he was not prepared to do in 1996. This is another example of a bill that has been rushed upon the opposition. We understand why that is the case on this occasion. Usually it is because the government has been inept, it is behind in its program, it has had drafting errors and it has had to catch up—and we, on this side, have to wear the pressure of that. But that is not what has happened on this occasion. The Treasurer came in here last Thursday morning with that Cheshire cat smile on his face—looking like the cat that has swallowed the canary—because he thought he had a stitch-up for the Labor Party. So he sent in the parliamentary secretary in 1996 to do the hard grunt, but when he thought there was some political opportunity involved he came in himself, all smiles. Let me share with the House what he said last Thursday:After bringing down 10 budgets and eight surpluses this measure is no longer required to keep the budget in balance.In 1996 the measure was required to introduce equity into the system, but now, in 2005, he says that it was only introduced because the government had to pay off some government debt. What a lot of rubbish. The government has been exposed.The other interesting thing that I was intrigued to learn of today is that Mr Miles’s speech of 13 February 1997 does not appear in the electronic Hansard. I challenge members to go into ParlInfo and find the speech of the then parliamentary secretary and member for Braddon, Mr Miles. It will not be found. So it seems there has been a little bit of airbrushing here. The government is onto the fact that they have been inconsistent with their approach to the superannuation surcharge, so they have tried to airbrush the former member for Braddon’s speech. But what the Treasurer cannot airbrush is his first budget. He has just done his last budget, but in his first budget he claimed that a superannuation surcharge was necessary in this country to make the superannuation system fair and equitable.They have been exposed at a most sensitive time, when they have introduced in this budget $22 billion worth of tax cuts which are weighted heavily in favour of high-income earners: $6 a week for workers on average incomes in 144 electorates around the country and, of course, up to $65 for us who sit in this place. Now they want to add to the tax cut for parliamentarians by extending to them another tax cut through the abolition of the superannuation surcharge.The Treasurer continues to portray this as a savings measure—a means of promoting savings in this country. He has a funny way of going about it. If he were serious about future funds, if he were serious about savings measures in this country, if he were serious about his Intergenerational report and responding to the very real warnings coming out of that report, he would have done something about it in this budget. The future fund does not do that—it is a tax liabilities offset fund. All it means is that people are going to be taxed more heavily today to pay off the debts of the taxpayers of tomorrow. The point has regularly been made in this place that there is no crisis in the unfunded liabilities in superannuation on behalf of the Commonwealth. Indeed, now that the unfunded schemes, the defined schemes, have been closed down, those liabilities are falling.I am pleased to see the member for Paterson enter the House because he is one of those members who are supporting this unfair package of tax concessions that will disadvantage people in his electorate, giving the average worker there just $6 a week, while he votes and gives himself a $65 tax cut. If the Treasurer was so awash with money—largely because, as a result of the minerals boom, we are enjoying the best terms of trade in 50 years—he could have considered returning the dividend to the people in the form of savings rather than consumption tax cuts. That would have made some sense to me. The future fund does nothing in terms of those issues, but an additional investment in savings in this country could have given working families a boost without boosting consumption, with all the implications that that could have for interest rates in this country. Of course, interest rates are a very important part of this debate. As we already know, following the interest rate rise of 25 basis points in March this year the $6 that goes to the average worker in the member for Paterson’s electorate has already been eroded. For someone with a $200,000 mortgage the additional cost will be $8, which more than erodes the $6 tax cut extended to the member for Paterson’s average income earner. So there were much smarter ways of doing it.I am a tradesman and I am proud to be tradesman, proud to have had my hands dirty and to have worked in small business as a tradesman. Unlike many who sit on the other side, I have a very good understanding of trades, of tradesmen and of the struggle of those working in trades, particularly those who are trying to make an income from their trade as a self-employed tradesperson. I can tell you with great certainty that there are not too many self-employed tradesmen in this country earning more than $60,000 a year. That is the reality. In question time today the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, standing at the dispatch box, wanted us to all scream out with great joy because he was giving a toolbox allowance to apprentices in trades. We think that it is a great idea and an appropriate thing to do if that is what the government thinks is the priority, but we do not think that is the priority. We think there are much bigger issues in the area of skills than giving an apprentice a subsidy for a toolbox. We know the Reserve Bank, among others, has made the point that lack of skills training is proving to be one of those big capacity constraints on the Australian economy which is putting more pressure on interest rates. But the point I make is that not too many self-employed tradesmen or, indeed, tradesmen will be amongst those getting the biggest tax cut out of this budget package.

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
content: —I appreciate your intervention, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sure it was genuine, but I draw to your attention to a second reading amendment circulated in my name which goes directly to the tax cuts in the budget, particularly in the context of the package here, which is the extension of those tax cuts through the superannuation break that the Treasurer is attempting to extend to those same workers.Let me go back to the tradesmen. The fact is that under this tax package the average tradesman will get six bucks. That is the reality. Some tradesmen are fortunate, working in some industries like mining: some will get more. During the debate on tax cuts last week I made the point that the average coalminer in my electorate receives about $95,000 annually. At question time we regularly hear the member for North Sydney calling across the chamber: ‘What about your coalminers? You are denying your coalminers a tax cut.’ We are doing no such thing.The Labor Party are not opposing tax cuts. We believe that a government that is awash with money should return a dividend to working Australians. What we are opposed to is the inequitable nature of the tax cuts. We are happy to give relief to the top end of the scale—we think that they deserve it—but we are certainly happy to give relief to the middle-income and lower income parts of the scale. The reality is that a tradesman working in one of my coalmines for $95,000 will be 93c worse off under Labor’s tax package than he would be under the government’s proposed tax package. I know my coalminers pretty well. I do not think that any of them would complain about giving up 93c on a weekly basis to help one of their mates that they drink with at the Australia Hotel in Cessnock, for example, on a Saturday afternoon—a $12 tax cut rather than a $6 tax cut. I do not know of any of my coalminers who would begrudge giving up 93c.

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
content: —It is like the Treasurer. Around 6.30 pm last Wednesday he graced the chamber with his presence to debate Labor’s amendments to his tax package. You would think that, after 10 years as Treasurer and having had our detailed amendments for seven hours and 45 minutes, he would have had some criticism of our tax package. He might have dissected it, ripped it apart, found the faults and presented them to the chamber. Guess what? He did no such thing. Instead, he came in here and heaped scorn on the opposition for denying people tax cuts. I wonder why he shared with the House not one criticism of Labor’s tax alternative. I have a pretty strong theory on that: he could not find any problems with Labor’s tax package. He could not find any fault with Labor’s low-income and welfare to work tax offset. He could not find any fault with the way in which we changed the thresholds throughout the scales, because they are fair and they are without technical fault. He did not have an argument to put up. For three weeks we have been making the $6, $12 and $65 point: the consequences of the government’s tax package. Not once during question time or during any debate in this place has the Treasurer challenged those figures—not once.We know why that is. Firstly, he cannot; secondly, he knows we are right; and, thirdly, he knows it is true: that is the impact on average income earners in the 144 electorates in this country. He knows that is the case and he knows that Labor’s package is fairer. But we know also that he was not worried about that. He had done the deal with the Prime Minister and they had come to the conclusion that it was time to give their natural constituency a break, and the best time to do that is during the first year of a new parliamentary term. That is what this tax package is about. That is what this surcharge cut is about.I go back to where I began: Labor recognise that there are problems with the superannuation surcharge. We acknowledge that it is hardly the most efficient tax ever imposed by any government, let alone by this government. We are happy to consider fair tax cut proposals, whether they be in direct tax cuts or in terms of a superannuation reform package. But this is no reform package. There is no reform in it at all. If this were a reform package it would be doing something at the lower end to again increase the savings capacity of ordinary Australian workers. The government said that the surcharge is about equality. It was originally about retiring debt, but that is now no longer necessary. The fact is that this surcharge reduction is about one thing and one thing only: taking care of the Prime Minister’s and the Treasurer’s natural constituency. On that basis they stand condemned and on that basis we will be opposing this measure.

name: Fawcett, David, MP
content: —I rise to support the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Abolition of Surcharge) Bill 2005. I am fascinated to see that yet again members opposite are going to try to put a roadblock in the way of hardworking Australians getting adequate reward for their labours. I am fascinated also to see that they say that their package stands on such good merit that the government should be responding to it, when in the press releases that they send out the figures do not stack up—they cannot even compare apples with apples. They launch scurrilous personal attacks on people and compare two levels of income—one being the average electorate income for each member—and then they compare the figures that they contest that their tax package would deliver to voters.The figures looked impressive upon my first reading. I thought, ‘How could this be?’ In the fine print at the bottom of the page, where they hoped that nobody would find it, was the fact that their figures were based not on $37,500, which they contended when they looked at the coalition’s tax package, but on $85,000. If their package is so good, why do they need to obscure the facts and use different figures to compare apples with oranges to try to sell their package? In their own words, they are undone.In 2004 the superannuation industry lobby group, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia, and the Australian Consumers Association argued that one way to encourage people to put more away towards their retirement nest egg is to reduce tax. The Chief Executive of ASFA, Philippa Smith, said:... the Government needs to be a partner in the savings effort for middle Australia ... Bolder steps and initiatives are still needed to fill the looming savings gap.The Howard government has taken significant steps with measures detailed in this year’s budget. These measures, which include not only the abolition of the superannuation surcharge but also tax cuts for all Australians, have been supported by a broad range of groups, including many of the state Labor premiers. In fact, there is only one significant obstacle to every Australian receiving a tax cut on 1 July this year, and that is the members opposite.With respect to the abolition of the superannuation surcharge, interestingly, some of the criticism from the member for Hunter related to the fact that it was this government that introduced the measure in 1996. ‘Why,’ the opposition argue, ‘does it now want to remove it?’ ‘Doesn’t it show,’ they argue, ‘that this was an unwise measure in the first place?’ There appears to be in some quarters an unrealistic expectation that circumstances never change, that priorities never change and that plans should be perfect and able to be followed without alteration, happily into the future. In my life experience, military analysts are often quoted as saying that battle plans are perfect until the first shot is fired, then victory relies on combat commanders who can adapt to changing conditions. So let us take a little time to look at the contexts of 1996 and 2005.In 1996 the new Howard government faced, among other things, the daunting task of dealing with the $96 billion debt left by the Labor government—a debt that was costing the Australian taxpayer over $5 billion a year. The introduction of the surcharge was one of a number of measures introduced in part to contribute to the long task of paying down Labor debt. It is worth noting at this point that not only has the good economic management of the Howard government paid down this debt by $90 billion but it has boosted spending on health, education and defence, amongst other portfolios, to record levels. So, while the surcharge was not introduced for debt reduction alone, the fact that this debt no longer exists is one more factor allowing the government to now move to abolish the surcharge entirely.With the immediate concern of debt reduction largely dealt with, there are two other areas of longer term concern that this government continues to respond to through a range of measures, including the subject of this bill. One is the ageing of Australia’s population. The other is the shortage of labour and, associated with that, the shortage of a skilled work force. Australia faces an ageing of its population over the next four decades. Twenty-five per cent of Australians will be aged over 65 by 2044-45, which is about twice the present percentage. As I speak with community groups and individuals throughout Wakefield, a common question I am asked pertains to how Australia will afford to look after its elderly into the future. Population ageing of itself should not be seen as the problem, but it will have economic and fiscal impacts that will create significant policy challenges. People over 55 have lower work force participation rates than younger people, and as more people move into older age groups participation rates are expected to drop even further.The Intergenerational report, commissioned by this government, indicates that taxation revenue is expected to follow GDP growth but that government expenditure is likely to rise rapidly, placing budgets under considerable pressure. Education and some welfare payments are projected to increase more slowly than GDP, while government spending on health, aged care and pensions will grow at a faster rate. If the government does nothing, the aggregate fiscal gap will be around 6.4 percentage points of GDP by 2044-45, with an estimated value over the 40 years of around $2,200 billion in 2002-03 dollars. A range of policy measures will be needed to reduce the fiscal pressure from ageing. Measures to raise productivity and participation would enhance income growth and the capacity to pay for the costs of ageing, including through taxation. Measures to encourage savings for retirement will also lesson the burden on the taxpayer into the future. Population ageing can only be conceived of as a crisis if we let it become one.The Howard government response has been broad and consistent in its direction. Over the past few years the government has implemented a number of important measures aimed at improving the superannuation and retirement income arrangements for all Australians. These changes have assisted Australians to build financial self-reliance for their retirement. Initiatives in 2001 increased the attractiveness and accessibility of superannuation. These measures included the introduction of the co-contribution scheme for eligible low-income earners who make voluntary superannuation contributions, and reductions in superannuation surcharge rates. The policy paper entitled ‘A more flexible and adaptable retirement income system’, released in February 2004, outlined further measures to improve the accessibility, flexibility and integrity of the retirement income system and to reduce red tape. This included the removal of work tests for individuals under the age of 65 who wanted to contribute to superannuation.The 2004-05 budget contained incentives to save for retirement worth $2.8 billion over four years and included an expansion of the co-contribution scheme and further reductions in the superannuation surcharge rates. The government has passed legislation to deliver choice of fund and has reconfirmed its commitment to the superannuation contribution splitting policy. In the 2002-03 and 2004-05 budgets the government announced reductions in the superannuation surcharge. Unfortunately, those reductions were opposed in the Senate and the government was only able to secure through the Senate a reduction to 13.5 per cent in 2004-05. The government now proposes, through this bill, to remove this impost on superannuation savings and abolish the surcharge payable on individual surchargeable contributions and relevant termination payments, with effect from 1 July this year. The measure presented in this bill will provide incentives for individuals to make additional voluntary savings through the superannuation system, as well as simplifying the operation of the system.The other area that government is addressing is the issue of work force shortages. These shortages have resulted from strong growth in the economy which has caused a growing demand for labour, both skilled and unskilled. This is true across all the sectors that I speak with in Wakefield. I see signs on power poles in Playford and Salisbury, for example, advertising vacancies right now for unskilled workers to commence work in the poultry sector. Growers in Virginia talk about their inability to obtain unskilled workers to work in their packing sheds. Businesses expanding in the viticulture sector tell me that their No. 1 risk is the inability to secure both skilled and unskilled workers.Employers I have spoken to indicate that they see a number of ways to increase work force availability but that there needs to be more incentive for workers to take up these opportunities. More work is available for many who wish to do overtime, but many workers do not have the incentive to do this, lest they be pushed into the top tax bracket. As stated earlier, there is only one group that is standing in the way of a solution to this. Unless the Labor Party decides to stop blocking the lifting of tax thresholds proposed by this government, not only will these workers and their families miss out but over 800,000 businesses in Australia will be forced to wear the higher costs associated with implementing multiple withholding schedules. Yet again, Labor is showing that it is no friend of small business. Like the changes to the tax thresholds, removing the superannuation surcharge provides another incentive for workers to undertake overtime without the risk of being pushed into another bracket, where additional work does not correspond with appropriate levels of additional reward.The opportunities to upskill are there for many workers, some funded by industry and some funded by the government. But there must be incentive to train. A large part of that is having the confidence that there will be an appropriate increase in reward for the effort put in to obtain the qualifications and for the effort and time spent fulfilling new responsibilities. This government—those on this side of the House—still believes in reward for effort and decries the politics of envy that would seek to cut down the tall poppies that seek to better themselves and their families. Again, the recent tax cuts and this bill are part of the response to this concern. I call on the Labor Party to get out of the way of the tax cuts and the superannuation surcharge relief that the people of Wakefield deserve.People have spoken to me about our tertiary qualified work force, the engineers needed by industry in Edinburgh Parks and Elizabeth West and the medical practitioners needed to support individuals and families in centres in Wakefield such as Riverton, Munno Para, Clare, Salisbury and Gawler. I have been asked many times why so many who train in Australia are no longer working in Australia. The thousands of professionally qualified Australians working overseas are sometimes known as the Australian diaspora. They are there for a variety of reasons, including family, professional development and even life experience. But a recent study by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry shows that the Australian government should focus on opportunities presented by this diverse and talented group whilst also tackling some of the domestic reasons that push them to live and work overseas—things such as our high personal income tax levels and workplace relations over-regulation. The ACCI study found that Australian expatriates tend on average to be highly educated and well skilled. They have strong engagement with the labour market where they are overseas and they are more likely to be employed on a full-time basis in their host country.In a 2002 study of Australian emigration patterns, demographic researchers found that almost 42 per cent of Australian expatriates surveyed held a postgraduate degree compared with around seven per cent of the resident Australian population, with almost 89 per cent employed as professionals and on a full-time basis. According to one of these Hong Kong based expatriates:The solution to the diaspora and retaining talent at home is to drastically reduce the tax rate to return incentives for working, saving and investing in Australia.

name: Fawcett, David, MP
content: —In conclusion, this government has moved to provide incentives for Australians to choose to learn, earn and stay in Australia and save for their life plans and retirement. The measures presented in this bill will provide incentives for individuals to make voluntary contributions to their superannuation and will simplify the administration of the superannuation system. name: Crean, Simon, MP
content: —I rise to support the second reading amendment to the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Abolition of Surcharge) Bill 2005, moved by the member for Hunter. I do so because it is important that, in the interests of fairness in this country, as we debate this particular bill we put forward what should be the obvious alternative to the course the government has chosen.On the specifics of the bill itself, it is true that Labor opposed the introduction of the superannuation surcharge when it was introduced in 1996. It did this for two reasons. Firstly, it was a broken promise. The government said that it would not introduce any new taxes and charges. It called this a surcharge and tried to pretend it was not a tax. Secondly, in introducing it, no other offsetting savings were introduced at the time to encourage or build upon the great legacy that Labor left this government in the establishment of a national superannuation system for the nation—a compulsory superannuation scheme. We are now opposing the abolition of the surcharge because, on top of the massive tax cuts for the wealthy that were introduced in the budget, this is an unfair measure. In terms of superannuation reform, it is not the appropriate starting point. The truth is that there are far more important tax related issues, including those associated with the tax on superannuation contributions, that need to be addressed.To give some perspective on the unfairness associated with this, just consider this situation: on top of the $65 a week tax cut for an employee on $125,000 a year, this measure represents an additional $27 a week tax cut when nine per cent superannuation contributions are made and $45 a week when 15 per cent superannuation contributions are made. If there is a common thread that has held this government together over the past nine years, it is the continual smash and grab from so many to give to so few. That common thread of greed and unfairness is the very essence of this government. Just recall that, in the 13 years that Labor was in office, we made seven tax cuts. Practically all of them benefitted ordinary wage earners. Some of the amendments benefitted high-income earners as well. We, after all, were the ones that reduced the top marginal tax rate that the Howard-Fraser government left—that of 60c in the dollar—to 47c.Unlike we who took the view that tax reform had to impact on everyone, that is not what this government has embarked upon. Tax reform introduced by this government was the mother of all taxes: the GST. For that, some people got compensation, which was eaten up in less than 12 months. You cannot really count that tax reform. In addition, over the last three years there have been three tax cuts, but the benefit for ordinary wage and salary earners from that has effectively been $10 over three years. There was the $4.40 milkshake and sandwich tax cut, nothing last year if you earnt under $52,000, and only $6 this year, while people who sit on the opposite side—members of parliament—get 10 times that amount. That is the unfairness that is embodied again in the nature of this proposal.I want to focus on a number of key issues that arise from this bill. The first is this. Labor have always been the party for the pensioner. We are now the party for the superannuant, because the biggest advances in superannuation in Australia have only ever occurred under a Labor government. Despite all of the opposition from the coalition between 1983 and 1996, Labor, through the accord, initiated, designed and implemented a true national savings scheme for this country—the most significant intergenerational policy ever implemented in this nation. But in the last nine years there has been no policy initiative by the government to advance the adequacy of superannuation. John Howard and his government have fought workers every inch of the way when it has come to superannuation.The abolition of the superannuation surcharge on top of tax cuts for high-income earners is the wrong priority at the moment. This is a surcharge that should be abolished—a tax that should be abolished. It never should have been introduced in the first place. But there are more pressing priorities before we do that—priorities which left unattended will not only add to the unfairness in this nation, which I have just outlined, but lead to a situation in which we are not investing in the drivers of economic growth and in which we are putting upward pressure on interest rates. So we are suggesting, and the second reading amendment does this, that the government should utilise the revenue generated from the superannuation surcharge to recast their tax cuts along the lines of those put forward by Labor. If they want to cut superannuation taxes, why not cut the contributions tax for everyone, thereby benefiting all workers, not just the top five per cent of workers? This was what Labor proposed in the lead-up to the last election.It is a historic fact that superannuation entitlements for all working people in this country came about because Labor governments recognised the need to address the long-term decline in our national savings as well as the need to provide financial security and peace of mind for people in their retirement. In 1983 what we inherited from the Howard-Fraser government was only 40 per cent of the work force in superannuation. Today, because of Labor’s reforms, and Labor’s reforms alone, that figure is 92 per cent—the vast majority of the work force. Savings, like investment, is the key to long-run economic growth, particularly as it relates to technological change and innovation. During the 1980s and 1990s, Labor responded to the need for greater national savings by introducing a world-class compulsory superannuation system—a system designed to secure a better retirement future for ageing Australians while reducing the intergenerational burden of government funded pensions. That is the very question that the member for Wakefield posed not five minutes ago. But he is not even here to hear the answer, so interested is he in learning the answers to his own questions. I interjected at the time. I am now doing it in accordance with parliamentary procedures, but he ain’t here to hear it. What sort of staying power do these people have?The impact of our changes for the future are that superannuation funds now amount to some $693 billion and they have given more than seven million workers greater security in retirement. You see, Labor did not just address the question of income adequacy whilst in work; we have also been prepared to address the question of income adequacy and economic dignity in retirement. The Prime Minister rabbits on about the so-called cuts to real wages. They did occur between 1983 and 1990, not between 1990 and 1996. The government conveniently ignore those figures when they run on about their real wages growth. Labor started the path to real wages growth with the economic legacy that we left this country. The government have just ridden the wave of it. In addition to that, the price—if you like, the benefit—of some of those real wage cuts was that we introduced superannuation for everyone: nine per cent compulsory superannuation. That is something that the Prime Minister not only never refers to but fought every inch of the way.The Howard government have never understood the concept of superannuation and, at every step, every opportunity, they have taken us backwards. I remind the House about what the Prime Minister, John Howard, said in 1991: ‘Even in better economic conditions, legislated superannuation imposts are wrong in principle.’ He does not believe in the great intergenerational policy change that Labor implemented for this country. I say to the government: if they do not believe in it, let them get out of the way; let them give Labor the opportunity to implement again the very mechanism that is going to provide the basis for economic dignity in this country.By 1996, the revolution in superannuation was so successful that John Howard went to the 1996 elections promising not to interfere with it and promising to implement the co-contribution. But he did touch it. He abolished it in the very first budget. Labor should have known and should have legislated that co-contribution so the Howard government could not get their grubby little hands on it, because what did they do? They converted the savings into a savings strategy that lasted all of six weeks. They abolished it within six weeks and that money in turn went to fund the private health insurance rebate. They shifted from savings to health. They shifted from a scheme that benefited all workers to one for only those who could afford private health insurance.As I have said many times, budgets are about choices. This government are making the wrong choices in terms of the future of this country. The first opportunity they had they abandoned that contribution which by now, if they had honoured it or if Labor had legislated to introduce it instead of relying on the Prime Minister’s word that he would keep it, would have seen compulsory superannuation not at nine per cent where it is but at 15 per cent. If that policy had been continued it would have delivered an additional $9 billion a year into the superannuation system.What does that mean? Back in 1995 for a person in their thirties on average weekly earnings that meant an extra return in real terms of $100,000. In the context of an accumulation account that is massive. That is what Labor’s policy would have done. Obviously it would be a lot more today and more again for young workers. That is the answer to the member for Wakefield’s question. That answers the question of how you lift adequacy. It is what decent policy does. We had bipartisanship on it but it only lasted as long as it took Howard to get elected. He then scrapped the promise. I make the point again: what sort of a friend of the workers is John Howard really? He comes into this place and says that he is the friend of the workers but he has fought them every inch of the way.

name: Crean, Simon, MP
content: —Budgets are about choices—I have made that point. Do not let us have any of this nonsense by the Prime Minister that he has got the interests of working people at heart. If he had their interests at heart he would have continued the plan that Labor had in place and not be undermining those conditions. Not only has he undermined our superannuation system, the Prime Minister is now gearing up for a full frontal assault with his industrial relations reform.The Treasurer’s big contribution to savings in this country was that savings rebate that I talked about before. It lasted all of six weeks and then ended up funding private health insurance. The government constantly undermine superannuation with ham-fisted, ad hoc measures that threaten our premier savings vehicle. In addition to abandoning the co-contribution they introduced this tax, which they now want to abolish, and they introduced a notion, a half-baked idea, to allow low-income earners to opt out of the superannuation guarantee. It is a pale imitation of Labor’s original co-contribution scheme—a voluntary, low-income earners co-contribution. Voluntary? How can people on such low incomes afford that contribution? Rather than benefiting low-income earners, anecdotal evidence shows that it is overwhelmingly benefiting wealthier taxpayers who are allocating superannuation funds for a low-income partner or offspring. The circumstances were that government even had to change the definition of the policy to allow this, because the uptake of the original proposal was so pathetic. The government’s direction is clear: they do not support the concept of compulsory superannuation. They cannot therefore be said to be supporters of the national savings of the country. The Howard government have never understood the importance of building on the vision they inherited. Rather than shape it to their own form, they have been intent on dismantling it.The government have also failed to provide Australia with a comprehensive retirement incomes policy. They have made the superannuation system more costly and complicated, ultimately contributing to the public’s current lack of faith in it. More importantly, this lack of commitment and policy has meant that this government has not continued to address the issue of the ageing population. I remember, because I was shadow treasurer at the time, that the Treasurer was asked, after his 2000 budget, what the next big issue on the agenda was. He said with that stupid smirk, ‘Ah, it starts with an “s”.’ When he was asked to elaborate, according to journalist Paul Cleary in the Australian Financial Review of Saturday 29 July, Mr Costello suggested perhaps ‘another Treasurer might undertake these reforms’. In other words he could not even say the word and he said that a future Treasurer would have to be the one that did something serious about superannuation.He is dead right. The only way we will get advances in superannuation in this country again is under a Labor government. Certainly his next agenda in this field started with ‘s’—it is silence. We have heard nothing from him about advancing superannuation in this country. Labor did introduce a strong national savings scheme and we will ensure that it continues despite all the efforts of the government to distort the benefits towards the wealthy at the expense of those in genuine need.We are alarmed at the administrative burden that the government’s obsession with choice of fund will impose. My colleague the member for Watson will be addressing this in relation to further legislation, and I will leave that to him. For 900,000 employers this system that they have introduced will mean a massive new compliance burden requiring some 34 complex steps. So much for cutting red tape, the other great broken promise of this government! They have swamped small business with it, as they did with the GST.The great irony is this: the government talks about choice of super funds but it will not, under its new industrial relations legislation, allow workers the choice of negotiating superannuation and including it in the awards. They are going to remove it as one of the allowable matters—what hypocrisy! They talk choice as if it is a great Australian virtue but, in the great revolution in this country on retirement incomes, not only have they done nothing about it, they have also denied workers the right to negotiate it and include it in their awards. What nonsense, what backwardness—what sort of a vision is this? This is steeped in the Prime Minister’s obsession with the past—an obsession which aims to ensure that trade unions do not develop superannuation and an obsession that says the funds themselves should then be dismantled. That is what they are about—they have done nothing to back it.I make the point that this was a budget of lost opportunities in many ways. But this particular measure, as part of a comprehensive approach to superannuation, retirement incomes and adequacy would have great merit in this country. We would support it in that context, because we never introduced this tax. But what we are saying is that it is not the appropriate vehicle for reform at the moment because too much remains to be done in terms of lifting adequacy. That path was started by a Labor government, it will only be continued by a future Labor government, and the sooner we get the opportunity to do it the better off Australians will be in their retirement. (Time expired)
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (ABOLITION OF SURCHARGE) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Washer, Dr Mal, MP
content: —The Superannuation Laws Amendment (Abolition of Surcharge) Bill 2005 abolishes the surcharge payable on individuals’ surchargeable contributions and relevant termination payments, effective from 1 July 2005. The surcharge applied when an individual’s assessable income and superannuation contribution exceeded $70,000. The surcharge was imposed at the rate of one per cent for each $1,000 of assessable income and superannuation contributions, to a maximum of 15 per cent when assessable income for surcharge purposes reached $85,000 per annum. These income thresholds have been indexed since that time and now stand at $99,710 and $121,075 respectively. Income for surcharge purposes includes not only superannuation contributions but also salary and wages, fringe benefits and superannuation lump sums paid to individuals.The superannuation surcharge has been unpopular for many reasons. It is complex and costly to administer and collect. Its collection costs are carried by all fund members, most of whom do not have a surcharge deducted from their contributions. It applies to low-income earners if the value of their superannuation lump sum payment on retirement means that their annual income for surcharge purposes in the income year in which they received the lump sum payment is above the surcharge thresholds. It is especially difficult to determine the amount of surcharge paid by defined benefit fund members, because the value of their deductible contribution—that is, their employer’s notional contribution—is difficult to calculate. While the surcharge applying to accumulation fund members is paid in the year after the liability occurred, defined benefit fund members pay any surcharge liability out of the benefits paid, via either pension or lump sum, when they finally retire.This bill will mean approximately 640,000 taxpayers will no longer be subject to surcharges on contributions and termination payments made or received from 1 July 2005. Many of these 640,000 spent the majority of their working lives in the decades before the implementation of compulsory superannuation payments. These individuals need as much incentive as possible to make additional voluntary savings through the superannuation system.Superannuation is a long-term savings system designed to provide income in retirement. It first commenced in Australia around 1850. These early funds were mostly established by banks and large private companies, such as insurance companies and financial institutions. Some public sector superannuation funds were established, such as the Police Superannuation and Reward Fund in 1862. At that stage, superannuation was regarded as a managerial gratuity because members were predominately managers and white-collar workers. Most employees had to rely on their personal savings to fund their retirement. If there were no personal savings, they had to satisfy the strict qualifying tests for age pensions provided by some state governments in the 1890s and the Commonwealth government from 1909.Selective vesting rules in Australia were common at this time and restricted superannuation benefits to a select few. Early vesting did not catch on in Australia, unlike in the United States and the United Kingdom, where enhanced retirement benefits were used to quell industrial unrest. For the first 130 years, there was little change in the way the superannuation system operated. In the 1950s, superannuation spread to more of the work force, although it was still mainly for permanent, generally male, staff and was seen more as a reward for long and dedicated service. Private sector employers started to set up their own company administered funds or paid contributions into a life office administered fund. During the 1960s, superannuation became more popular when the tax treatment of contributions to funds became more generous for the self-employed. However large sectors of the work force still did not receive superannuation.In 1974, only 32 per cent of employees were covered by superannuation. During the 1970s, combination funds—now referred to as hybrid funds—emerged. These plans had a dual benefit structure, with the employers’ benefits placed in the defined benefit section and the employees contributions plus investment earnings in the defined contribution section. This way, the advantages of both fund designs could be obtained. During the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s a series of government inquiries into the superannuation sector set the scene for superannuation in Australia to change.In 1986 there was a major change, with the inclusion of compulsory super in industrial awards. A three per cent wage productivity increase was put through superannuation rather than a direct wage increase. Guidelines were also introduced requiring that contributions were fully vested in the member and preserved in a super fund until retirement. This encouraged the growth of defined contribution funds and immediate vesting of benefits. In 1983 the total value of assets invested by Australian superannuation funds was $32 billion. In 1991 the total had increased to $135 billion.With an increasingly large ageing population that would need to be supported in retirement, award super would not have grown fast enough in terms of contribution levels and coverage. Therefore, in 1992 compulsory super for all employees was introduced, with the objective of improving total retirement income in a way that taxpayers could afford. Prior to this time, Australia was one of the very few developed nations that did not have a national employment related retirement income plan. A non-tax deductible levy was imposed on employers who did not abide by the superannuation contribution rates for employees. The superannuation guarantee charge commenced on 1 July 1992, starting at three per cent of employee earnings and progressively increasing to nine per cent by 2002. That resulted in 92 per cent of the Australian work force being covered by superannuation. In 1996 the superannuation surcharge was introduced to help correct the deep $10.3 billion deficit left by the Labor government.The superannuation system then became more attractive in 2001 with the policy statement A Better Superannuation System. This enhanced the system by the introduction of the co-contribution scheme for eligible low-income earners who made voluntary superannuation contributions. In the 2002-03 budget, the government announced that the superannuation surcharge would be reduced at the rate of 1½ per cent per annum so that it would be reduced to 10½ per cent by the 2004-05 financial year. However, this proposal was blocked by the Senate and the government was only able to secure a reduction to 13½ per cent in 2004-05.Not to be deterred, the government then announced in the 2004-05 budget reductions to the surcharge at the rate of 2½ per cent per annum to 12½ per cent in 2004-05, reducing to 7½ per cent in the 2006-07 financial year. Once again, opposition from the Labor Party in the Senate blocked this proposal. In February 2004 the policy paper A more flexible and adaptable retirement income system was released. This contained further measures to improve the flexibility, accessibility and integrity of the system and also to reduce red tape. It included the removal of work tests for individuals under the age of 65 who wanted to contribute to superannuation.That history of superannuation changes brings us to today. After 10 budgets and eight surpluses the superannuation surcharge is no longer necessary to keep the budget in balance. As you are all probably aware, the projections are for a doubling of the population over 65 to around 25 per cent of the total population over the next 40 years. It is far better to enable people to contribute to their health and retirement costs. Therefore, we need to provide as much incentive as possible for people to contribute additional voluntary savings into the superannuation system.There is disparity between men and women in both the incidence of having superannuation and the average balance of accounts. There is not much difference between men and women up to the age of 25. But, by around age 60, there is a 15 percentage point difference between men and women in the incidence of having superannuation, and the balance of women’s super at the time of retirement is around half that of men.There are a couple of factors at work. Younger women have the benefit of compulsory superannuation contributions for most of their working life, while older women have had access to employment-linked superannuation contributions for only part of their working life. Superannuation outcomes for many older women will have been affected by time out of the labour force, in order to raise children or to undertake other family responsibilities.Women aged over 55 who have returned to relatively well paid jobs in the labour force have a lot of catching up to do. Even though more men than women pay the superannuation surcharge, it is of particular disadvantage for women aged over 55. At this stage, many women are earning reasonable salaries, have their children off their hands and can afford to top up their contributions.Over the history of changes, this government has been committed to assisting Australians in building finances for their retirement. This bill not only provides further incentives for individuals to make additional voluntary savings through the system but also simplifies the operation of the superannuation system. The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has calculated that the abolition of the superannuation surcharge will benefit over one million Australians. I commend this bill to the House.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (ABOLITION OF SURCHARGE) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
content: —Who said, ‘Truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life?’ Who said, ‘A coalition government will provide in full the funds earmarked in the 1995-96 budget to match compulsory employee contributions according to the proposed schedule’? The answer in both cases is John Howard. It is a matter of record that one of the first acts of the incoming coalition government was to, in fact, renege on that ironclad commitment that the Prime Minister had made and, in doing so, to commit one of the greatest acts of vandalism in Australia’s economic and social history.A superannuation system had already been legislated and funded, whereby nine per cent was to be obtained from employers over a period, another three per cent from employees and a co-contribution of three per cent from the Commonwealth of Australia. That totals 15 per cent, and if those measures that had been legislated by the previous Labor government had not been wiped out—abolished—then Australians by now would be enjoying superannuation contributions of 15 per cent: nine per cent from employers, three per cent from employees and three per cent from the Commonwealth.But the government abolished that plan, Labor’s plan to get compulsory superannuation up to 15 per cent, and now we are debating another measure that the government introduced around the time. We are debating now the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge that was introduced in 1997 because the government said it needed to be more equitable in the range of spending cuts it was implementing and it therefore wanted to take some pain from higher income earners.At that time, Labor said it opposed the introduction of that surcharge for one clear reason, and that was that the government, in another commitment pre 1996, had said—this is again the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, as opposition leader—that there would be no new taxes and no increases in taxes in the first term of a Howard government. The introduction of the superannuation tax surcharge violated that pre-election commitment, and the Australian Labor Party held the government to account on that by opposing the introduction of the superannuation tax surcharge.The measure before us—that is, the abolition of the surcharge—involves in the order of $2.5 billion. In the circumstances confronting Australia in 2005 and in the context of the income tax cuts that the government introduced in the 2005-06 budget, Labor does not consider the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge to be a fair measure. The reason for our opposition is that, if you combine the income tax cuts for those on incomes above, say, $100,000 with the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge, the outcome could be tax cuts not of $65 a week—which we have quoted as being the value of the tax cuts alone—but tax cuts of anywhere up to $110 a week. Labor does not consider that to be a fair proposal at a time when higher income earners would be getting this double benefit of a personal income tax cut of $65 a week and the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge and low- and middle-income earners are to be content with a $6 a week sandwich and milkshake tax cut. That is why Labor opposes these measures, including the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge. Labor has a different view of fairness in this country.As I was sitting here listening to the Treasurer deliver the budget, I noticed that when he announced the tax cuts at the high-income end, every coalition member understood precisely what that meant for them—that is, a very substantial tax cut of $65 a week. The cheers got even louder when the Treasurer announced that he would be abolishing the superannuation tax surcharge, because that meant more money in the pockets of members of parliaments—paid for, I must say, by the operation of bracket creep on low- and middle-income earners. Earlier today I pointed out that a range of occupations, including receptionists, hairdressers, sales assistants and farm hands—in the context of a very bad drought—would be getting tax cuts in the order of only $6 a week. They got no cuts at all last year because the tax cuts were restricted to those earning more than $1,000 a week and they got a $4 a week sandwich and milkshake tax cut in 2003. One then has to go back to the year 2000 to find the earlier tax cut, which was in fact a partial compensation for the introduction of a $36 billion goods and services tax.The history of tax cuts under this government for the forgotten people is a very sorry one, and is compounded by the most recent budget. The effect of the government being unwilling to provide any significant tax cut for low- and middle-income earners is that bracket creep will be taking more from them than the tax cut gives to them. Not for one day or $1 will the forgotten people be ahead, not even in the coming financial year. Bracket creep for them, according to the budget forecasts and their earnings as revealed in the Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys, is such that the $6 a week tax cut is smaller. So they do not get a genuine tax cut not for one day or for $1. So, on equity grounds, we consider the proposal before the parliament to be unsatisfactory, and that is why we are opposing it.I will move now to the more fundamental question of superannuation in this country. Why is it that the coalition has such difficulty in supporting superannuation for the working men and women of this country? Prior to the Hawke and Keating Labor governments and the introduction of compulsory superannuation in the mid-1980s, superannuation was the preserve of the privileged. But, in a farsighted set of policy decisions, the Hawke and Keating governments introduced compulsory superannuation for working people through the award and, through that, the development of industry funds.Those industry funds, interestingly, have performed very well. They have low fees and charges and, over time, they have proven to have performed very well for the working people of this country in the investment returns that they have been able to achieve. But, for purely ideological reasons—because these are industry funds and trade unions are associated with them—the government has felt very hostile towards them. This hostility goes right back to the mid-1980s when the coalition opposed root and branch Labor’s attempts to introduce superannuation measures. It opposed those measures in the House of Representatives and the Senate, but fortunately we were able to get those changes through. The consequence of those dramatic reforms has been that superannuation funds now have assets of well in excess of $600 billion.Back in the early 1980s, one of our greatest problems was national savings. Labor in government created a massive national savings pool of, as I say, more than $600 billion now. And here we are back to a situation where national savings rates in Australia are very poor yet again. One of the reasons for that is that this government has favoured consumption over savings and has not supported compulsory superannuation in Australia. That has meant that the savings rates are very low. It would be terrific if the government were more serious about supporting superannuation in Australia.In 2002 the Treasurer introduced into parliament through the budget processes the Intergenerational report. It was a valuable document because it drew the attention of policy makers and the Australian people to the economic challenges of having an ageing population. The Intergenerational report and subsequent work by the Productivity Commission project that in the decade from the year 2020 our growth rate per person will be half that of the early 2000s. That is a consequence of two insidious forces operating in Australia. One is the ageing of the population, and on this matter I do agree with the Treasurer when he says that demography is destiny. There is not a lot we can do about the ageing of the population because the die is cast.The other force is faltering productivity growth. Through far-sighted economic reform measures implemented by the Hawke and Keating governments, Australia was able to achieve a sustained period of strong productivity growth that provided the foundation for very large improvements in prosperity in this country. You would think the Howard government, upon coming to office, instead of coasting on that productivity growth, would continue a reform program, including a superannuation program, to ensure that there were adequate national savings and, more generally, to ensure that productivity growth was able to be maintained at very high levels, because we know that today’s productivity growth is tomorrow’s prosperity.But instead of doing that this reform-lazy government, in a most vandalistic fashion, reneged on a commitment that the Prime Minister had given before the 1996 election to ‘provide in full the funds earmarked in the 1995-96 budget to match compulsory employee contributions according to the schedule’ that had been set out in the previous budget. So the signs were very bad for Australia when this government came to office, because one of the greatest reforms that Australia could have—that is, the spreading of superannuation through the Australian work force and the generation of a massive pool of national savings—was being undermined by one of the first decisions of the incoming coalition government.Fast forward now to 2005, and here we have the legacy of a reform-lazy government where our national savings effort is nowhere near up to scratch. One consequence of that, of course, is increasing current account deficits, and even today figures have been released showing that the current account deficit is 7.25 per cent of GDP. In 1986, when Paul Keating warned of the dangers of Australia becoming a banana republic, the current account deficit was a much smaller share of GDP. This government seems completely unconcerned about having a current account deficit 7¼ per cent of GDP. It says that salvation is just around the corner—‘Don’t you worry about that!’ in the immortal words of the late Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. It says that we are going to be rescued by high mineral prices. It has really been saying that since around the year 2000. The budget forecasts for export volumes have consistently been underachieved by very large amounts. We had government ministers in the parliament today saying, ‘Look, things were set to improve but we have this terrible drought now, so things may not improve on the current account to the extent that we would have hoped.’So we are now saddled with the problem of inadequate national savings and of large current account deficits, and those current account deficits are consistently feeding into record foreign debt. Back in 1995 Mr Costello and Mr Howard, who were then in opposition, said when they launched their debt truck that they would follow policies to bring down the foreign debt. Bring down the foreign debt? At that time it was $180 billion and now it is $425 billion. Far from bringing down the foreign debt, this government has presided over a more than doubling of Australia’s foreign debt because of the large current account deficits, because of the persistent trade deficits—41 trade deficits in a row—and because of this government’s lack of a national savings strategy.The only contribution that I can think of it making to a savings strategy was the ill-fated savings bonus. Members might recall the Prime Minister being asked whether he would claim that savings bonus that the government had introduced in a prior budget. He said he would not, and the rest is history. That particular measure was scrapped just a few weeks after it was introduced. This government has failed very badly to ensure that we have a pool of national savings to deal with the economic challenges of an ageing population.Today we have a debate about the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge, and that abolition is designed to achieve one thing and one thing only—and that is, the ascendancy of the Treasurer to the prime ministership. He has the backing of his entire party room for that measure because they know what the personal consequences of that are. But, in terms of the economic consequences, this budget does nothing of any significance to improve our national savings effort. It yet again favours consumption over investment; it favours consumption over savings. It has increased the spending spree that Labor complained about before the last election from $66 billion to $103 billion. If a $66 billion spending spree was going to put upward pressure on interest rates—which it did, resulting in the Reserve Bank increasing interest rates in March by a quarter of one per cent—then certainly a $103 billion spending spree can only add to the risk of further interest rate rises.Indeed, BIS Shrapnel, in conducting some economic forecasts, has suggested that mortgage interest rates could reach nine per cent in the not too distant future. I certainly hope that does not happen, because nine per cent mortgage interest rates would flatten the Australian economy. The truth is that previous economic recessions have been caused by the Reserve Bank increasing interest rates by too little and too late.The government, through the budget that it brought down a couple of weeks ago—including this measure—has only increased the risk of further increases in mortgage interest rates and the flattening of the Australian economy. Instead of investing the proceeds of the record terms of trade—the benefits have come to Australia via large mining company profits that are then being taxed—the government is using that money to fund the abolition of the superannuation tax surcharge and the provision of income tax cuts for people on higher incomes.These proceeds from the best terms of trade in 50 years should be used to achieve a better savings result for Australia—because that is what we are debating tonight: a savings policy for Australia. The government has not done that. Some of that money could have been spent fairly on income tax cuts and on investing in the nation’s future through extra investment in education, innovation and infrastructure. On all those counts, the government has failed. Instead it has brought down what is effectively a pre-election budget a year after an election for reasons best known to the Treasurer. Those reasons have more to do with the aspirations of the Treasurer of Australia to become the Prime Minister of Australia than they do with the legitimate aspirations of the Australian people for future increases in prosperity and living standards.The government’s budget, including the measures that we are debating tonight, is a very short-sighted document. It has no vision for the future. It does not invest in Australia’s future; yet, at the same time, it increases the risk of further interest rises in the future. It would be quite difficult to imagine a more unfair budget or a more economically irresponsible budget. Mr Deputy Speaker, if it does come to pass that interest rates do rise later in the year—and I do hope that they do not, because the Australian people and the Australian economy cannot afford it—let it be known that the Australian Labor Party opposed this government’s budget, not only on equity grounds but also on economic grounds.
