Speaker: N/A

name: Brough, Mal, MP
role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
content: —I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate on the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Abolition of Surcharge) Bill 2005. The bill represents a further significant step in improving the superannuation and retirement income arrangements for all Australians. It is only one step in many that this government has undertaken since it came to government in order to maximise the retirement incomes of retiring Australians and, in doing so, give them the quality of life that they both deserve and would want to enjoy in their retirement years.The government believes richly in incentives. It has delivered incentives through the co-contribution scheme and through this legislation by providing the most tax effective investment that anyone can utilise for their retirement—that is, superannuation. It is very important for Australia that individual Australians save for their future so that they can obtain the highest possible living standards and so that the drawdown on the budget as we age as a population is minimised.The surcharge, as everyone in this House knows, was introduced in 1996 when the Liberal-National Party was brought to power after the demise of the Keating government. It was not until after the election in March 1996 that the true position of Australia’s financial position, the government’s financial position, was known. What has become known as ‘Beazley’s black hole’—some $10 billion—was the legacy left to us by the previous Labor regime.The then Howard-Fischer government and now the Howard-Anderson government took unprecedented steps to ensure that a sound financial basis underpinned this nation and, in doing so, put down the footings that would lead to the prosperity that this nation is now enjoying, with record numbers of people in jobs, record levels of wages growth, low inflation, housing ownership up, share ownership up, and people feeling that they have a secure future. One measure by which that has been achieved has been the implementation of the super surcharge. It was done to raise additional revenue so that we could plug Beazley’s black hole.It is extraordinary that nearly 10 years later the member for Brand is still, in Labor’s eyes, the best they have to throw up as an alternative Prime Minister. This is the person who, as the finance minister in the Labor regime under Keating, plummeted us into such a position. As a nation we found out that $10,000 million was the hole in the budget for one single year. Some $96 billion was the legacy left to this government and, more importantly, to the taxpayers of this nation over the coming years.The government has taken measures to get us back into a position of security where the public debt in this country is at acceptable levels. As a result of the budget which has just been brought down, which contains the measure for the removal of the surcharge, the federal government has reduced public sector debt to just $6 billion from the high of $96 billion. That was the reason the surcharge was brought in. Today we are debating how we can remove it, given that the Treasurer announced on budget night that that was the government’s clear policy.Today the federal budget is in a solid financial position with more than one per cent of GDP in the surplus, not only this year but also in the out years. It gives some comfort to know that we can maintain our AAA credit rating, because that keeps downward pressure on the interest that the nation bears and on interest rates generally. By doing this, we have been able to achieve the removal of an impost of some $2.5 billion from 600,000 taxpayers.In simple terms, that means that 600,000 taxpayers will have larger retirement incomes. They will also have greater incentive to save more of the tax cuts that will come on 1 July, or shortly thereafter if the Labor Party continues to stymie our efforts to bring them in—but be assured that every Australian taxpayer will have their tax cuts on 1 July or very shortly thereafter. Eligible Australians will take the option to use the government’s co-contribution to maximise their savings incomes and get the $1.50 for every dollar they put in. As to higher income earners, I remember the fellow on the tarmac at the airport who wanted to get a message to the Treasurer about how pleased he was, as were his 50 co-workers, that this was being abolished. They can now make a choice—a choice which is theirs to make, not the government’s—to put some of those tax cuts into their retirement incomes, get the tax effectiveness from them and build a more sound and secure retirement for them and their families.This bill complements a significant boost to superannuation savings announced last year. The government expanded the very successful co-contribution, where once it was dollar for dollar and some 500,000 Australians earning under $40,000 took up the option in its first year of operation. That was a wonderful achievement. The member for Groom, from the Toowoomba region in Queensland, had over 7,000 constituents make a contribution and receive a dollar for each dollar of contribution. That is an extraordinary percentage for any one electorate. In my own electorate it was over 5,000. I am very pleased that people took that opportunity.I encourage everybody in this place to go out in the next month—30 days; that is what we have left—and encourage Australians to get their slice of the co-contribution. Encourage people earning under $58,000 to put a little something away for the future. Put a down payment on the tax cuts that are coming in now and the Howard government will match that with $1.50 for every dollar that you contribute. It is only through these measures and through responsible government that we have been able to remove the $2.3 billion impost in the super surcharge, increase the benefits of the co-contribution and make more flexible the superannuation arrangements for many Australians who wish to remain in the work force part-time and draw down on their superannuation as they grow older.It comes as no surprise to me that the Labor Party will oppose this bill tonight. They have opposed the tax cuts. With the Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2005, which we debated directly before this bill, they stand ready to ensure that, as a result of the tax cuts being rejected, some older Australians will pay a Medicare levy that they otherwise would not have to. Now they are saying to 600,000 Australians: you do not deserve to have the superannuation surcharge removed even though the country is now on a sound financial footing and you should continue to have that impost placed upon you when it is no longer required.It is a sad position for Labor Party. It is a position which is inconsistent in all but one manner: the Labor Party opposed the introduction of the super surcharge, they opposed the reduction in the super surcharge and they are opposing the abolition of the super surcharge. That is consistency—three different positions, but at least they consistently oppose. If oppositions, both state and federal, could learn something of what the public feels these days it would be: don’t oppose for opposition’s sake. I am afraid that is what we are seeing here tonight. We have seen many bills put forward by the government being opposed by the Labor Party in recent times.Quite simply, Labor’s recent record on superannuation lacks any semblance of credibility. It is far removed from the Labor Party that introduced the superannuation guarantee. It is a party that went to the last election not only promising to put taxes up for some Australians and to take away the family tax benefit for all Australians but also, unbelievably, to rip $3.8 billion, according to their own documentation, out of retirement incomes of Australians by removing the very popular co-contribution. On top of the $2.5 billion, $3.8 billion simply says that the party that once trumpeted superannuation as being important to this nation has run away from this as a policy initiative which can do many good things for the individual and for the nation as a whole.The abolition of this surcharge will simplify the operation of the superannuation system, and I know it will be welcomed by superannuation funds, businesses and the ATO alike. It will boost the superannuation savings of affected individuals and provide incentives for individuals to make additional voluntary superannuation savings as and when they can. It also builds on previous changes introduced by this government aimed at assisting Australians to achieve greater financial self-reliance for their retirement. I not only commend this bill to the House but I say to the Labor Party: remove yourselves from the shackles that have so hindered your capacity to move away from this ideologically driven position of wedge politics and envy politics. Acknowledge that the previous Labor government left a terrible legacy to Australia in the form of debt. With that shackle now removed from Australia we know, in good faith and with assurance, that we can remove the superannuation surcharge once and for all. I commend the bill to House.

Speaker: N/A

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
content: —The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer must be very pleased I moved that second reading amendment on the previous bill, the Superannuation Laws Amendment (Abolition of Surcharge) Bill 2005, in order to give him something to talk about as he tried to sum up debate on a bill which I think was entirely unjustifiable for all the points I made throughout the course of that second reading debate. So to assist the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer on this bill, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005, I shall now move an amendment to this bill as well:That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:“whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:condemns the Government for the poorly designed choice of superannuation fund regime which is too complex and unsafe; andcalls on the Government to:exempt small business—20 employees or less from this new red tape burden;remove the two year gaol term and the $22,000 fine on employers if they provide advice to their employees; andkeep the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve Account open”.You have to ask yourself what this government has against small business. The bill we are debating tonight amends a bill which was passed a year or so ago and does not come into effect until 1 July 2005. I made the point in earlier debates that the minister who was just at the dispatch box, the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, is becoming a serial offender in messing up these legislative programs. Here we have a bill not yet implemented that we are amending in this House tonight and the opposition will be supporting most of the amendments to the extent that they are designed to reduce the burden of the superannuation choice regime on small business. So we are more than happy to help the government out in this regard but what we will also be submitting to the House is that these amendments are not enough because the superannuation choice regime imposes such a burden on small business that no amendments short of repealing the original bill could hope to redress the situation. So what does the government have against small business? Why are they imposing this additional burden on Australia’s more than one million small businesses and the more than three million employees they pay on a weekly basis?This arose from a 1996 election promise and the Labor Party have justifiably been running interference on this proposal ever since. They went to the 1996 election promising a number of other things. Firstly, one was no new taxes—and we have just had the debate on the superannuation surcharge. In the first budget of the Howard government we had a surcharge which of course was effectively a new tax, and that is why we opposed that provision. Secondly, they promised small business a 50 per cent reduction in red tape. What a laughable matter that has become in the intervening 10 years or so. I should say that it would be laughable if it were not so serious. So we had the Bell committee, the Prosser committee, the Reid committee and the Baird committee along the way and where has red tape gone? It has gone north. There has been no greater contributor to that northward shift in the red tape burden on small business than the introduction of the goods and services tax.The government do not want to talk about the GST anymore. They would have us believe that all is rosy out there with respect to the GST. I have been prepared to concede in this place on a number of occasions that I think some form of consumption tax in this country was inevitable and, as the government well know, the Labor Party had a go at that itself. But it is all in the implementation, and there is no doubt that the compliance burden of the GST on small business has been even worse than small business could ever have imagined. We have a report put out by the Australian Taxation Office last week that indicates the extent to which small business is behind in remittance of their GST payments to the government.So this government has been a serial offender in this matter. It says it is about choice. But it is not about choice when it comes to the Trade Practices Act. The government refuses to move to give additional protection to the small business community under the Trade Practices Act post-Bell in cases like Rural Press and the inadequacy it has left in section 46 of the Trade Practices Act. This is not about choice in any case. This is ideologically driven. This bill is simply about the government’s concern about any influence the union movement might have over some $700 billion that we now have invested in superannuation funds in this country. That is what the bill is about.I remind the House that, prior to the Hawke and Keating governments, superannuation was a privilege extended in this country only to public servants and those on high incomes. We also had a national savings problem in this country. The Hawke and Keating governments addressed both of these big issues in one fell swoop by introducing for the first time in this country access to superannuation for all Australian workers, not just for a select few. That has had an enormous effect on the economic and social wellbeing of individual workers and working families in this country. With $700 billion under investment, that has also done much for national savings, a challenge which still lies before us with the inadequacies of the nine per cent contribution to superannuation. Despite those inadequacies, the government is not prepared to take on that issue. With the Intergenerational Report and all the Chicken Little predictions that came out of that report, we were entitled to expect that the government would have sought to address some of those issues in its 2005-06 budget but, alas, they chose not to do so. We got a future fund which is no more than a tax liabilities offset fund bringing forward the future obligations of taxpayers to current taxpayers, which means more tax for current taxpayers, but nothing which will address Labor’s core concern coming out of the Intergenerational Report—that is, the inadequacies of our savings pool in this country.If the government wanted to do something about that in the budget, they could have delivered tax cuts in the form of savings rather than consumption, which would have gone a long way to addressing the issue of returning a dividend to the Australian taxpayer at a time when the government are awash with money, rather than putting that money straight into consumption with all the implications that might have for interest rates in this country. Instead what did the government choose to do? They chose to deliver a $22 billion tax cut package which, as we know, was targeted at the higher income ranges in this country—$65 a week for those who sit in this place and on average $6 a week for those workers on the average wage in the 144 electorates represented in this place.That is a bit of the history of this bill. It seeks to amend a bill which has not yet been implemented for all the reasons that Labor pointed out when the original bill was debated in this place—a bill which was ideologically driven which was going to produce an inappropriate impost on business, particularly small business. The government’s concern in relation to super funds which may have a union influence in this country is totally beyond my understanding, given the performance of those funds and the contribution they have made to the economic infrastructure of this country. This bill amends the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2004, which was passed by the parliament some time ago. Specifically, this bill contans amendments to (1) close the government holding account for unpaid employer super guarantee contributions on 30 June 2006, (2) remove the obligation on employers already providing choice to employees to provide the standard choice-of-fund form to existing employees, (3) prohibit the employer from recouping part or all of the administrative costs associated with implementing choice of fund by charging employees, and (4) make ASIC responsible for enforcement of third-line forcing provisions and some other minor amendments.It intrigues me to hear the government expressing concern about the potential for third-line forcing under super choice when in another bill, which is apparently stalled in the Senate, it talks about relaxing third-line forcing provisions. That is a not insignificant change in the Trade Practices Act and will have significant implications for the small business sector. We have seen that very recently with the attempt by Coles to force certain marketing arrangements upon their suppliers. The government says that in some cases third-line forcing can prove a competitive market. But they have thrown the baby out with the bathwater. If someone wants to engage in activities that come under the definition of third-line forcing, they can go to the ACCC to get authorisation to do so—and that happens all the time. It happens with cooperatives, taxicabs, Sky News going into local hotels and clubs—you name it. It happens with shopper dockets, an example which those on the other side in this place like to throw in from time to time.If the ACCC comes to the conclusion that third-line forcing is competitive rather than anticompetitive, it can authorise it. But the important thing is that the ACCC can revoke authorisation at any time. Under the system being proposed by the government, which I suspect is mirrored in this bill, all the applicant would need to do is give notification of the action. The important thing about that is that the onus is then put back on the ACCC to prove that the third-line forcing arrangement will not lead to a substantial lessening of competition. That is a reversal of onus but is also a raising of the bar in terms of the test that the ACCC has to meet or prove that it is an uncompetitive practice.All the amendments in this bill, except for the first one, are reasonable, and they are accepted by Labor. The government claim they are closing SHAR because it is no longer needed. This is supposedly due to the existence of bank provided retirement savings accounts, which the government claim are a low-cost alternative. They have not been shopping around too much—and that does not surprise me, because we in this place are pretty comfortable in our superannuation arrangements. But if they had looked around they would have found that the RSAs provided by the banks are low return at about 2½ per cent and, of course, attract significant fees. An examination of a bank web site shows that this government, by closing SHAR, is giving a free kick to the banks. In other words, we are abolishing SHAR to allow the banks to grow their retirement savings accounts, impose big fees and provide low returns.The fact that the government is making a further major change to its own legislation within days of the 1 July start of choice highlights how poorly considered the policy is. ‘Costly, complex and unsafe’ is Labor’s description of the implementation of choice of superannuation fund by 1 July 2005. For 400,000 employees there will be a massive new compliance burden. Some 34 steps are needed to comply, including five million forms to be handed out to existing employees in the first year and over one million forms in each year thereafter; ongoing record-keeping for five years to be made available for tax office inspection and enforcement; and payments to multiple super funds—there are thousands of different funds, and the funds nominated can be changed every 12 months. Employers can be fined up to $500 per employee if they get all this wrong. Employers will face significant legal liability if they give advice to employees, even if they are asked. The fines extend to jail terms. All this adds up to one thing: higher costs for employers. Not since the GST have employers seen anything like it, and plenty of them are reporting it. A further 200,000 employers and two million employees will be added to this complex regime on 1 July 2006. Small business will be hardest hit by the new compliance burden. That is why Labor is calling for an exemption from super choice for small business.Two specific matters that have arisen in the past few months require further detailed comment. The first matter is that more than 900,000 employers are being told to print and pay for 3.8 million forms to implement the Howard government’s employee choice of super fund. Five million employees will need to be given the forms by their employer over the next few months, with a further one million forms needed each year thereafter. Employers face the major new red-tape burden of form filling and record keeping, and the costs of the new super scheme which starts on 1 July.It is outrageous to expect employers to carry the cost of printing millions of forms on top of all the other new costs. Businesses are complaining that the tax office infoline is telling employers to print and pay for their own forms. The tax office admitted at the Senate Treasury estimates in February that only 1.2 million forms would be printed. Five million forms are needed initially and only one million will be available. Senator Sherry, Labor’s key superannuation spokesman, has already established at estimates who will bear the cost of the payment system. All the costs in the new cost burden will be borne by the employer. Form printing and distribution, checking and record keeping of forms, payment of contributions to multiple funds, software systems upgrades and specialist advice on the new system are all new costs to the employer.The second matter is the excessive penalties: two years jail and/or a $22,000 fine for employers is what they face under the new super choice law if they risk giving advice. It is important that all business owners, particularly of small businesses, push the Howard government to remove the penalties as they are too harsh for any mistakes that could be made. The penalties are over the top: they are harsh and excessive. They are also unnecessary. The two-year jail term should be removed and the fine of $22,000 should be substantially reduced. In the circumstances of a new and complicated system the penalty on an employer under the FSR Act should be reduced substantially to the same level that applies under the choice of superannuation legislation itself.Labor is all for protecting the funds of small business employees but these controls are over the top. Many small business owners are unsure how to cope with the additional workload necessary to offer choice of super fund and they will be the ones most vulnerable. The penalties are a result of the application of the FSR Act that applies to any person who gives advice who is not licensed to do so. Of course, most employers are not licensed financial advisers and planners nor are they ever likely to be. It is a certainty that some of the five million employees will ask their employer for advice about what to do and some employers, trying to act in good faith and do the right thing, are inevitably going to give advice about the funds. The employer should not give legal advice but it is understandable that some will do so. It is understandable that some will not understand the legislation. It is understandable that a good employer will want to help an employee through the maze of paperwork and help them grow their super fund and will give advice not knowing that they could be breaching the law.Super choice is incredibly complicated and the Howard government is demanding employers be across it by 1 July, even though tonight the Howard government is bringing in a bill to correct the original bill itself. This is simply unfair and the employer has to wear not only the new red tape costs but now face unnecessary penalties. The Howard government said it would cut red tape for small business. It would be a good start if they stopped making it worse.For employees there is an unsafe regulatory framework that fails to protect consumers from fee rip-offs. For example, entry and exit fees and commission based selling is still permitted providing it is disclosed in complex, lengthy 50-page disclosure documents. Super fees and charges will come down due to competitive pressures as promised by the Liberal government. Labor will hold the government accountable to that promise. The inclusion of retirement savings accounts as a default fund with no insurance coverage when it is required by other types of funds is not a level playing field. This clearly favours the banks which offer this type of account. Labor will be listening to employers and employees to develop a simpler and safer choice of fund system.First, the government should be picking up Labor’s suggestion and exempting small business with 24 or fewer employees. This is not an arbitrary figure. We have heard this 20 employees figure before. In fact we have heard it ad nauseam in this place over the course of the last 10 years as the government has argued that small business should be exempt from the unfair dismissal laws. It has argued that small businesses do not have a human resources department to deal with these claims. It has argued that small businesses are at a special disadvantage. Tonight, in one sense, the Labor Party is agreeing with the government and saying, ‘Yes, that’s right. Small businesses with 20 employees or fewer do not have the capacity, the human resources department, the money and the time to be dealing with this excessive red tape burden.’Second, Labor want to remove the threat of the $22,000 fine and we certainly want to hear the government spokesperson on this bill reassure us that no small business operator in this country could face a jail sentence for inadvertently giving advice to an employee on the question of his superannuation fund. We will be very happy if the minister comes in here tonight for the summation and explains to us that the FSR Act does not apply in these circumstances and reassures us that no small business person could possibly face a jail term under these arrangements. If he does that then we will be happy to withdraw our in detail stage amendments, which would remove that threat. We will be happy to withdraw them. If he does not give us that assurance then we will be obligated to move those in detail stage amendments to ensure those small business people are protected.We are living in a funny world at the moment. We have a Commonwealth government in this country that is at the moment drunk with power. This new form of federalism would cause Menzies to turn in his grave. Gough Whitlam was often accused of being centralist. He pales into insignificance compared with what we are seeing in the Commonwealth government today. In fact, Gough Whitlam was not much of a centralist. Gough Whitlam believed in a greater role for central government in the affairs of people but at the same time as he was building on the Commonwealth’s power he was devolving power to the regions. He was creating sectoral commissions and cooperative arrangements between the three levels of government to ensure the decision making was not top down but bottom up. He has been misrepresented in many senses on his approach to federalism in this country. After years of screaming states rights the current Prime Minister and his senior ministers are trying to take control—the Minister for Health and Ageing is trying to take control of health in this country, the Minister for Education, Science and Training is trying to take control of education in this country and the Attorney-General is trying to take control of defamation laws in this country. It goes on and on and on. It should be of real concern to us all.This government needs to remember that the federal system works best when it is working on a cooperative basis. It cannot work otherwise. The federal system is a good compact. It is being embraced by new nation states like Iraq and Afghanistan. In the UK, even though they have a unitary system, they are moving towards a federal model in the sense of the strengthening of regional decision-making bodies. The federal system can work and can work well. That has been recognised around the world. But it cannot work when it is not a partnership. We should all be concerned about this.The government wants to talk about choice. How about giving the voting public a choice? How about giving them the opportunity to have a federal compact in this country which works, an arrangement where you have a cooperative relationship between the various levels of government in this country. So let us talk about choice, let us talk about cooperative government in this country, not the Commonwealth government acting on what it might see as a mandate—which, I can assure it, will be temporary in controlling the Senate. The government will not have it next time. No-one is likely to have it for a long time, and I think the government should start acting more responsibly.

Speaker: N/A

name: Robb, Andrew, MP
content: —I rise in support of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005. This bill consists of measures the government seeks to put in place to ensure that the transition to super choice on 1 July is as easy as possible for businesses and employees and to minimise the burden on employers in complying with the new super choice regime.Superannuation choice allows employees to choose the fund into which their compulsory employee contributions are made. This superannuation choice measure complements a range of important superannuation initiatives that the government has put in place to increase the savings pool for the Australian community—initiatives such as the co-contribution, which has been hugely popular, and the scrapping of the surcharge, which will provide people with a significantly greater incentive to save and make provision for themselves rather than rely in future on taxpayers to support them.This government believes in choice. The member for Hunter, in the previous speech on this bill, repeated much of what he said in 2003 about the original legislation and claimed that the bill is not about choice but about ideology and an objection to industry funds. Maybe the member for Hunter has not noticed, but this government is all about choice, and not just in superannuation. We have had a concerted program over 9½ years of government to increase choice in education, in health and now in industrial relations—in a host of areas. In education we have got tremendous opportunities for parents around the country to choose between government schools and private schools, independent schools. There has been a concerted program which has increased the excellence of our schools right across Australia. These are not the class based policies which the Labor Party presented at the last election. Those policies, I might add, have not been rescinded; they remain Labor policies.Mr Deputy Speaker, you also see choice in the health sector. We have got 56 per cent of all operations conducted in private hospitals. We have got a great model of private and public hospital provision. Again, that is a very significant and deliberate approach taken by this government to increase excellence, to provide choice and to provide efficiencies across all sorts of sectors. Again, in industrial relations, which we have been talking about in the last few days, we are not scrapping awards; we are providing choice, serious choice, so that we can increase the flexibility and the efficiency of the workplace.In that same vein, the government is offering choice in superannuation, and not through any ideology or any preconceived view about industry funds—they are free to participate and to operate in this whole choice equation with other funds. The choice in superannuation will allow Australians to take control of their own superannuation savings and consequently their futures. Being involved in the decisions about where their superannuation contributions are paid will mean that employees will start to consider the adequacy of their retirement savings sooner rather than later. This is a good thing. The policy provides for choice right at the start of a person’s employment life and causes them to reflect upon the provision they are making for the future. It is not smart to start thinking about the adequacy of your provision for retirement as you approach retirement. Choice will play a big part in helping to focus the minds of people throughout their lives on the adequacy of provision of funds for their retirement.Choice of funds will also mean that the superannuation industry and individual funds will need to be more competitive and responsive to the needs and wants of Australians in terms of their superannuation investments. Greater competition means greater efficiency, which should drive improved returns on superannuation, lower charges and lower administration fees. Already we are seeing considerable evidence that super funds are reducing fees and administrative charges in the lead-up to the provision of choice on 1 July. Competition is already starting to deliver results. This is not ideology; this is the power of choice with regard to superannuation.Choice will also be an advantage for people who want to change jobs on a regular basis or are involved in casual or temporary work. If people are allowed to choose their fund, it will ensure that lost superannuation money will become a thing of the past. In 2003, when this legislation was being debated, there was around $7 billion and 4.6 million accounts on the lost member register of the Australian Taxation Office. That is a very significant item, one that needs to be dealt with and one that will be dealt with by the provision of choice.The current arrangements also disadvantage those in itinerant work and those in multiple part-time jobs and, again, this will be addressed by the provision of choice. There is a further, intangible benefit when individuals are empowered to make decisions on things such as their superannuation savings: they become far more aware of the broader economic decisions and events that will impact upon their future livelihood. This is a good thing. It is a very good thing to increase the awareness of people right across the community about things that will improve their lives and the provision of funds for their retirement. Choice and individual freedom are major drivers of good policy. That is the conclusion. It is a not a matter of ideology; it is a matter of good policy. It is working in so many areas of public policy now as a result of the very deliberate efforts of this government which are delivering great results in all sorts of areas.Tonight an amendment was moved that seeks to exempt small businesses with fewer than 20 employees. This is a frivolous amendment in the sense that it will cause more problems than it seeks to solve. The fact is that the paperwork requirements for small business, for all business, have been deliberately and very effectively reduced to a minimum. In fact the interaction with small business over the last few months through a very serious education program put in place to educate, advise and communicate to small business the requirements they face—the two-page form they are required to fill out within one month from 1 July, a form required to be filled out once a year—and through the shifting of the onus onto employees has meant that the response from small business is such that, in all of the efforts around the 850,000 small businesses in this country, there is not a concern about the implementation or the paperwork. The only thing that is really worrying small business is the scaremongering being perpetrated by those on the other side of the House. When they have looked at the detail and have looked at what is involved, they are comfortable with what they are required to do—that is, to fill out a two-page form within a month of 1 July and to repeat that exercise every 12 months.If an exemption were provided for small business, it would mean that a very large number of employees would not be given the right to choose a fund. I have just been through a whole series of advantages that choice will provide to Australian workers right across this country. All of those advantages would be denied to a very large number of employees. Small business accounts for nearly 97 per cent of all private sector businesses and employs 50 per cent of private sector employees. The Labor Party seeks to deny hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of employees the opportunity of choice in super and all the advantages that come with a choice in super. Choice of fund is expected to increase competition. As I said earlier, the fees and charges of various superannuation funds are already decreasing. They are already coming down as a result of the announcement effect and the implementation effect of this policy provision. If small business employees are unable to choose their own fund that will reduce these benefits of competition.This bill makes some consequential amendments to the Small Superannuation Accounts Act 1995, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 and the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. Schedule 1 of the bill amends the aforementioned acts as follows. An employer may not directly charge an employee for the cost associated with complying with the super choice legislation and implementing the choice regime. This bill imposes a penalty on employers who seek to do so. This is important because employees must not be discouraged from exercising their right to choose a fund through the actions of their employer. However, this does not imply that an employer is liable for any financial disadvantage experienced by an employee as a result of their choice of fund decision where this loss is not related to the actions of the employer—for example, if a fund chosen by the employee increases its fees.Secondly, this bill specifies circumstances where an employer does not have to provide employees with a standard choice form, thus avoiding the imposition of unnecessary costs on some employers. A very serious attempt has been made to minimise the requirements, the paperwork and any onerous provisions on businesses, especially small businesses. A very successful attempt has been made to do that. Section 32NA of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 provides for circumstances where an employer is not required to comply with the choice of funds legislation in providing a standard choice form to their employees. This includes situations where the employee was offered choice of fund prior to 1 July 2005. Further, the bill clarifies a number of matters, including the test for whether a defined benefits fund is in surplus, the employer’s obligation to contribute to the fund specified as the default fund on the standard choice form, whether a choice of fund offered by employers before 1 July 2005 is consistent with the choice legislation, and the penalty provisions in relation to these matters.The bill specifies that ASIC will be responsible for the administration of the ‘no employer kickback’ provisions in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. Fund trustees must not try to inappropriately induce employers to move their employees’ contributions to the trustee’s fund by offering personal incentives. The bill further amends the provisions in relation to the use of the superannuation holding account special account. This special account was originally established to receive small superannuation amounts from employers who could not find a superannuation fund. In future, employers will not be able to use this fund, because this facility will no longer be needed as retirement savings accounts offer similar low-cost benefits for employers.The bill will amend the legislation to make the superannuation holding account special account an eligible choice fund until 20 June 2006, giving employers a further year to make arrangements to contribute to a superannuation fund or retirement savings account. From 1 July 2006, the special account will be closed to new employer deposits. All of these provisions are designed to make it easier for employers to implement this scheme and to make it easier for employees to follow the arrangements. They are commonsense and I welcome the support for these provisions by the other side of the House. Choice of funds is an important policy and it is important to all working Australians. This bill makes the necessary amendments to ensure that the transition to choice is as easy as possible for all employees, employers and businesses. I commend the bill to the House.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Burke, Tony, MP
content: —The member for Goldstein made some extraordinary comments just then concerning the concept of choice. He used the line that this government is all about choice. He is claiming, in the context of superannuation, that the government is all about choice just days after the Prime Minister stood in here and said that superannuation should cease to be an allowable matter. The Prime Minister stood in here and said that if an employer and employee agree and want to put something into an industrial instrument, the government will get in the road and say, ‘You’re not allowed to exercise that choice.’ On the exact issue of superannuation which the member for Goldstein has just referred to we find that if an employer and employees agree that they want to have a default fund and that the default fund will be the only one available—whether it is put into an AWA or a collective agreement—and they make the decision because there is a clear benefit to the employer in terms of paperwork, this government will say: ‘We’re going to interfere and not allow that choice at all. We’re going to get in the road and say that you’re not allowed to agree on that anymore.’If it is okay by the employer and it is okay by the employee but the government is troubled by it, I say that it is bad luck for the government. Let the employers and employees make their own agreements. That is why they are called agreements. They do not necessarily have to agree with the member for Goldstein, but if they agree with each other it should be allowed to be an allowable matter and should be allowed to be put on foot.There is another thing about which we have no choice at all. There is no choice when it comes to red tape with this government. This government said that they would reduce red tape by 50 per cent—in fact, they said it even before they became a government. That comment was made by the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition as he then was, in the great debate when questioned by Ray Martin. He said, ‘We are committed to reducing the red tape that small business has to grapple with by 50 per cent in our first term.’What do we find subsequently? We find, in the Financial Review on 18 April this year, the Minister for Small Business and Tourism saying that the new federal review stems from the Howard government’s fourth term agenda goal of reducing red tape. What was meant to be done in the first term in reducing red tape has now become a fourth term agenda item. It is open to the government to do that now. There is a new way that the government can reduce red tape by 50 per cent: take it back to 1996 levels and you will probably be there. Nothing annoys small business more than the way this government has added every extra level of compliance burden and said to small business on every occasion: ‘It is your fault and you can deal with it.’ A fascinating speech was made in 1994 in which someone said:They have no idea that the average small businessman is simultaneously the managing director, the sales manager, the personnel manager, the chief accountant and the tea lady all rolled into one. They have this vision that small business operators have a personnel department that can fill out all the forms, answer all the questionnaires and keep all the records of discussions with employees. They do not know the realities of trying to run a small business and the sorts of pressures that bear upon small businessmen.That speech was made on 5 May 1994 by the member for Bennelong. If only he remembered those words now, because every time this government has a new idea and decides who is going to do the paperwork, it leaves it at the door of small business. It leaves the red tape at the door of small business. This government knows it has nothing at all to be proud of when it comes to that original promise on red tape for small businesses. Subsequently, at the great debate at the National Small Business Summit only held a couple of weeks ago, we had a ringing endorsement from the minister for small business on this policy. She said:You appreciate that this whole issue of superannuation choice has been around since 1998 when Senator Rod Kemp was the assistant Treasurer and so it has been out there for a very long time, but this is something I have inherited.That was a ringing endorsement from the minister for small business. It is no surprise that when we debated the exemption for small business in an MPI, the minister for small business was nowhere to be seen in this chamber. She got out the door before I got to my feet and made sure she had nothing to do with defending this policy.When we are debating a second reading amendment to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005 dealing quite specifically with an exemption for small business, wouldn’t you think that might be an occasion for the minister for small business to wander down into the chamber? But, no, she was not put on the speakers’ list because the government realises the nightmare that has been created for small businesses in the way this has been implemented. The government knows it full well, and every time the government interacts with any small business operator, which clearly does not happen nearly as often as it should, this government will be told the same message.How extraordinary it was to hear the previous speaker say, ‘You talk to small businesses and there are no big problems out there once you explain it to them.’ I presume he thinks COSBOA is guilty of the same level of naivety. I presume he believes that the peak body of small business organisations, which publicly backs Labor’s call for an exemption of small business, just have not looked at the detail. Well, I am sorry, members of the government, they have. It is extraordinarily patronising and condescending to anybody who is out there running a small business and having to deal with the paperwork—when what they want to focus on is running their business—to be told: ‘It’s only a two-page form.’ Good one! It is a two-page form with a 16-page explanatory document for employers and a 55-page explanatory document for employees.Faced with that sort of paperwork, what do we think employees are going to say to the small business operator? It is pretty clear what they will say. There will be some who say, ‘Can I rip it up?’ and they will rip it up. There will be some who go out there and make a choice. And there will be a lot who say to their boss: ‘What do you reckon I ought to do?’ I have to say that is a relatively innocent question. But if the employer answers that question and gives honest advice, which has been requested in good faith, they are subject to either a maximum $22,000 fine or a maximum two years imprisonment. When this was debated in the MPI we had what I have to say was impressive spin. I will concede to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer it was impressive stuff—and I have the quote here because if I tried to paraphrase no-one would believe it:I make it clear to the shadow minister and to the small business community of Australia—quite a creative moment in his speech—that there is no such provision—referring to the jail sentences—in the choice legislation. I invite the shadow minister to take a look. The comments of the shadow minister, and of his leader in his speech in reply, alluded to the point that somehow we, the government, had introduced in this legislation a policy and a position that would require, in the event of a broken commitment by small businesses, their ending up in jail—and that is untrue.The same sentiments were echoed in the MPI debate by the member for Mackellar, who said:For the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for small business to try to drum up fear and loathing—which I thought was creative in itself—and purport that a $22,000 fine is contained within this legislation is unworthy of members of this parliament. Indeed, it is the sort of tactic that gives politicians in general a bad name.At one level what they said has an element of truth to it, because at one level it is true. The jail penalties are not contained within the choice legislation. The jail penalties are contained within the Corporations Act and they are activated by the choice legislation. But we had said in this parliament that somehow it is great compensation to small business operators to say: ‘Well, if you end up making a mistake with this and you end up giving financial advice, at least you’ll have the consolation of knowing it wasn’t the legislation responsible for super choice that put you in jail. It was only the way it interacted with the Corporations Act.’ They’ll be able to lean back in their banana lounges in Long Bay Jail quite content—thank heavens it was the Corporations Act and not any piece of legislation that had super choice in its title.Sorry, but the super choice legislation activates those clauses. If you are simply operating from a default fund, you never fall into the trap of accidentally or inadvertently giving financial advice. The mere fact that employees are given these forms means—let us not pretend: everybody in this room should know this for certain—the scenario I described before will occur. Employees will say to the boss: ‘What do you reckon I ought to do?’ If you do not think they have that sort of close relationship with the boss then you do not understand how small businesses operate. In so many ways the people who work for a small business act as an extension of the family of the employer, even though they might not be directly related. The relationship is that close. Advice will be sought.For the government to say that there is any relief because the jail penalties come under an act with a different title is to treat small business with utter contempt. Yet that was the argument that was run in this chamber last week by the minister for revenue and the member for Mackellar. I hope no-one runs that line in this debate tonight because the dishonesty of it is now exposed, so I say to you: if you have been given your speaking notes by the minister I would have another read over them.For those people who think they might have inherited this legislation, for those people who think that this might be the responsibility of others, the opposition is making sure there is an opportunity to deal with that. For those people who think that they did not really intend for that interaction to happen between the super choice legislation and the Corporations Act, Labor are making sure that there is a way of dealing with that. We are making sure of two things. I was not here for the whole speech by the previous speaker but I heard him refer to one of them, which is an exemption for small business. This is not small business under the new workplace relations definition of 100 employees, but small business with fewer than 20 employees. We will provide that exemption for them. It is not good enough to argue in rebuttal that that is terribly unfair to the employees. We already have a period of time where it is currently not applying to people under collective agreements or AWAs, although the government is planning on changing that and interfering with the choice of the parties further down the track. We already have a case that for more than 12 months to go it will not apply to people on state awards. There are already exemptions in the system. So it is simply not good enough to say, ‘That would be terribly unfair to employees,’ because it is already being introduced as a package that will not be universal when it kicks off. That is already the case.We are giving two opportunities to the members of this House in respect of the super choice legislation tonight. In the morning, members of this House are going to divide and all those members of the government are going to have to come in here and decide first of all whether they support an exemption for small business. They are going to have to vote as to whether it is reasonable at the very least to stop making the red tape burden worse. I do not know how they managed to come up with such a convoluted system. I do not know how anyone can say it is just a two-page form. Mind you, if all that comes back is a two-page form and the employer acts on it, they are acting in breach of the legislation, because it has to come back with a certificate as well. Simply to say it is a two-page form is wrong and ignores the issue about the 16-page explanatory document for employers and the 55-page explanatory document for employees. So the exemption for small business is not an unreasonable call. It is not unfair to employees but it gives the choice to small business operators that if they do not want to have to take on an extra burden of red tape they do not have to.But the second amendment that we will be dealing with in the morning, which every member of this House will vote on, will be quite explicit: do you believe that there should be jail terms when an employer inadvertently gives advice, even when that advice is requested by the employee? If there is a kickback involved, if an employer is giving advice and getting a kickback to make some money for themselves, there ought to be serious penalties. If the employer is going out and being a full-on advocate and trying to persuade employees and push them in a particular direction, that is contrary to the spirit of the legislation and penalties ought to prevail. I have no worries with that at all. But surely it is reasonable to say that, if the request comes from the employee and the employer simply answers a question in good faith with no pecuniary benefits, they should be exempt from prison terms. This is not a big call. This is not a really radical view.I have to say, when we first embarked on making a bit of noise about this issue, I thought we would lose traction on it very quickly because I thought the government were going to announce that they would fix it. I cannot for the life of me understand why the government would believe it is good public policy to impose a prison sentence for a small business operator who acts in that manner. People might say, ‘The courts will take it into account.’ A prison sentence should not even be on the table as a possibility for an employer who acts in that fashion. Every single member of this House will exercise the vote tomorrow morning and will make it clear whether or not they believe employers who act in good faith at the request of employees should be subjected to prison terms.I am looking forward to seeing which way the member for Kingston votes, what he is going to say to the businesses in Lonsdale or Seaford and what he is going to say when the Southern Times Messenger is notified about the impact of this on the local small businesses in that electorate. I am looking forward to hearing what the member for Bonner has to say and what the Wynnum Herald subsequently reports on the issue of prison terms for employers who act in good faith. I am looking forward to seeing what the member for Greenway has to say to the Blacktown chamber of commerce and to the Blacktown Advocate when she has to defend increasing the red tape burden on small business and defend prison terms for employers who act in good faith. I am looking forward to seeing how the member for Wakefield, the member for Braddon, the member for Hasluck and the member for Stirling decide to interact when they are asked questions on 7BU, by the Northern Argus, by the Midland Kalamunda Reporter or by the Mount Barker Courier. I am looking forward to all of that.
