name: Pearce, Christopher, MP
content: —Just worry about yourself! Don’t worry about that.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Burke, Tony, MP
content: —I am being told a classic principle by the member opposite: ‘Just worry about yourself.’ Isn’t that precisely what the government have done? For the government to handle any part of the paperwork would involve a cost to government—and we can’t have that! Let’s make it a cost to business. On the cost to business issues, you bet they have just worried about themselves. We even had the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer in this chamber last week saying, ‘Look, there is really no compliance problem because there are these things called clearing houses.’ Yes, there are things called clearing houses—just as there are accountants and bookkeepers—and every one of those things costs money. None of that financial burden is being borne by the government. The government are providing the exact level of leadership that I just heard across the table. They will just worry about themselves and look after themselves.When it comes to small business, that is not good enough. The government has not just ignored this key promise but has gone in the exact opposite direction. There was a key promise about the reduction in red tape for small business and the government has increased it. It is about to increase it again, and tomorrow morning we will get a chance to say enough is enough. Small business should not bear the brunt of a government that only cares about itself. Small business should not be subjected to criminal penalties when acting in good faith. Small business deserves a break. Small business deserves to have what was originally promised to it: less red tape. I say to the members opposite: even if you have decided that you are going to dishonour this promise, even if you have decided that you do not really care about small business, just stop making it worse. Members opposite get a chance to do that tomorrow morning. It would be a shame to miss that opportunity. We might get political traction out of it, but it is a lousy deal for small business.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Cadman, Alan, MP
content: —The member for Watson made an interesting speech. It is a pity it was not accurate and a pity it was not based on fact. Here is the first newspaper I have picked up, and look at this headline: ‘MYOB survey reveals confidence about the next 12 months’. The survey also attests that most small businesses already offer choice in super. In the survey, 1,501 small business owners and general managers answered 17 questions about their business via the internet. So much for the confected argument that this is a worry to small business. I just want to educate the member because he is trying to manufacture a case that does not really exist. The results of the second survey show:… although 54 per cent of businesses do not believe super choice will be a significant burden … More than 90 per cent of businesses with five to 19 employees are aware of super choice. The need for super choice in the small-business sector has been called into question by this survey, with 73 per cent of businesses surveyed already offering choice of super to their employees.Where does the Labor Party stand with these jolly confected amendments and the carry-on about the damage to small business? There is one survey of 1,500 small businesses.There are other surveys, but firstly I want to demonstrate to the House how simple this matter of choice is. The Assistant Treasurer has provided me with a copy of the ‘Choice of superannuation fund Standard choice form—information for employees’. Option 1, in the first column, reads: ‘You do not have to choose a fund’. Option 2, in the second column, reads, ‘Choose a fund’. It also gives further information. When you turn over the form you find that half of the page contains information for the employer to complete. It reads, ‘Part A: Employer to complete’—which just means he has to fill in his name and address. He then has to list where the employer superannuation guarantee contributions have previously been made. The choice part of the form asks the employee for their name and address—the usual stuff—and the fund into which they want the money to go. How simple is that?What a manufactured process the Labor Party is using tonight. By filling in half a page of this form employees can indicate which fund they wish to put their money into. By completing half a page of this form employers can indicate which funds they have used previously—if employees seek to switch the fund they use. It is simple. It is not difficult. There is no angst. Three-quarters of small businesses already offer choice in superannuation. In fact, if they decide that their employees will be given choice between now and 1 July, that is satisfactory. It does not have to be done on 1 July or during the month of July; it can be done now.I noticed in the Australian Financial Review of 13 April this year an article by Barrie Dunstan headed: ‘Wake-up call on super’. He writes:With only 11 weeks to go, a study of super fund members by Mercer Human Resources Consulting found that at least 10 per cent were considering switching funds in the next two years.There we have a choice in super producing movement in the marketplace, with people shopping around and looking for something different. The article continues:The study revealed the profile of prospective switches: they were likely to be male, dissatisfied with their current fund, with multiple super accounts and—some with—high account balances.So there we have a typical itinerant worker in the building industry with a multiplicity of funds with all the companies that he has worked for, each of them shoving his money into a fund of their choice—not his choice. That worker is dissatisfied with the process. A large number of workers are looking at the options in the market already and are wondering where they are going to put their money. What happens to the industry? Of course, the superannuation industry are worried about that because they do not know what the results are going to be. So what does that concern produce? It produces reduced fees and better conditions for the investors. That is the competition process that the choice in super generates. The article continues:As example of the mismatches, Mercer found that the two features members most wanted were the ability to nominate a beneficiary at death—81 per cent wanted that—and the ability to choose their own fund.Seventy-two per cent wanted the ability to choose their own fund. There we have both the employees, 72 per cent, wanting to choose their own fund and the employers, 75 per cent, who have already given that opportunity to their employees. The manufactured indignation from the Australian Labor Party just does not hold water. Three-quarters of employees and three-quarters of small businesses have already made up their mind. Numerous surveys indicate that they are not worried about it. They are more worried about interest rates rising, and they certainly will not have interest rate rises to the same degree under this government as they would have had under the Labor Party. So they have confidence in that area and choice of super is not of concern to them.When you look at the form you have to ask yourself: what could be simpler? I know that the most uneducated person living in a boundary riders hut in Deputy Speaker Scott’s electorate, who had never been to school, would have no difficulty in understanding this form. I believe that the most poorly informed employer, starting out in business with their first employee, would also find this a simple form to fill in. They would know their own name, for instance. They would know to which fund they had made contributions before. If they had no contributions previously they would just scratch that part out. The form reads, ‘Employer superannuation guarantee contributions have previously been made to ...’ There are just three questions that they have to answer. So the most uninformed employer has three questions—one of which includes their name—to complete in the choice of super form which, according to members of the Australian Labor Party, is supposed to be so complex.For the employee there are four questions to answer. The fourth question is a little harder; it is a tick the box question. The part reads, ‘My employer’s previous superannuation fund named in part A question 3.’ If they want their money to go there, they tick that box, or they tick the second box which reads, ‘My own choice of fund.’ Having chosen one of those two boxes, they have to write down their own name and address and other details. It is hard stuff; it is really difficult; it is really complex! It is half a page with great big boxes that are easily filled in. Even a person who is half-blind could read it without any assistance. As I say, it would be as easy for a jackeroo as it would be for a station manager. It would be as easy for the small businessman with a take-away shop and his weekend casuals as it would be for people wanting to make extra money working at weekends to supplement pocket money from their parents. I do not know what the Labor Party are on about.There is one other aspect of this that I find fascinating. In an article by Chris Wright in the Fin Review of 30 March, he writes about the increased interest in the do-it-yourself funds by people who are now given a choice. People not only have the choice of going to their employer’s fund or a fund operated by a large institution, they also have the option of investing in their own fund. Chris Wright outlines in the article the advantages for people who invest in their own fund from research by AMP Capital Investors and research group Investment Trends. The article states:Many investors felt that the choice of super regime, which kicks in in July, would prompt still greater numbers to take the DIY route. As more and more corporate funds close, and investment options gain greater attention, it’s likely that many will opt to try managing their own superannuation assets.The study showed that the motivations for doing so are not as straightforward as is usually assumed.While a desire for greater control of investments was the main driver towards starting a DIY fund, with 55 per cent of respondents mentioning it, only 24 per cent said they launched such a fund in order to save money on fees.The article quotes Mark Johnston of Investment Trends:‘It’s a relatively small subset who say it’s all about fees.’There we have increased interest in doing it yourself, employees who are well informed, employers who are already doing it and a simple form at that.The provisions of the bill before the House make clear some of the aspects of choice that need to be known before 1 July. This relates to the way the taxation fund, the SHASA, is operating. This is a fund operating out of the Australian Taxation Office that allows employers to put small amounts under the care of the tax office. It does not earn any interest but no fees are charged either. If an employer does not know where an employee is, the money goes into that fund with the name and details of the employee. It also allows itinerant workers, such as fruit-pickers, who earn small amounts to lodge in that fund—maybe small weekly payments for a short period. That fund is going to operate for another year and will close on 1 July 2006 because the government has decided it will be simpler to move that investment across to retirement savings funds operated by banks.When he gives his speech in reply, I would like the Assistant Treasurer to give us a bit more information about those bank operated funds because, according to the Bills Digest, the earning capacity of RSAs may not be as high as regular funds and their fees may be higher. I think there is some uncertainty about whether that is a fact and I would like a few details about how RSAs perform compared with normal funds. If employers of, say, fruit-pickers or itinerant workers of any type choose that route, I would hate to think that any contributions being made into those funds are going to be whittled away by increased fees and charges by the banks. I think we all have enough of a healthy respect but also a suspicion of bank charges to know that they need some careful supervision of whether or not people are going to be disadvantaged by that process.I think this is just a terrific thing for Australia. The whingers in the Australian Labor Party are really base because they know that industry funds are not going to be able to compete. They know that the union based funds have not performed as well as they should have, so they focus on small business in order to draw attention away from the campaigns being waged by industry funds to hook in more people. The union movement are advertising on television day and night to try to attract people to industry funds operated by the union movement. They forget to say that in the advertisements, but that is what those funds are about.I have here a booklet authorised by the Australian government entitled ‘Super choices—think about your future’. It is a simple booklet that lays out all the key factors. Anybody wanting information about choice between now and the end of July should try to get hold of this booklet. It is readily available and contains web site addresses and a toll-free telephone number that people can call. The booklet offers advice on the types of funds that a member can join and where they can get information. They can also get information about the performance of the different types of funds operated by different companies and compare the fees and benefits of different funds.There is also a useful table indicating who is eligible to join this choice process. In New South Wales, for instance, employees whose superannuation contributions are paid under state awards or industrial agreements can choose a fund under state law. However, there is no obligation on your employer to agree to the choice. This regime will apply to about five million people coming under the ambit of Commonwealth law or awards. The information about choices allows people to find out about each fund, how their money gets paid back to them, how they can consolidate if they should change jobs—so the portability factor is there—and compares costs and fees.Also, whether or not there is a death and disability adjunct to the super fund is something of great interest. As I remember, 81 per cent of employees are very interested in whether or not there is a death and disability factor attached to their super fund. Most people want that because, if they have families, they like to be sure that their families will be well cared for if they become incapacitated. There is even a worksheet to allow people to work through the process. It is a simple booklet—well prepared and easily understood. It is only a few pages, but it clearly sets out information to assist anybody wanting to make a choice of super.The process is easy: people can have choice as to their super fund and they have to do that before the end of July. If they decide they want no choice at all, the employer can make that choice for them. If they decide not to exercise a choice, the employer will do that for them. If they make a decision for choice and they choose a non-complying fund, they have a period in which that can be fixed up. They have a right to change their fund once every 12 months if their fund is not performing or they get better information and they decide to consolidate their funds in one place. ATO tax educators’ seminars will be happening around the country so that people will be better informed. So information will be provided to people wanting to know more about funds. If there is noncompliance by an employer, the fines are there but they cannot be more than $500 per employee. I would like to warn employers this is a process that needs to be complied with. It is simple: it is just half a page with three questions to be answered by the employer.This is a terrific change for Australia. This puts people in charge of their own destiny. It stops money being wasted. Hundreds of millions of dollars are lost each year by people who cannot keep track of their super. At the end of the day that means funds which are rightfully theirs cannot be used in their retirement and funds to which they have contributed by hard work are lost and may go back to central revenue. This is an opportunity for everybody who works to take advantage of the nine per cent compulsory payment. It can be put in one place where fees and charges do not fritter away or eat up their hard-won funds and salaries. So the simplicity, the ease with which small business is adopting it and the processes entered into by this government to simplify the process and make it easy should encourage everybody to be involved. I think it is a great move forward. I want to congratulate the government and the ministers involved for producing such an excellent scheme.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Bowen, Chris, MP
content: —I am pleased to be able to speak in support of Labor’s amendments to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005 but it gives me no pleasure to speak on a bill which involves such a substantial increase in paperwork and compliance burdens for small business. We have just heard a contribution from the honourable member for Mitchell, who said that it was a ‘simple’ process. Unfortunately, he simply showed how out of touch he is with small business. It beggars belief that the honourable member for Mitchell can say that a process is simple because it simply involves a two-page form. If it is such a simple two-page form, why does it require a 55-page explanatory document for employees and a 16-page explanatory document for employers? That does not sound very simple to me.This bill makes quite significant changes to the superannuation choice regime just one month before the new regime comes into force. One must really question the amount of planning that has gone into this when such significant changes are being made just one month before such a major change comes into law. There is one minor improvement in this bill, and I suspect we should be thankful for small mercies. This bill removes the obligation on employers already providing choice to employees from having to provide the standard choice of fund form to existing employees. It should not have been so complicated that such an amendment was necessary so late in this process. It should not have been so complicated that there would need to be changes to this paperwork nightmare. The fact that the government has had to bring into this House legislation which exempts those businesses already providing super choice to employees from providing the forms to existing employees shows how terribly complex this regime is, how terribly complex the paperwork is and what a burden it will be on people in the small business sector.Small business people tell me time and time again that the biggest issue facing them is compliance. In my electorate and other electorates the issue that gets raised again and again is compliance. For example, not one person who runs a small business has raised with me the need for unfair dismissal reform. However, people have raised with me time and time again the paperwork burden. But this bill and this regime make the paperwork burden so much worse for people in small business. On 3 May the shadow minister for small business, the honourable member for Watson, visited my electorate and we went together to the Filpure water filter shop in Fairfield and spoke to Alex Kariki, the proprietor. I am sure what he said about the changes would be echoed by many small business people throughout the nation. He said, ‘I thought the GST paperwork was too much but this is ridiculous.’ I certainly endorse that remark by Mr Kariki.From 1 July, small business will have to deal with a whole new compliance regime. Putting aside the penalties and ridiculous burdens placed on business people, just the paperwork alone—apart from the business activity statement and the other paperwork that small business people have to comply with—will prove significant. I always think it pays to go back and look at what the Liberal Party has said about these things in the past. In 1996 the then Leader of the Opposition and now the Prime Minister said:We are committed to reducing the red tape that small business has to grapple with by fifty per cent in our first term.There are many things that I could say about that statement—obviously it is a non-core commitment or a rock solid, rolled gold commitment—but I will simply say it is just another broken commitment. But there is an easy solution to this; it is not complex—simply exempt small business. Exempt small business from not only the two-page form, which the honourable member for Mitchell described as ‘simple’, but also the 16-page explanatory document for employers and the 55-page explanatory document for employees. This government finds it simple and easy to exempt small business from unfair dismissal legislation, so it has found a way to do that, but it finds it intolerably difficult to exempt small business from the paperwork nightmare that will accompany the introduction of superannuation choice. This brings me to a closely related matter, which is that of penalties.The intersection of the financial services reform regime and the changes that are encompassed in this bill means that an employer who innocently answers an employee’s question about which superannuation fund the employer might think the employee should sign up to is liable to fines and imprisonment. The government will no doubt say that will never happen and we are just scaremongering as it will never get that far. If it is not going to happen, remove the doubt: accept Labor’s amendments.COSBOA, the peak small business group in Australia, certainly agree with Labor that small business should be exempt from the draconian penalties contained in this regime. COSBOA are not traditionally seen as an organisation affiliated with the Australian Labor Party. They are not traditionally seen as a radical socialist organisation. They are seen as a mainstream organisation representing small business. But on 4 May 2005, COSBOA issued a press release which in part says:The Shadow Small Business Minister Mr Tony Burke is right when he calls for exemptions for small business.I am glad that the shadow minister has been able to join us in the chamber to hear the endorsement of his actions by COSBOA. Our only difference with COSBOA is that we say all employers should be exempt from these draconian and ridiculous penalties. There is a real inconsistency here. If this legislation is passed without Labor’s amendments, as I have said, an employer answering an innocent question from an employee about which fund the employer would recommend the employee enter into could find themselves liable for a fine of $22,000 and a two-year jail sentence. If that same employer gives his or her employee some advice about buying a property—if that same employee went to the employer and said, ‘Excuse me, boss, do you I think I should buy this property down here?’ and the employer said, ‘Yes, that’s a great investment, it’s going to have a great return over the next few years and I would strongly recommend that you buy it’—there is no penalty. Even if that employer has an interest in that property which they do not disclose to the employee there is no penalty. Under Australian law as it stands at the moment, there is absolutely nothing wrong with that.So an employer or any other individual can run a shonky property investment advice business, lead people astray, give them poor advice and take kickbacks, and there is no penalty. But in the legislation proposed by the government we have a situation where an employer who gives advice to somebody in their business—they might say: ‘Yes, I think that fund looks fine. I’ve been in that fund myself and I’ve always found them good’; it might be quite innocent advice—would potentially find themselves liable to a jail term and a $22,000 fine. The government says that that will not really happen, so it should support Labor’s amendments and remove the doubt.The government has allocated $88 million over the next five years to implement this policy. Most of that will go into compliance enforcement—forcing small business people who are already struggling with a compliance nightmare to comply with this extra paperwork burden. I was drawn to comments made today by Peter Switzer in the Australian. We heard a lot of quotes from the Australian Financial Review from the member for Mitchell, but the one thing he did not quote was in the Australian today. Peter Switzer is a very respected commentator on small business matters. This is what he said today:Let’s focus in on the madness that Super Choice has created …These are not my words or the member for Watson’s words but the words of an independent commentator in the Australian. Later in the article, he says:Well, if this employer fails to follow the Super Choice regulations he or she could be in a lot of trouble—unwittingly.And don’t even think about the workload if your eight—or however many—staff all start their own self-managed super fund. Experts warn that even one staff member going for this option will be an administrative nightmare.What is all this for? The member for Mitchell said: ‘This is great, because 10 per cent of people might want to choose their own super fund. We are going to send a paperwork nightmare to small business people who are already struggling in paperwork. We are going to threaten jail terms and fines so that 10 per cent of people can exercise a choice of super funds.’ If that 10 per cent of people could be accommodated without this massive burden on small business, we on this side of the chamber would have no problem with that. But this is a matter of balance. This government, which uses so much rhetoric about small business, is willing to impose on small business this paperwork burden—all for, as the member for Mitchell said, the 10 per cent of people wanting to exercise their choice.In this bill, the government is also saying it is the employer’s responsibility to be aware of the merger of super funds. If an employee is a member of a super fund which merges, it is the employer’s responsibility to notify the employee and make sure that the employee is aware of it and can change their arrangements. Again, if they do not comply with that, there are penalties. Wherever you look in this bill there are penalties for small business people struggling to do their bit in a difficult environment with compliance paperwork issues imposed on them not just by this government but also by state and local government. Some of it is justified and some of it is not, but the bottom line is that a small business person has to spend on average one day a week just on paperwork—not making sales, not going out and chasing leads, not training staff but doing paperwork. And that will only be worsened by this bill.This government likes to portray itself as a friend of small business. It goes on and on about unfair dismissal exemptions. We will be saying a lot more about that when the legislation comes before the House and about how this government could be reducing the compliance burden on small business in a much fairer and more effective way. That is not a matter for this debate, but we will certainly be arguing very strongly in coming months when the government again brings the legislation before the House. This government refuses to accept Labor’s amendments to this bill which support small business. I call on those Liberal members who parade around their electorates pretending to be the friends of small business to do one of two things. They like choice, so we will give them a choice. Choice No. 1 is to come into this House and vote with the Labor Party—vote for the amendments to support small business. I am not sure they are going to take that choice. I am not sure that many of them will show the courage we have seen from some of the members opposite.Over the last few days we have seen the member for Kooyong, the member for Pearce and the member for Cook show considerable courage. They and all members opposite could show some courage on this matter and vote with the Labor Party for the constituencies they parade around the country pretending to defend. Let them come in and do that. But, as I said, they get a choice. If they do not wish to do that there is choice No. 2, which is to come in here and explain their position. Look at the speakers list. There are three speakers from the government on this bill. Where are the members from Western Sydney who parade around as friends of small business? Let them come in and defend their position. Where is the member for Lindsay? Where is the member for Greenway? Let them come in. Where is the member for Macarthur?They go around the small businesses in Western Sydney and I bet they say—because we have heard this before—‘Small business has never had a better friend than the Howard government.’ They will say around this country, ‘The Howard government is the best friend of small business.’ They say it in the chamber and they will say it elsewhere because that apparently is the mantra that focus groups are promoting through the government. It is everybody’s best friend. It is like kindergarten—remember? You had so many best friends. The Howard government is everybody’s best friend. But let them come into this House and explain to small businesses in their electorates why they are voting for jail penalties, why they are voting for fines and why they are voting for increased paperwork burdens. It is not a choice they have to make. It is very easy. They could come into this House and vote for Labor’s amendments. We are making it easier for them. They have brought this bill in and provided us with an opportunity to again move this amendment. We are giving them a second chance. Come in and support small business. Defend small business. That is their rhetoric.They claim we are the party of the trade unions and everybody except small business. We are proving that we are the party that defends the battlers and those who are having difficulty with the compliance burden being placed on small business. We are the friends of small business in this House. This government is showing that it is not. Those individual members should come in here and justify their position—the honourable member for Greenway, the honourable member for Lindsay and the honourable member for Macarthur. Let them come in here and explain to their constituents and to their small business people why they are not voting for Labor’s amendments. Let these people who promote themselves around the countryside and around their electorates explain why they are not coming in here and supporting Labor’s amendments. Why are they not supporting the exemption of small business from this legislation and, just as importantly, why are they not supporting exemption for all businesses—small and big—from these ridiculous penalties and this ridiculous enforcement regime?I have not been here for as long as some honourable members, so I have not seen as much legislation go through, but this has got to take the cake. For the time I have been here this is probably the silliest piece of legislation I have seen. I have seen some silly legislation in this House and in other houses. This is the silliest. It takes the cake. Maybe the honourable ministers responsible, the Minister for Small Business and Tourism and the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, are having a little competition to see who can have the silliest legislation. This one is taking an early lead. We have 2½ years to go of this term so it may get pipped at the post as we go, but they are certainly making a strong start early in the term.Let me turn to some other aspects of this bill. I was surprised to hear the honourable member for Mitchell steal my thunder on this. He actually made the point that I was going to make—and all credit to the honourable member for Mitchell. He actually made a valid point about this. This bill provides for the abolition of the superannuation holding accounts, special accounts, which were put in place in 1995 to receive funds paid as part of the superannuation guarantee where those contributions cannot be paid into employees’ superannuation funds. This is particularly important for itinerant industries—fruit pickers and others who move around the countryside. There has been some growth in publicity for web sites which allow people who have left their employment without a forwarding address to go back and get the appropriate superannuation rolled over into their current fund, and I hope that more people do that. That is good for them and it is good for the economy. However, as the honourable member for Mitchell said, the SHASA pays no interest and does not charge any fees. The government says that SHASAs are no longer necessary because the retirement savings accounts offer similar low-cost benefits for employers.I say to the government, with respect, that the evidence is to the contrary, and the honourable member for Mitchell made this point. He might be voting with Labor on this item. I did not get the impression he was going to support the amendments protecting small business because he showed how out of touch he was with small business. He said the two-page form, which needs a 55-page explanatory memorandum, was very simple. It is particularly simple for the honourable member for Mitchell. I am glad he found it simple; I am not sure that the small businesses in his electorate will. The retirement savings accounts do charge fees. In the financial year 2003-04 the total expenses of retirement savings accounts were 2.3 per cent of assets under management. The average fees and expenses of superannuation funds for the same period were 1.3 per cent. The evidence is that the returns on RSAs are not as high as those for other superannuation funds. They are certainly not high enough to justify their fees.I do not mean to disparage retirement savings accounts. They are a legitimate choice for many people. However, I fail to see the logic of the government’s arguments. They say RSAs are a suitable replacement for the SHASAs, but the evidence is that they charge high fees and do not have comparable returns. The honourable member for Mitchell said he would like the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer to come in here and explain that. I endorse his request. I think he should hear the explanation for that because it does appear to defy all logic.Let me return to the central items of this bill. I commend Labor’s amendment, as moved by the honourable member for Hunter and supported by the honourable member for Watson—the two relevant shadow ministers. It is fair, it is sensible and it provides some relief for small business. I call on all honourable members to support it. This should not be a matter of politics; this should be a matter of supporting small business.Let those honourable members who go around talking to the papers and the chambers of commerce in Western Sydney, Parramatta, Blacktown, Penrith and Campbelltown and those Liberal Party members who hold small business functions—morning teas and fundraising dinners and no doubt fundraising lunches and breakfasts—come in and justify to those people why they are voting against Labor’s amendments. It is not too late. The speakers list is out and there are only three government speakers, but I am sure the Chief Government Whip would allow more speakers from the government to come in here and justify their position. I suspect that they will not because they find it hard to defend the indefensible, and that is unsurprising. They find it hard to come in here and say, ‘We are the party of small business and, by the way, we are voting for increased compliance costs and penalties which involve jail terms and which do not apply to shonks in the property industry but will apply to people running milk bars and other small businesses throughout suburbs in electorates in Western Sydney.’ I do not think they will do it and it will be to their eternal shame.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: Tollner, David, MP
content: —Many members will know that before coming to this place I had a career in the superannuation industry. I worked for a couple of years as an insurance and investment multiagent working for various banks, insurance and investment companies. Early in 1992 I moved to an industry super fund, the Australian Retirement Fund, where I continued to work until I was elected in the seat of Solomon.I have followed the superannuation choice of funds debate for several years now, and it surprises me that members opposite constantly refer to this legislation being an attack on industry superannuation funds. There are generally two types of funds around: there are public offer funds and those not for offer to the public such as public sector funds—which are exempted from this legislation—and corporate funds. Corporate funds will be the big losers in this legislation because they have no ability whatsoever to attract new members. They are the types of funds that are run by large companies that provide a superannuation account for their employees. They are only open to employees of the company or the entity that runs them. Because they cannot attract new members the only thing that can happen is for them to lose existing members.With public offer funds, we know that there are small self-managed funds, which are required to have fewer than five members, and they make up a miniscule part of the superannuation industry as a whole. However, the people who start those funds tend to be the higher earners, the high net worth people, because administratively they are very expensive. But they do allow greater flexibility in investment and retirement options for those people who take them out.The other funds are retail or commercial funds and the industry superannuation funds. I want to dwell for a little while on the fundamental differences between industry superannuation funds and retail or commercial funds. Industry funds are probably the only mutual superannuation funds that exist today. They are funds which are called ‘not for profit’. All profits go to account holders of that fund. Profits are not creamed off to pay the shareholders or to pay commission agents. Ultimately, the owners of the funds are the members of the funds. The design of these funds has a couple of interesting benefits. Because there are no shareholders or paid commission agents, those funds do not have the overheads that the commercial or retail funds do. The funds can manage to keep fees very low for members because they can access wholesale investment products in the investment market.It stands to reason that the bigger the industry fund the better it is going to be for the members. There are economies of scale with superannuation, as there are with most other things. To buy one egg costs you so much money; to buy a truckload of eggs reduces the unit price of each egg. The same principle works in investment markets, so the larger industry funds have tended to perform extremely well over recent years. The fund that I worked with has somewhere around half a million members and has performed exceedingly well. The fees are around $1 per week for members. The returns have been exceptionally good. For the last two years the fund has won the award for superannuation fund of the year.We have heard a bit tonight about compliance burdens. One of the biggest compliance burdens for superannuation funds, be they retail or industry funds, is the superannuation surcharge. That has massive compliance costs. In industry super funds—evidently the funds that our friends opposite recommend to people—a lot of their members are paying for those compliance costs throughout the whole fund. So I was quite surprised to hear earlier tonight that the Labor Party opposed the abolition of the superannuation surcharge, because ultimately the superannuation surcharge affects not just the high-income earners but members of all funds; they are all hit with meeting the compliance costs. As I said, the bigger the industry fund the better. Over recent years we have seen mergers of many funds because they have realised that either you get big or you get out. Small industry superannuation funds will not survive in the current climate.I find it interesting that members opposite, for the last few years, have seen choice of fund legislation as an attack on industry superannuation funds, when industry superannuation funds themselves are screaming for the introduction of choice of fund legislation. They can compete, they can compete very well and they can compete on their own terms. Industry funds have matured in the marketplace and they are ready to stand on their own feet without award compulsion. Award compulsion is how industry funds started. As you will know, Mr Deputy Speaker, in the late eighties, with the introduction of award superannuation, employers were forced to pay into their industry’s superannuation fund. Those funds quickly grew through the compulsion that employees had to be members of those funds, and they thrived as a result.The point of all of this is that the way the retail funds operate is quite different. Retail funds and commercial funds are set up primarily as a mechanism to pay dividends to shareholders of the entities that own those funds. The second priority, of course, is to provide a return to their members. Retail and commercial funds generally market themselves in the community by way of commissioned agents and financial advisors. So there are costs for those funds.You can weigh up the differences. The commercial funds have a very active army on the ground of advisors who willingly run out there to sell their product. If they want to sell more product, they merely have to increase the commissions on the policies they sell, whereas industry funds tend not to engage commissioned agents. The reason I mention this is that I was reading an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 28 May by Simon Hoyle, who was commenting on an industry fund’s advertising campaign:If you could increase your retirement savings by $76,000 simply by paying lower fees, you’d probably grab the opportunity with both hands. That’s exactly the reaction industry superannuation funds were hoping you’d have when you saw advertisements they were running, in print and on television, before the introduction of fund choice on July 1.But the funds’ plans are on hold, at least for the time being, after the Australian Securities and Investments Commission on Friday raised concerns about the content of the advertising. ASIC’s main concern is understood to centre on the ads’ comparisons of average fee levels for industry funds and retail master trusts. It’s believed the regulator thinks it might be misleading to project those fees over a long period.The article goes on to mention the regulator’s concerns:At the centre of the regulator’s concerns are the assumptions and calculations used to produce the numbers in the industry fund ads.The financial modelling was done by superannuation research and ratings firm SuperRatings. Jeff Bresnahan, the firm’s managing director, stands by the calculations. “We were asked to provide a series of comparisons, and we did so with a series of variables that we built into the models,” he says. Wherever possible, he says, SuperRatings used assumptions suggested by ASIC on its consumer website. “We have total control over the sourcing [of data] and modelling,” Bresnahan says. “We did work off a brief from IFS ... but I am quite confident that the results are fair and representative.”… … …An advertising campaign was seen as the only effective way for the funds to communicate with the public. They can’t rely on the distributors of financial products—mainly financial planners and investment advisers—to do the job.Commercial fund operators are not planning a marketing campaign to counter the industry funds’ message. But a commercial fund operator doesn’t need to advertise a fund to make it attract money; all it has to do is crank up the commission it pays or provide some other incentive to its distribution force.That says in a nutshell what the differences are between the industry funds and the commercial funds. I am not going to take sides and say one is better than the other, but clearly they are different. Clearly one offers better returns and lower fees; the other offers, I suppose, personal advice and support throughout the time you hold a policy with that particular entity. What concerns me is that ASIC have decided to intervene in this matter. I am concerned that, in a choice regime, they are not allowing adequate information to get out to the public to allow people to compare funds. They seem quite happy to allow financial advisors to go and talk to a multitude of Australians about how to make a choice, but they do not seem happy to allow that advice to be aired in a public advertising campaign.I intend to follow this through with ASIC and find out exactly what their concerns are. I would have thought that, if they had concerns, they would have had some modelling done. But evidently that is not the case. They are asking that the industry funds group putting this advertising campaign together to vindicate their figures.I would like to comment on a couple of points that were made by members opposite. Firstly, the member for Hunter seems to have some problem with the closing of the superannuation holding accounts reserve and the redirection of funds to RSAs that would normally go to SHAR. His concern was that RSAs are run by banks and, in some way or another, it is not good to let banks look after this money. I should inform the member for Hunter that it is not just banks that run RSAs. Credit unions and his friends at the industry superannuation funds also run RSAs. They are just as likely to pick up the funds that would have normally gone to SHAR and that will now go to banks, credit unions or industry superannuation funds. I cannot see the need to retain SHAR, considering we now have the lost members register. It is a lot easier to locate lost members; there are protocols between superannuation funds that have identified lost members and work is happening more and more to find lost members and ask them which fund they would like to be in.Another concern the member for Hunter had was to do with compliance costs for small business. Since it became an issue several years ago that the choice of fund regime would cause costs for small business, there have been a lot of technological developments that will obviously be the answer to the compliance costs for small business. Most small businesses that I am aware of these days have bookkeepers, accountants and access to computer technology. Those ones that do not are generally small employers of the micro size, where sending off one or two cheques a month is not going to make a great deal of difference to compliance costs.The member for Prospect seeks to exempt small business from the superannuation choice regime. He says it is because one person may want to get into a self-managed fund. I find that quite bizarre. Generally, as I say, there are not very many people in the work force in self-managed funds. They are generally high net worth people of considerable means who have a full understanding of how the choice system works and are fully capable of arranging their own affairs to make sure that an employer can contribute to their fund. I see no reason why employers with fewer than 20 employees should be denied the opportunity for their employees to make a choice.For a number of reasons, including some of those which I have just mentioned, I support the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005. I do not have a problem with funds getting in there and fighting it out for their members. I would like to see a level playing field. I would like to see ASIC get on the program, get out of the way and let the industry superannuation funds advertise their products fairly. But I see that industry super funds these days have matured greatly, certainly compared with the early days when I worked with them. They are ready to stand on their own two feet, not worry about award compulsion and compete in a free marketplace. I am more than happy to support this bill.
debateinfo: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 2005
Speaker: N/A

name: O’Connor, Brendan, MP
content: —I rise to make comment on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005, to reflect on the amendment that has been moved by the shadow minister and to inform the parliament of the concerns I have, and others share, in relation to this matter. There is no doubt in my mind that there has been a lot of ideological positioning by the government in relation to this matter. I do not accept for a moment that the government has considered the adverse effects that will flow from the enactment of this bill, not only to small businesses—and we have focused primarily this evening on the concerns they have about what will happen if this legislation, certainly in its present form, is enacted—but also to employees. I know many members, certainly on this side of the House, share a concern about the potential effects upon employees.It is a little rich to listen to members of the government seeking to lecture the Labor Party on superannuation. I really think it is a little rich for the government to attempt to put to members of the Australian Labor Party in this parliament a view that the government somehow have a great record on superannuation. The fact is that the coalition, when in opposition between 1983 and 1996, had to be forced kicking and screaming to the table to support the legislation in relation to super in that period. Indeed, there were circumstances in which they opposed the superannuation guarantee contribution that was enacted by the Hawke and Keating governments.We know which party and which governments have made the most significant contributions to the fundamental underpinning of super in this nation. It certainly has not been this government. In fact, in almost 10 years this government has done very little to improve upon the policy that was created over that 13 years Labor were in government. What we do know is that in 1996 the Treasurer introduced a surcharge—in reality a tax—on a significant number of employees, and it has taken almost nine years to abolish that tax. The Treasurer, on behalf of the government, managed to impose the tax and now he is abolishing the tax. I would suggest, and I am sure many would agree with me, that it is not really a great improvement to the super scheme of this nation to impose a tax and then remove the tax and effectively boast that you are doing something in relation to super.My personal view is that we should have moved on from the nine per cent superannuation guarantee contribution that is made by employers to employees in this country. If we were serious about national savings, we would have gone a lot further than the maintenance of the nine per cent and there would have been some building upon the efforts made by Labor governments between 1983 and 1996.I can recall how many workers were without any form of superannuation in the early 1980s, and certainly before that time. In fact when I sat at the kitchen table speaking to my dad and other family members, superannuation to us was a benefit to a certain group in society, not necessarily the average, ordinary workers—those who worked with their hands and worked in factories, those who worked in banks as tellers or those who worked as tradespeople. Those occupational groups rarely had any form of savings whatsoever. I am talking now about the 1970s and early 1980s. It was not until the Hawke government introduced some form of compulsory contribution that we started to see universal superannuation for employees in this nation. As I have said before, that was resisted by the coalition parties in opposition.So we do not really need a lecture from the government in relation to superannuation. What we do need, however, is a policy that makes it easier for those responsible for operating the schemes and, indeed, for those who will be affected by the schemes. What we have said this evening, and will say tomorrow as this debate continues, is that there has been a failure by this government to really understand the adverse impacts on the way in which employers, particularly small business employers, will be able to apply the provisions of this bill if enacted. So I would like to take the opportunity to touch upon some of the concerns that I have, and I know others share with me, in relation to this matter.Firstly, we know that the bill itself leaves open the possibility for employers to be liable for either a fine or, even worse, a jail sentence if they are placed in a position of providing advice unwittingly to an employee in relation to what super fund the employee wishes their contributions to be placed in. As I understand it, the view of government is that that is not a concern, is an unlikelihood and would not eventuate from the passing of this bill. But as the member for Prospect and others have said in this debate, we could remove all doubt by accepting the amendment moved earlier which would remove the penalty provisions of the FSR Act that provide for jail terms of up to two years and/or fines of $22,000 if employers give advice in good faith in the context of choice of superannuation fund implementation.That should be very easy to do. If there is any doubt, and if the government would like to see this bill passed with the support of the Labor Party, all it has to do is support the removal of the possibility of employers being penalised, either by fine or by jail. I cannot see why the government would not accede to that request and accept the amendments. They have been put in good faith and they should be accepted in good faith so as to remove all doubt in the minds of members in this place and, more importantly, in the minds of small business people who on 1 July will be confronted with an enormous amount of paperwork. As we know, it is a two-page form, but it has a 16-page guidebook. For the employee there is a two-page form and a 55-page guidebook. Those things are about to hit all the businesses in this country. What we can do tonight, if the government accedes to the proposition by Labor, is to remove all doubt that those penalties could apply.Further to that, Labor believe that we must exempt those small businesses that have fewer than 21 employees from the provisions of choice of superannuation fund. We do not believe that is a very difficult thing to do. We listen to the government day in, day out talk about their concerns for small business, yet they have failed to concern themselves with the compliance that will be precipitated by the enactment of this bill. The amount of paperwork and red tape that will apply as a result of this enactment is going to make it a lot more difficult for small businesses. Some will deal with it better than others. There is no doubt about that. For example, if the small business operator is lucky enough to have all of his or her employees wanting to join the same fund, there will be less of a problem in relation to the regulations required. Equally, if it is a medium-sized company there will be less regulation, or if they have on their books someone who looks after these arrangements and looks after the payroll and all of the administrative matters it may be a bit easier.But think for a moment of those very small businesses where the employer happens to do a range of things because they are too small to hire specialists. It will fall entirely on them to undertake these functions which are being thrust upon them by this government. Think of the concern that small businesses of maybe four or five people will have if this bill is passed. I listened earlier to the wisdom of the member for Solomon, and I have to say that I do not agree with him when he says that all of the small businesses that he knows of have accountants, bookkeepers and the like. That is clearly not true; it is clearly not the case. I think he should go back to Darwin and spend a bit of time walking through the streets, going into the shopping centres and talking to the small businesses in that city. He would find—and it should not take too long—that it is not the case that small businesses have specialists undertaking the administrative functions or the financial decisions for the employer.As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, the small business people in your own electorate, and indeed in mine, have to do a myriad of tasks. And this bill, if enacted—particularly if enacted without the amendments that has been proposed by Labor—will compound the problems already inflicted upon them. Let us remember—because I can assure you that the small business people have not forgotten—that it was this government that turned them into tax collectors. It was this government, when it introduced the GST and imposed that regressive consumption tax upon the nation, that created a responsibility on all of those small operators to become tax collectors, apart from everything else. This government has form in relation to adding compliance regulations and red tape, or whatever you want to call it, to small businesses. And they are doing it again. Labor is giving the government an opportunity to remove that level of compliance for at least those small operators with fewer than 21 employees. We ask the government to seriously consider it.With respect to employees, choice about superannuation is very significant. As you well know, superannuation is probably the biggest saving that ordinary workers will ever have. They may have their houses and some assets but effectively, near the end of their working lives, close to retirement, the biggest asset they have is their superannuation. Throughout the course of their working lives, decisions made about super are very important. Having said that, I do not think we can assume that the five million workers whom it has been asserted this bill will cover would necessarily be able to understand all of the regulations and requirements to make an informed choice about superannuation. So we on this side are concerned that too little information has been provided to employees on what would be, without exaggeration, one of the largest financial decisions of their lives—the choice of a superannuation fund. They will have to choose a superannuation fund in a climate where the white shoe brigade will be spending money on advertisements, selling their wares and attempting to convince employees that they have the best scheme. All the snake oil merchants will be out there, hoping to seduce employees into a particular scheme.Under all of that there will be very little transparency—because there does not seem to be enough prescription in relation to that—about entry fees, exit fees and fees to administer the funds. Employees will not have the wherewithal, the inclination or the information to understand exactly the decision to be made. But it is imposed upon them by this government to make a choice which may lead them to find themselves out of their current arrangements.In theory I have no problem with allowing employees to have choice but I do have concerns about the way in which this is structured. I actually printed from the web site, just this evening, the ‘Choice of superannuation fund standard choice form—information for employees’. I have a law degree. Hopefully I can understand this one-page document, but in looking at this document I am concerned that employees will be greatly confused about how to fill out this form. The form has a heading ‘Option 1’ and underneath that there is a line which says:You do not have to choose a fund.That is the title of option 1. You can imagine that many employees who do not have a great deal of knowledge about the types of superannuation funds available may say, ‘I guess I can choose option 1. That way I do not have to choose a fund. That way the status quo will remain because I am not making a choice as to a fund.’ I can assure you that many employees will assume that that will mean that the status quo will remain. But the status quo will not, or may not, remain. If the employer chooses as the default fund a super scheme other than the one that the employee is already under—that is, if the employer chooses a different superannuation scheme—and then the employee ticks option 1, that employee unwittingly will find himself or herself in a different super scheme.I can assure you that in the first paragraph of this supposedly simple form there is already a capacity for people to make a mistake. They will make that mistake by filling out the form under option 1 ‘You do not have to choose a fund,’ and they could find their retirement money, their savings, diverted to another fund. That is a real problem. You would not want to have any problems with your vision, but if you look closely at that first paragraph you can see a line that says:This may not be the same as your current fund.You would almost have to get out the magnifying glass to read the small print on the form. When employees are basically told, ‘You do not have to choose a fund,’ then I can assure you that they will assume that that choice will leave them with the status quo, when it will not leave them with the status quo—or it may not, if the employer changes the fund. Whether this bill is passed, with or without the amendments proposed by the Labor Party, it is very important that we get the paperwork right.This is already on the government’s web site. As I understand it, listening to the shadow minister in the MPI last week and again this evening, the government is not even putting out these sorts of forms anyway. But they are on the web site. If I am confused, I would say that many others may be confused. If the government is concerned about employees making an informed choice and a genuine choice then it should be ensuring that they do not consider option 1 as the status quo, because it may not be.Mr Deputy Speaker, you have to give the government some credit: they have managed to offend small business people and employees at the same time. Normally they go after employees. It is usual for them to go after workers; it is a sort of default mechanism of the government. We understand that. They hate workers. But when you see them go after small business people and employees at the same time, you have to take your hat off to them. They have managed to offend small business people in effectively imposing compliance, red tape and bureaucracy on the one hand, and on the other hand they are going to make it very difficult for employees. On that basis I ask the government to consider the amendments, otherwise we cannot support the bill. (Time expired)

name: Hayes, Chris, MP
content: —I rise today to speak in strong support of the amendment put forward by the opposition to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005. I cannot help but think what the small business owners and operators must be thinking about this bill. Here we are 30 days away from the introduction of superannuation choice for all employees, except for those who are ineligible, and the government is hurriedly trying to get through the finishing touches to this legislation—finishing touches, mind you, that have been foreshadowed since March but have only recently been introduced to the parliament.This is legislation that should have been completed long ago. It is a mess that we are in, but I am glad that this has occurred because it has given the opposition the opportunity once more to try to convince government to take some notice of the concerns of small business. It is another opportunity to point out the serious flaws in this superannuation choice plan. It is another opportunity for Labor to add a few of its own finishing touches to the scheme. It is another opportunity for the government to support the exemption of small business from the super choice plan.Whilst some may think that Labor’s campaign to exempt small business from super choice and to point out the flaws in the legislation is merely an attempt to differentiate itself from the government this is just not the case. The opposition is clearly concerned about the position of small business—a position that has been reflected through the electorate in the real and genuine concerns of small business owners and operators across the country. Let me take the opportunity to have a closer look at some of the concerns of small business owners and operators.Small business owners are concerned primarily with the compliance costs of the scheme and the associated penalties. First, let us consider the compliance costs. Although small businesses are used to filling out plenty of forms and paperwork for this government, it is surprising just how much time is spent in complying with these requirements. As I began to come to terms with the amount of paperwork involved with super choice, it was at that point that I realised that I was glad to have recently left my small business and entered this parliament.In order to work out exactly what small businesses are obliged to do under the scheme, small business owners have to go through a 16-page document entitled ‘Choice of superannuation funds—guide for employers’, which outlines what has to be done in order to meet their obligations. I can see what is going to go on. Despite the government’s generosity in investing more than $19 million in its super choice advertising campaign with its catchy theme song, most people would not have thought much about superannuation. Regrettably, it is a fact that most people probably do not spend much time thinking about superannuation. However, shortly they are going to have to, as this is what I imagine will be the likely scenario come 1 July.The night before superannuation choice forms must be provided, in many houses, in thousands of small businesses and home based businesses, you will hear the sounds of modems dialling. They are going to log on and get the form and they are going to have to print it off, because the ATO will not be providing all the necessary forms. They are going to download all the forms on superannuation choice on the web site—provided it does not crash. The next morning they are going to hand the standard form to their employees and tell them that this is the form they need to fill out for super choice. The employees are going to say, ‘Super what?’ This is where it is going to get tricky. Of course, having read the publicity available, small business owners know that they can only provide information to employees about what superannuation choice is, about their obligations as an employer and about how the employee nominates their fund. Words during this conversation will be chosen very carefully as small business owners know that if they say or do anything that may be considered as advice or a recommendation they could be faced with criminal sanctions of up to two years in jail and a $22,000 fine.We have all heard that in a few weeks time it is expected that some five million employees will be handed one of the super choice forms. It is a relatively straightforward document. It is two pages in length and gives an employee the opportunity to choose a super fund into which will go their employer’s contributions. Of course, if the employee wishes to investigate further and find out exactly what they are filling in, that straightforward two-page document comes with a very handy 55-page compendium which will give them more information on super to help them make the super choice decision. After receiving the form and getting the limited help that the boss is able to provide, the employee, form in hand, will still be as confused as ever as they walk away wondering what they are going to do next.Let’s face it: this is not a small decision. It is a very significant one. This is about saving for people’s retirement. Even the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer concedes that this is the second largest financial decision that people will have to make in their lives other than the purchase of their homes, and they cannot take advice from their bosses, no matter what their relationship with their employer is. Being a small business person myself and knowing many other people in a similar position, I have to say that we actually have a reasonably caring attitude to staff—at least in my case—and to think that small business operators would not be so disposed to help employees and to give advice if they are asked is just nonsensical.As I mentioned earlier, before I entered this place I was a small business person. I worked pretty hard in my business and I do share the concerns of other small business people. But, in my case, I had one employee. As I read about superannuation choice, I wonder what my position would have been come 1 July. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.Leave granted; debate adjourned.

name: Sercombe, Bob, MP
content: —Telstra is an extremely powerful organisation within our society. In fact, it is an organisation whose power continues to grow. By this I do not just mean that it is powerful in a corporate sense because of its size but powerful because of the sophisticated technology the organisation utilises, and this sophistication continues to grow through the convergence of technologies. To illustrate this point, I refer to yesterday’s Australian Financial Review, the lead story of which was ‘Telstra’s plan for internet TV revolution’. The story starts off:Telstra is negotiating partnerships with major commercial television networks and key Hollywood film studios as it ramps up revolutionary plans to deliver television, movies and interactive services over the internet.The story goes on ‘They encompass a range of offerings, including built-in personal video recorders’ and the capacity to offer ‘music video and audio streaming, home shopping, multi-media messaging services, educational content and wagering on sporting events’. Interestingly, within the Financial Review yesterday there was an editorial supporting the lead article that started off with the sentence, ‘Telstra’s ambitions know no bounds,’ and I think that is an accurate reflection of the increasing significance of Telstra in our society.The sort of technology that Telstra is increasingly the master of does have a capacity, if managed correctly, to increase the range and the diversity of opinion in our society and in fact increase the liberties in the society. But where these powers and these technologies are concentrated in a particular organisation—an organisation with some of the characteristics of a monopoly—it has quite the opposite effect. These are particularly significant when we are talking about an organisation that the government is hell-bent on privatising because that process removes the very significant constraints of public ownership that puts some limits on the organisation. This is an organisation which has significant problems in its culture, and particularly problems in its management systems.I think this is best illustrated when you look at the way the organisation treats its own staff. I had occasion in a debate in this place back in November 2003 to refer to allegations about Telstra misusing information stored in a database of a subsidiary company—a company called Integrated Public Number Database. More pertinently tonight, I raised the circumstances of Telstra abusing its technology and its role as a manager by invading the privacy of employees. I referred in that context to a Val Butler, and I referred particularly to a constituent of mine, Mr Peter Zabrdac. Mr Zabrdac, as I pointed out to the parliament in a subsequent contribution in June last year, alleged—and I believe with considerable accuracy—that Telstra utilised the software package called Ultra to improperly record telephone conversations he was having that were not connected at all with his workplace duties.I regret to advise the House tonight that I have evidence of another prima facie case of such inappropriate conduct. Ms Kim Sund, who is a constituent of mine, on 25 May emailed the privacy officer of Telstra in the following terms:… whilst conducting a regular one on one appraisal, my one up manager … advised me that my personal calls were being monitored and had been so over the last few months. This was specified by himself in a written document he composed detailing the discussion topics of the one on one meeting. In this document he stated: “None of these calls appear to be of an urgent nature, so I would encourage Kim to utilise her spare time in the afternoons to make these calls”.Time prevents me from going into further detail on this, but there are a variety of Telstra procedures and policies in place to handle this sort of matter and it appears on the face of it that Ms Sund’s calls have been inappropriately monitored by Telstra in defiance of both her own privacy rights and Telstra’s own management protocols. On the face of it, this is a significant abuse of Telstra’s technological power and it is a further example of how Telstra, given its current management culture, conducts itself. I believe this raises serious questions about the important liberties of the Australian public in a circumstance where important constraints on Telstra’s processes are being removed whilst privatisation occurs. (Time expired)

name: Vasta, Ross, MP
content: —Every Australian should be proud that we have one of the best health systems in the world. Medicare ensures that all Australians have access to free or low-cost health care. It is an honour to be a member of the government that has increased spending on health by more that 260 per cent, from $17 billion in 1996 to $45 billion in 2005.In recent years, the government has implemented the biggest improvements to Medicare since it was first created in the 1980s. We have invested $3.8 billion in the Strengthening Medicare package; $2 billion for the 100 per cent Medicare; and $500 million in Round the Clock Medicare. Thanks to these changes bulk-billing rates across the nation have increased from 66 per cent in December 2003 to 72 per cent in December 2004.Bulk-billing rates have also increased in my electorate of Bonner. The simple reason that we have been able to invest this extra money into our health system is because the government has managed the economy sensibly. These additional resources did not appear out of thin air. They are the result of a careful and deliberate policy to keep the budget in surplus and to repay government debt. It was not too long ago that government finances were in a very different state.When the Keating Government was voted out of office in 1996, the incoming Howard government inherited a $96 billion debt. To put this figure in perspective, it is worth noting that the interest payments on government debt at the time amounted to more money than we currently spend on state schools in a year. It is against this background that the coalition government quickly acted to make the tough decisions necessary to get the budget back in the black.One of the hardest decisions the government had to make was to close 43 low-volume Medicare offices across Australia. Four of the Medicare offices closed were in Brisbane, including the office in the bayside suburb of Wynnum. Media reports at the time indicated that the Wynnum Medicare office was being used by an average of only 45 people per day. While I understand that cutting back on government services is never popular, we should never forget that the decision to close down the old Wynnum Medicare office came as a direct consequence of Labor’s financial mismanagement. Fortunately, many things have changed since then. The sacrifices made in 1996 and 1997 have paid off, and we now have more money available to spend on improving government services in our community.The most important change since 1997 is that thousands of new families have moved into our local area and there is a new demand for government services, such as Medicare. Anyone who knows Brisbane’s bayside suburbs will tell you that they have experienced dramatic growth and renewal in recent years. Brisbane is at the centre of the fastest-growing region in Australia and the eastern and bayside suburbs have been growing at least 25 per cent faster than the remainder of Brisbane.At present, the nearest Medicare office is located eight kilometres from Wynnum in Carindale, and a growing demand for Medicare services means that people using this office are often faced with long queues. Last year, the government made the decision to open the Carindale Medicare office on Saturdays to cope with the high demand. With all of this growth occurring, it has become increasingly apparent that bayside residents need their Medicare office back as a matter of priority.As a result, I gave local residents my word that I would do everything possible to secure a new Medicare office for them. Since my election to the House of Representatives last year, I have kept my promise. I have used every trip to Canberra as another opportunity to lobby my parliamentary colleagues about this issue. With the help of the local community, more than 5,000 signatures were collected in support of my fight. I particularly want to acknowledge the editor of the Wynnum Herald newspaper, Mr Ron Goodman, for the vital role he played in mobilising community support for a new Medicare office.Today, I want the record to show my gratitude to the government for listening to the people of the Bonner electorate. Not only has the government listened—it has acted as well. (Time expired)
