name: Burke, Anna, MP
content: —Tonight I want to put on the record my thanks and appreciation to two wonderful women from my electorate—Elaine Ong from the Box Hill Veterinary Hospital and Dr Audrey De Jong. Both of these phenomenal women have recently been back to Sri Lanka on a couple of occasions to use their skills to help in the post-tsunami reconstruction. Dr Audrey De Jong wrote to me about her post-tsunami visit to Sri Lanka, and I would like to read from her letter tonight. The efforts to rebuild have not been completed, and we should not forget that there are still many people volunteering their time, their resources and their skills in these devastated areas. I think we should not leave them out of our thoughts for too long because the work still needs to go on. Audrey writes:I volunteered to be part of a second medical team that visited Sri Lanka in early February. The team consisted of Specialist Physicians, Surgeons, Psychiatrists, GP’s, a Nurse and a Surgical Trainee.My involvement was as a result of my brother Dr. Quintus De Zylva, a Specialist Physician, who had the first medical team in Sri Lanka just three days after the Tsunami struck to assess on going needs and render whatever assistance at that time. We took with us loads of medical equipment and supplies and medicines, all generously donated.After our arrival in Colombo the medical team headed south. Nothing prepared us for the scenes of devastation we encountered, it was shocking to see so much suffering and loss.In Galle my brother Dr. De Zylva set up a state of art Coronary Care Unit.I would like to put on the record my thanks for the generous donation from Philips Medical Systems who provided six beds. They also sent an engineer to personally set up the equipment and a supervisor trainee to assist the local doctors and nurses in how to use this state-of-the-art equipment. The letter continues:The Psychiatrist ran a teaching session in grief and trauma counselling as the suicide rate was increasing rapidly and the children were showing signs of anxiety and panic.The main hospital in Galle had been damaged and there were about 1200 babies a month being delivered there. A makeshift maternity ward was set up in the Outpatients Dept. ... and there was overcrowding, 3 patients to one bed and on the day I visited there was a baby weighing less than 1 kg who was born. There was no incubator available.We set up field clinics ... another 3 1/2 hours by road from Galle. We worked outdoors under a Banyan tree and worked in very hot and humid conditions. The message passed by word of mouth that there were Doctors arriving with medicines.On the first morning we saw over 200 patients and after a very short break for lunch, when we returned there were even more. Over the next few days I think we saw an entire village. We started at 8:00am and did not finish till 7:00pm. It was exhausting physically and emotionally but, we just had to keep going. We could not turn anyone away. We ran out of medicines on the first day and had to get another van load of supplies from Colombo the next day. We were the first Doctors that some of them had seen since the Tsunami and that was six weeks later.We treated injuries, infected wounds, saw lots of children, many orphaned, anaemia, malnutritioned, and chest infections and of course depression and sadness after all that they had been through. Just to be able to be there for them was so important but the task was enormous.Where to from here?We intend to keep the support going. Another medical team is being put together—they have already been and returned—and I am planning to go again.Having been there on the ground we are in a better position to advise on what is needed. I am also talking to a local group about our experience in Sri Lanka. People are still giving us donations and these donations are very important to continue the work we have started.Although I was exhausted I came away with a sense of peace and achievement and with some hope that the recovery/rehabilitation process has begun.Elaine Ong, who is a veterinarian, also travelled to Sri Lanka. She writes:After the 17 hour flights, it is another 10 hours by van to the South Eastern coastThe journey is long and hot. The roads are narrow and bumpy. There is no such thing as a luxury vehicle to rent unless you pay a fortune, so all the volunteers have to sit in an old van with no airconditioning and no seat beltsI wondered if I would arrive in 1 pieceHaving arrived at the refugee camp:We operate on 20-50 dogs /cats per day with 2-3 vets and 2-3 dogcatchersThey all receive a rabies vaccination, injections for parasites, antibiotics, flea/tick treatment and multivitamins. The stray animals are let go as there is nowhere to house themThe very ill or injured animals are euthanased humanelyThey also performed many desexing operations to ensure that the animal population would decrease. I do not think people thought about the plague that animals had actually been causing in the area. This is a country that prides itself on being humane to animals. They have trained two Sri Lankan vets and two dog catchers to keep the work going. Much of this work has been done by their own charity as many people did not think about it. I certainly want to thank them for their great work. (Time expired)

name: Secker, Patrick, MP
content: —I wish to raise a matter that would be of interest to the member for Wannon—not a name that we often hear, but we know he is present—regarding the Border Road. I will explain to the House what the Border Road proposal is all about. On the South Australian-Victorian border there is a surveyed road. Some of it is track, some of it has been sealed by the Wattle Range Council and some of it is unformed. But it is right smack in the middle of the vast pine and ever-growing blue gum plantations in both the electorate of Wannon and my electorate of Barker.There are enormous predictions of extra truck traffic that will transport forestry products, often to the port of Portland in Wannon. It is very important to both federal electorates and it is a state government responsibility. It is a very important road and I have been committed to it for four years because I can see the looming crisis that we would have with the roads in our district, especially in the areas around Mount Gambier, Penola and Naracoorte. At the moment we have the Riddoch Highway, which goes from Keith to Mount Gambier. It is largely a single-lane road with a couple of passing lanes. It is hardly coping with the traffic volumes now, but in the next four years it is predicted that traffic will close to triple when the blue gum forest production comes on line.So it is important that we plan for the future. Unfortunately, the state government has not made any commitment. I know the local state member for MacKillop has been committed for quite a while and I understand the member for Mount Gambier has finally come on board. But we certainly have not had any commitment from either the South Australian or Victorian state governments. This is rather strange. They brought the parliament down to Mount Gambier in the south-east, but they still have not twigged to the fact that probably the biggest issue in the area is planning for road infrastructure.I note in its budget last week the state government announced a paltry $22 million for road infrastructure for all of the rural areas in South Australia. You might compare that with the $200 million or so that the Commonwealth government gives directly to local government for roads. We also found $204 million under AusLink for the Sturt Highway redevelopment in my electorate, $15 million for Dukes Highway and some more for the electorate of Grey. So there have been considerable funds coming from the Commonwealth, but the state government, which is awash with money and seems to be city-centric, is prepared to provide $20 million or so for a tramline in the middle of Adelaide that will go about one kilometre and an extra $80 million for an opening bridge at the port because of a foolish promise made by the Deputy Premier for a bridge that only opens twice a day. Meanwhile, the Border Road is on a major freight route. You can see what the concerns of the Labor government are in South Australia. It is really a very city-centric government.In 2001, the privately owned Auspine company commissioned a study of the cost-benefit ratio of the proposed Border Road project using their own transport data and blue gum harvest estimates. This study did not take into account the other benefits to industry in the south-east and Victoria; nor did it take into account the less tangible benefits, such as reduction of noise, vibration and intimidation by trucks passing through Mount Gambier, Penola, Nelson and Coonawarra and so on, or the improved conditions for tourists. It did not take into account the fact that the Border Road would reduce heavy vehicle traffic, in particular trucks transporting timber on the Riddoch Highway, making it a much less stressful road. name: Jenkins, Harry, MP
content: —Seventy years ago, James Henry Scullin, the fourth Labor Prime Minister of Australia during the period 1929 to 1932, wrote:Justice and humanity demand interference whenever the weak are being crushed by the strong.In the year 2005 this remains true, and in no area of public policy at the moment does it ring more true than industrial relations, given the way in which the Howard government is looking to put through wholesale changes to the way in which industrial relations is being carried out in this nation. It can be said that the reforms that are suggested by the Howard government have their basis back when the Prime Minister was Treasurer or even further back to when he first arrived in this place. But saying that does not acknowledge the great changes that have been made in industrial relations over that 30-year period. It flies in the face of considering the contribution made by the efforts of Australian workers and trade unions to the way in which Australia has progressed as a nation.Often we hear the trite saying of the Prime Minister that he is ‘the worker’s greatest friend’. He rolls out statistics about wages and compares them to the period of the Hawke and Keating years but he does so without acknowledging the way in which Australia operated in a cooperative manner. Not only employees and employers but also government were part of a tripartite approach which enabled Australia to progress and reform the way in which the economy was structured. The government sat down at the same table as representative organisations of employers and representative organisations of employees. The accord not only achieved great changes that the government was able to implement but also ensured, through its social wage aspects, that Australian workers got protection way beyond simply what money they got in their pockets.Tonight the House has been discussing a number of pieces of legislation to do with superannuation, and it went forward without the other side actually acknowledging the advances that were made in superannuation, such as the expansion of superannuation to all through the superannuation guarantee that ensures that all employees have access to superannuation. These were achieved through the cooperative efforts of the government and employees through their organised trade unions. It is simply irrelevant to suggest in a debate about industrial relations in the year 2005 that the government has an ideological bent about collective action on behalf of workers. This is a point that I have visited before and will continue to revisit. Those opposite seem to have a penchant for denying the ability of workers to come together as a collective, go forward as a collective and achieve as a collective. That is the basis for and the way in which Australia’s industrial relations has progressed in the past. Denying an employee’s access to organise collectively through a trade union and, by doing that, failing to ensure that there are decent minimum wages and conditions, and denying individuals proper rights in the workplace—these are the things that this House must put its mind to and discuss as we go forward on the pieces of legislation.I see one of the government whips, the honourable member for Corangamite, in this place. The third member for Corangamite was James Henry Scullin and of course Mr McArthur is the 11th member for Corangamite and the longest-serving one. He and I have distinct differences over the way in which industrial relations should be carried out. I hope that one of them is not on the basis that the present member for Corangamite does not believe that ‘justice and humanity demand interference whenever the weak are being crushed by the strong’. In my last comment tonight I want to say to the honourable member for Corangamite that the market is going to Epping because on this basis elected officials of the Labor persuasion saw that they needed to be involved in agitating on people’s behalf because the western solution that he so championed had the support of the millionaire backers and it was on this occasion that the weak banded—(Time expired)

name: May, Margaret, MP
content: —I want to pay tribute tonight to the surf-lifesaving movement and the impact it has had on my electorate since the beginning of the 20th century. At this time of the year many of my surf-lifesaving clubs hold their annual presentation evenings at which they recognise the dedication and commitment of young men and women to protecting our beaches during the summer months. It may not be well known that at the beginning of the 20th century bathing during daylight hours was considered indecent. How life has changed since those early years. I am told that residents flouted the law, forcing it to be changed so that residents could enjoy our beautiful beaches particularly during those hot summer months. A change in the law meant the now very popular recreational and sporting pastime of surfing began to grow into what it is today: part of the Australian way of life, a way of life that is enjoyed by thousands of visitors every year to our country and a way of life that is enjoyed by both young and old. Seaside holidays were family favourites and the Gold Coast was one of the most popular destinations for a seaside holiday.As surf-lifesaving grew rapidly in popularity, its dangers rapidly became apparent. The sea is unforgiving of those who are inexperienced in water. It is dangerous for those who cannot swim. There was concern by experienced and regular surfers about the rising incidence of drownings in the surf. More experienced surfers began to form themselves into lifesaving bodies to assist those who were required to be rescued from an unfamiliar environment, and so the lifesaving movement began. Surf-lifesaving in Queensland began at Coolangatta Beach, in the electorate of McPherson, on 21 February 1909. From these very humble beginnings of a fragmented voluntary surf rescue service, Surf Life Saving Australia has now achieved world recognition for the outstanding courage and service of its members. At present in Australia there are 285 clubs with over 100,000 members who protect the bathing public around the beautiful Australian coastline. In Queensland there are 59 clubs with in excess of 23,000 members. In my own electorate I have 11 surf-lifesaving clubs. Each of these clubs has its own history. Many of them have been operational for years.Tonight I want to pay tribute to the Tallebudgera Surf Life Saving Club. The club is located adjacent to the Tallebudgera Recreation Camp and approximately 500 metres south of the entrance to Tallebudgera Creek. The Tallebudgera Surf Life Saving Club was formed in 1946 by a group of ambitious young men who had no former training or experience of surf clubs or surf rescue. There was no gear whatsoever. Initially, a reel and line brought down from the Palm Beach club was used to train the first squad. Later, a reel on loan from the state centre enabled the club to mount its first patrols.From these humble beginnings grew a mighty club which is now steeped in history and has gone from strength to strength delivering rescue services to the Tallebudgera Beach area. There have been many people involved in the success of this club—a club of volunteers does not prosper, grow and serve the community without the dedication and commitment of many people. The history of the club is about individual achievements and collective achievements; the success of the club is about the collective skill, hard work and dedication of all concerned over many years. A club of any sort is neither more nor less than a group of people. More than 1,000 members have been connected with the Tallebudgera Surf Life Saving Club over the past 50 years. In addition to those members there are also members of the various committees, juniors groups and supporters clubs.The recent annual awards at the club presentation night were a celebration of volunteers giving to their community. It was a celebration to acknowledge those in the club who had given that bit extra. It was about recognising a new life member, Bob Maskell. It was about recognising Ian Hamilton, Chris Gregory, Emma McAuliffe and life saver of the year Erin Harmer. There were many others—special helpers Ron and Ursula, best junior Tenille and many others. There is not time tonight to name them all, but to each of the winners go my sincere best wishes for the contribution you have made to your club and your community over the last 12 months.Surf Life Saving Australia is primarily a volunteer organisation. Surf-lifesavers are rostered on beach patrol duty by their clubs, and they complete these patrols in their own time and for no pay. From its earliest days, the association’s motto ‘Vigilance and service’ has not changed. The role of surf-lifesavers is to watch over and care for the people who use the ocean beaches. To that end, the record speaks for itself—almost 500,000 lives have been saved. We all need to continue to see the red and yellow flag and our surf-lifesavers remaining on our beaches during the summer months for many years to come.Question agreed to.

name: Ellis, Annette, MP
content: —I rise today to speak on the government’s failure, as I see it, to protect some of nature’s most graceful and magnificent creatures: the humpback and minke whales. These wonderful gentle giants of the sea, renowned for their long oceanic treks around the world, their unique communal hunting, communications and social activities, are still unforgivably being hunted and killed. But, what is worse, they are being killed and slaughtered in Australian territorial waters.Many people today may be thinking to themselves, ‘Hang on. Surely we banned that sort of thing ages ago.’ And they would be right in thinking that. Whaling was officially banned in Australian waters in 1981 when the Whale Protection Act 1980 came into effect. This was back in time when Australia was one of the leaders in the international efforts to protect whales. Australia also played a key role in the declaration of the Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary in 1994. Under Australia’s Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, it is made very clear that killing whales in the Australian Antarctic Territory is illegal. Whales in Australian waters are protected by Australian law and it is time the government enforced its own legislation. The Prime Minister’s 2001 election policy on whales stated:The government has strengthened domestic legislation protecting Australia’s whale and dolphin species. Under the EPBC Act, Australia’s entire Exclusive Economic Zone has been formally declared the Australian Whale Sanctuary. This offers unprecedented protection for all [whales and dolphins].Since 1994, the Australian Antarctic Territory has been part of our exclusive economic zone. However, since 2000 Japanese factory ships have slaughtered over 400 whales within Australia’s waters as part of Japan’s notorious ‘scientific’ whaling program. Australia has a proud history on environmental issues such as preventing the slaughter of whales. Given this proud record, current moves by Japan to increase its killing of whales should be strongly opposed. Unfortunately, the values of those progressive and enlightened governments of the past do not seem to be reflected by the federal government today.I would like to congratulate, however, the state and territory governments who have joined with the federal opposition in condemning the Howard government for its failure to effectively oppose the proposed slaughter of humpback whales and the proposed increase in the slaughter of minke whales. In its recent communique, signed by every single state and territory government and by the federal opposition, demands were made of the federal government in this regard.I also draw attention to the fact that I have launched a petition within my electorate which is being picked up very quickly by my community, who are going to add their voice to mine here today, calling for the stopping of this action—the slaughtering of minke and humpback whales—by Japan, and by any others for that matter. I call on government members to join us in putting all the pressure we can on Japan to ensure that this terrible slaughter is not allowed to occur.
Speaker: N/A

name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration
content: —In this week, when we are thinking about reconciliation—the ongoing business of bringing our various races in Australia towards a better understanding of each other’s history—I thought it would be useful to remind ourselves of how far we have come.I want to refer to a document that is in a book that I had published in the 1970s called Aborigines in White Australia. It is a documentary history of the attitudes affecting official policy and the Australian Aborigines between 1697 and 1973. This is a quote from the Hansard of the progress report of the Royal Commission on the Aborigines, in July 1913. It comes from the South Australian parliamentary papers. The chairman, the Hon. J Jelly, asks Mr EC Stirling what he feels should be brought to the attention of the royal commission review. Mr Stirling, an expert in Indigenous affairs at the time, stated:I would like to refer to the half-caste children. My opinion is that the more of those half-caste children you can get away from their parents and place under the care of the State the better. I think you should take them at an early age. Supposing they were taken charge of by the State Children’s Department it would be easier to deal with them if they were taken when they have the attractiveness of infancy. There is always something attractive in the infants of all races, whatever be the color. You would get people to take those children young who might be disinclined to take them when they were older. I think that it is the best way to save the half-caste children—take them away from their surroundings. When they are caught young they are far less inclined to revert to their old state. There is a strong tendency among the half-castes when they have grown up to go back to the ways of the natives. They are far less likely to do that after they have had a long contact with civilization.The Hon. J Jelly asks:What would be a suitable age to remove them?Mr Stirling answered:I think when they are about 2 or 3 years of age.The question was asked:You would not recommend that they be taken away when they are absolute infants?Answer from Mr Stirling:No; because then you would have the burden of them that all children are at such a young age. When they are a couple of years of age they do not require so much attention and they are young enough to be attractive.Question from Hon. J Jelly:Do you think that their experience of two years with the black mother would seriously interfere with them?Answer from Mr Stirling:No. There would not be time for them to establish habits and customs. I am quite aware that you are depriving the mothers of their children, and the mothers are very fond of their children; but I think it must be the rising generation who have to be considered. They are people who are going to live on.We have come a long way since 1913. Thank goodness! I commend our government for the work it is doing in making better the lives of all our Indigenous fellow citizens, especially the stolen generations. I commend our Prime Minister’s recent statement to the nation giving our government’s support for all things that will help, both symbolically and materially, in our progress towards walking together in the next century.

name: Lawrence, Dr Carmen, MP
content: —I want to argue today in favour of a royal commission into the unarguably unlawful detention of Cornelia Rau and the treatment that she received while in detention. I have spoken to a lawyer representing Cornelia Rau and I am aware of work by the University of Newcastle Legal Centre.There are clear problems with the Palmer inquiry. It is no reflection on his integrity, simply a question of the process. Unlike a judicial proceeding, you cannot test the evidence. We do not know what evidence has been provided to Mr Palmer, so lawyers cannot ask questions about it, challenge the claims, collect relevant dissenting opinions and so on. One of the lawyers at least has had experience in dealing with DIMIA—the recent case in the South Australian Supreme Court is illustrative. Only after systematic questioning and independent psychiatric evidence did a clear picture emerge of the treatment of two detainees in Baxter.Rau’s lawyer has also been refused funding to enable independent psychiatric assessment or to pursue the questioning of witnesses—mainly detainees who are reluctant to give evidence to Mr Palmer for fear there may be retribution in their cases. The University of Newcastle Legal Centre, acting on behalf of the family, have also raised serious questions about the adequacy of the Palmer inquiry. Limited powers and narrow terms of reference might not allow the identification of systemic failures and those who are responsible for them—it is about what happened, and not why. As I mentioned, there is no protection for detainees alleging potential criminal misconduct. Two such people approached me while I was at Baxter and I have passed that information on to Mr Palmer. But, again, those people are not available for direct testimony. It appears from the terms of reference that the Palmer inquiry will not address questions of the lawfulness of Rau’s detention and may fail to look at the question of her treatment and the provision of adequate care. In my view anyone who is in the sick culture that now pervades DIMIA is unlikely to get adequate care.Palmer is already reported as recommending an open inquiry with judicial powers, after some 200 more cases have been dumped in his lap. He suggests that the Ombudsman might be an appropriate person to conduct that inquiry. I want to argue today, very briefly, against that proposition, based on my own experience with the Ombudsman’s inquiry into the December 2003 disturbances in Port Hedland. At my request the Ombudsman undertook inquiries. DIMIA appointed Keith Hamburger to conduct an internal investigation. The Ombudsman determined that it was ‘professional and independent’. He wrote to me outlining briefly 67 findings and 37 recommendations. The key ones would have prevented what has just happened in Baxter if they had ever been made public and acted upon. He reassured me that the inappropriate detention of people in management support units and their inadequate care would be the subject of change by the department.I have never been able to get a copy of that report under FOI. It remains languishing somewhere on someone’s desk in DIMIA. More than a year ago this material would have been available to the department and in the public arena and I believe would have prevented what has happened to Cornelia Rau and others. We need a full, public, open inquiry, with proper testing of the evidence, and with commitments from the department to systemic change, which is clearly the problem in this case. No more pussyfooting around. (Time expired)

name: Gambaro, Teresa, MP
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence
content: —I would like to congratulate Craigslea State High School, one of the fine schools in my electorate, and to mention Kaye Gardner. Craigslea State High School has been chosen as one of 61 Australian schools to trial the federal government’s Family-School Partnerships Framework. Funding from this excellent package will enable the Craigslea State High School to implement and evaluate innovative ways of building strong partnerships between the school and the parents of the attending students. I think everyone in this place would agree that families have a major impact on the upbringing of their children and their achievements and that when schools and parents work in partnership the children perform better, stay in school longer, and enjoy their scholastic days much more. I want to congratulate all the stakeholders who have worked together to draft the structure for the Family-School Partnerships Framework. These include the Australian Council of State School Organisations, the Australian Parents Council and all the staff and students who participated in the program.I would like to take a moment to congratulate the Craigslea State High School on their very proactive approach to improving the standard and amenity of their school canteen. I understand that the P&C association and staff are working through a plan that will not only modernise the facility to the new standards that the community desires in the range of nutritional food available but also, quite innovatively, change the canteen from a place ‘where food is’ into a cafeteria that has the potential to become the social hub of the school and to have a positive impact on the whole tone of the school and school life.As well as achieving the desired result of a much more nutritious and innovative menu for students, it is envisaged that this modernisation will make the new cafeteria a far more attractive place in which parents will be delighted to volunteer to participate and, again, strengthen links between the school and parent communities. It is also pleasing to note that students are being actively encouraged to be part of this upgrade and that the P&C are strongly motivated in their support of this particular project.The two programs that I have just mentioned are the types of progressive development in education that I know members in this place strive to achieve for all of the schools in their electorates. I want to particularly thank all of the school community—the parents and all of the students at Craigslea State High School. I know that they are going to be the beneficiaries of a terrific canteen, or tuckshop, when it is finished. I thank them for their wonderful achievements to date and congratulate them once again.

name: Hayes, Chris, MP
content: —Child care is a significant issue in our community, an issue of concern to families and an issue that impacts on workplaces. Not unsurprisingly, it is an issue that constituents of my electorate of Werriwa are also concerned about. I bring this issue to the attention of members not simply to pass comment on the government’s child-care policies but to draw the attention of members to the case of the Bambi Kindergarten in Ingleburn. Bambi Kindergarten is a not-for-profit preschool run by the community and established in 1952. It is currently facing eviction because the land on which it stands has been allocated by the Department of Defence to the new Edmondson Park development. The Bambi Kindergarten was established by the wives of soldiers serving in Korea. It acted as a support centre for families as well as an early childhood education centre.Edmondson Park development is not new and I do not stand here today objecting to it. I object to the actions taken by the Department of Defence, in being unwilling to secure some land within the development to retain this facility. I toured the facility in my by-election campaign and was informed by the kindergarten that on several occasions they had been provided with verbal assurances that the land would be secure and the lease renewed.Sadly, this facility is far from secure as the department has backed away from these assurances. Bambi Kindergarten has recently been offered a further, but final, annual lease. Needless to say, this news was received poorly. It left the management, staff and current users of the facility, as well as the community, generally questioning this government’s commitment to the provision of child care. Through the shadow minister for defence and homeland security, the Minister for Defence has been approached to consider options such as gifting the land and allowing the kindergarten to remain or assisting the kindergarten to secure alternative accommodation. To date, I have yet to receive a response from the minister.This kindergarten has a unique historical association with Australia’s defence community. I encourage the minister to intervene to make sure that it can continue to provide high-quality child-care services to the people of Prestons, Horningsea Park, Macquarie Links, Ingleburn and of course Edmondson Park. Child-care places are scarce enough. Why exacerbate the situation by closing down a facility with 200 child-care places per week, a facility that provides affordable child-care services and that has served the community for well over 50 years?

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
content: —The temperature today on the Sunshine Coast is 23 degrees. The sun is out and there is no breeze to speak of. I am describing the last day of autumn on Queensland’s Sunshine Coast, an area I am privileged to represent in the Australian parliament. On the Sunshine Coast today some people have even managed to take a swim at one of our beaches.
Speaker: N/A

name: Adams, Dick, MP
content: —Tasmanians!
Speaker: N/A

name: Slipper, Peter, MP
content: —It would not happen in Tasmania, my friend. My electorate of Fisher includes most of Maroochy shire and the city of Caloundra, both of which will benefit from an influx of visitors when winter takes hold of the southern states and their cold well and truly sets in.The weather is just one of the many reasons that so many people from interstate gravitate to the holiday mecca that is the Sunshine Coast. Winter on the coast is characterised by cool nights and warm days. However, even at 23 degrees today, the weather bureau, I am told, says winter appears to have come early to the Sunshine Coast this year: the average temperatures over recent days are lower than we would normally expect. But it does not change the daily movements of the local surfers, who are also enjoying the mild weather. The water may be a bit nippy but I imagine it is much more pleasant than conditions in the southern states.Visitors have a range of options as to what they can enjoy when they visit the coast. For some, it is a leisurely stroll along one of the beaches; for others, it is enjoying the outdoor dining at Mooloolaba. Some, of course, are content to simply enjoy time out, relaxing in the sun.It is easy to gloat when you come from such a beautiful part of the world as the Sunshine Coast. Not only are the water and weather pleasant but so are the people. Visit the coast and you will be greeted by many a happy smile. It is a good lifestyle on the Sunshine Coast, without the traffic snarls of the major cities and without the lengthy travel times to get to the places you want to go.The attributes of the coast are what help to attract a thousand new residents to Queensland each week. The population of the south-east corner of the state is 2.6 million and expected to grow to 3.7 million by 2020. On the Sunshine Coast we would expect our population to double over the next 10 to 15 years, as people move from the rustbelt areas of southern Australia to what is undoubtedly the best part of the country to live. I do not blame people for moving to the Sunshine Coast; the good things on the Sunshine Coast are hard to resist. I hear the forecast tomorrow is for yet another sunny day and 22 degrees. My friends opposite, eat your hearts out.
Speaker: N/A

name: Adams, Dick, MP
content: —I want to take this opportunity to put on the record my complete support for two towns in my electorate—Zeehan and Queenstown. Some chardonnay-swilling, towny journalist from a publication by the name of Australian Traveller has had the audacity to say that Zeehan and Queenstown are ugly and are ‘must-flee holiday destinations’. This denigration of these two important Tasmanian working towns is not only stupid, even in fun, but plainly not true.All the west coast towns are mining towns, steeped in an incredible history which you have to know and touch. That history can be seen in the curious moonscape hills of Queenstown, in the architecture of the old part of Zeehan and the southern part of Queenstown, and in the opera house and the museums of both towns. This area is a photographer’s dream. Many tourists I have met who may have come for a day end up staying for three or four because there is so much to do and see, if you like your history real and still being formed. You cannot argue with the fact that Dame Nellie Melba sang in the Zeehan opera house; that our own Tasmanian princess, Mary, took her new husband, Prince Frederik, there; and that Princess Anne has also been a visitor. They thought Zeehan was well worth a visit. Neither town has masses of expensive restaurants, shopping malls or trendy coffee shops, but that is immaterial to the real traveller, the one who wants to know what a country is made of, how it became what it is today.The west coast is a region made up of a number of small towns, all with different functions, and set among some of the finest wilderness in the world. It is sold as a whole experience. The west coast produces the wealth of Tasmania in all sorts of ways, and one of those is tourism. Others are mining, forestry and fishing. So if you want a real experience, forget those seagull critics, take a trip to Zeehan and marvel at the conditions people lived in only 100 years ago. Follow the coast down to Strahan and then hop onto our beautiful Abt railway up to Queenstown, where the local people will give you a warm west coast welcome. Western Tasmania is wild, wet, rugged and quite beautiful—all of it. There is no experience like it. Miss it at your peril!
Speaker: N/A

name: Lindsay, Peter, MP
content: —I could not fail but be associated with the member for Lyons and his comments, and I agree with him entirely. I would like to raise the matter of wearing of unofficial, purchased or commemorative medals on the left breast. Following the 2005 Anzac Day ceremonies it was brought to my attention that several personnel were wearing bought, unofficial medals together with their official medals on their left breast. I know that many veterans have also approached the President of the Townsville branch of the RSL, Rod McLeod, about this concerning matter.Australia’s honours and awards system has been recognised throughout the world as being beyond reproach. Medals have never been awarded without detailed justification. Indeed, the recently amended Defence Legislation Amendment Bill increased penalties awarded for personnel wearing official medals to which they have no entitlement. However, there has been no corresponding legislation to preclude anyone—veteran or nonveteran—from buying any number of unofficial medals and wearing these on their left breast, either with or without official medals.To the general public these people appear to be veterans who have rendered invaluable service to our nation. In reality, they are denigrating the real official medals worn with justifiable pride by veterans. Many of these official medals have been awarded for active service which has involved, sadly, loss of life or which has seen personnel wounded physically or psychologically. If we do not do something to preclude the wearing of these unofficial medals on the left breast, our highly regarded honours and awards system will become a sham.I am aware that a succession of ministers has indeed examined this particular issue and, unfortunately, the gobbledegook that comes back from the department has to be seen to be believed. You get words like this:... the Directorate of Honours and Awards has sought and received some legal advice on this complex issue. However, further detailed advice is required before options can be formulated to address this issue and determine a way forward. The Directorate of Honours and Awards has sought further legal advice and a response is awaited ...Too right—a response is awaited.

name: George, Jennie, MP
content: —I have been contacted by the Illawarra Legal Centre over the last couple of days concerning the possible closure of the New South Wales Working Women’s Centre and I have been requested to pursue the matter here in parliament. It appears that the centre is faced with somewhat of a funding crisis. Originally the grant to establish the centre was in the order of almost $300,000, which has reduced to $240,000 in the last budget—a decrease in real terms of up to 37 per cent. When the financial problems began to emerge, the funding from the federal government, originally instituted by a federal Labor government, was added to by a $100,000 contribution by the state government. The centre looks as if it might have to close its doors because the demand for its services is outstripping the financial capacity of the organisation to remain viable.I have a particular interest in these centres because, as I indicated, they were first established by a federal Labor government and the purpose of their creation was to provide information, advice and assistance on work related issues for women, particularly women who may not have been members of a trade union and women who were not able to access legal services through payment for those services. Originally they were established in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. On all accounts these working women’s centres have performed well and provided a very valuable service.The linchpin of the centre in New South Wales is its telephone advisory service, which provides confidential support, information, advice and assistance to women who ring. I am told by the centre that the issues of common concern relate to unfair dismissal, discrimination on the basis of pregnancy and caring responsibilities. The demands for the services of working women’s centres are growing the more the labour market is deregulated.It would be a great tragedy if the New South Wales centre is forced to close. It is the only specialist community legal centre in New South Wales for employment related advice and representation for women. In its 10 years of service to working women it has developed a particular expertise in the interface between employment and discrimination law.I believe the government should urgently address the funding problems that beset this centre and that extra funding should be provided to ensure that the New South Wales centre remains open, accessible and viable and continues to provide support to women at work, many of whom as we know are now part-time and casual workers who are desperately in need of such assistance. (Time expired)

name: Haase, Barry, MP
content: —I rise this afternoon to bring to the attention of the House a dreadful and unworkable situation that we have in the Kimberley region, and to a lesser degree in the Gascoyne region of Western Australia—that is, the shortage of produce pickers. It is something that is being experienced right across the horticultural areas of Australia and we are not finding the solution that we need. Sure, there have been a couple of programs introduced such as the working holidaymaker program, under which we have reciprocal arrangements with a number of countries throughout the world, including the United Kingdom, Canada, the Netherlands, Japan, the Republic of Ireland, the Republic of Korea, Malta, Germany, Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Hong Kong, Finland, Cyprus, France, Italy, Belgium, Taiwan and now Estonia. But with all those arrangements in place to allow students and working people between 18 and 30 to come to this country for 12 months—and, if they work in a seasonal activity in a regional area for three months, to apply for another 12 months—we still have not come anywhere near to solving the problem.My good folk in Kununurra, specifically the members of the Kimberley Primary Industries Association, have made investigations in Thailand. They have established that there is a large list of ready and willing workers to come to Australia from Thailand to contribute their efforts. However, I am not for a moment advocating that we permit an unfettered avalanche of unskilled employees to come to Australia. In this regard I am pleased that the minister has told me that a work and holiday program is being negotiated with Thailand and will see 100 unskilled workers allowed to come and work and holiday in Australia. That is a maximum of only 100.The prime problem in the Gascoyne region of Western Australia and in the Ord Valley at Kununurra is that they are a long way from the bright lights of south-east Australia. Almost 100 per cent of these workers would prefer to be in that south-east Australian region where they can flit a couple of hundred kilometres, get involved in some picking work and then qualify for another 12 months stay while always being on the fringe of those bright lights. What we need to do is come up with some solution that will see these people penetrate through to some distances from south-east Australia. My growers are prepared to foot the bill for some transport, accommodation et cetera if these workers will only come to the Ord Valley. The question is: how do we effectively communicate that? Even though we have some web sites in place today, it is not enough. We need a solution for agricultural workers. (Time expired)

name: Moylan, Judi, MP
content: —Firstly, I congratulate the Treasurer on another successful budget. It is his 10th budget and, if my memory serves me correctly, the eight in surplus. Good economic management does not happen by chance; it has to be planned for. The measures we take now will undoubtedly have a very major impact on the Australian people and the Australian economy in years to come. As the Treasurer has said, measures taken in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and cognate bills will prepare the country for the great demographic changes that are now taking place and anticipated to take place in the next decades. Those changes will undoubtedly reshape our communities over the next several decades. It is never an easy task to work through the many competing demands for funding and achieve a balanced budget in terms of both the bottom line and the competing interests. Like other developed countries, Australia has many challenges, and the added considerations of managing the finances over what is a very vast landscape with a relatively small population base are quite a challenge.The matter of clean water provision, for example, and maintaining a strong environment policy are both very big ticket items for the government, and the government is to be commended for the policies that it has worked through to date with local communities. One of the features of the government’s environment policy is that its detail is worked out with local communities, and local communities help to extend the value of the dollars spent on environmental work and remediation because of the numbers of volunteers who become involved in these projects. The government backs this commitment with a substantial injection of funding and has done so now over several budgets. On this occasion, some $200 million will go to conserve water and improve the state of local rivers and waterways. Once again, I am aware that in many electorates throughout Australia people are working voluntarily in these areas and extending the value of those dollars in their communities. Many dedicated people work in the electorate of Pearce, often on a voluntary basis, to improve the environment and conserve water.One again, the government’s commitment to working with local communities is an excellent one. I have seen evidence of that in many of my country towns. Having a large country electorate and a large geographical area to look after, I see the work that is done in country towns, and it is impressive. One of my country towns, Northam, for example, with a population of about 5,000 people, has won a number of awards for its ecohouse. The ecohouse shows and demonstrates to people how they can conserve energy and water. It is very popular. It has become quite a talking point in the town and a place where many tourists like to go. They can try first-hand and see first-hand how they can, with some simple measures, conserve energy and water in their own homes. The house that has been used as the ecohouse model in Northam, and partially funded by the federal government, is a very old house—I think these houses go back to about the 1950s—so it was quite a challenge for the local council and others helping with this project to find ways in which to conserve energy in an old structure.I would also like to mention the farmers in my electorate who rely on the health of their land for their ongoing living. Farmers know the value of conservation and in my area they work very hard to ensure sustainable agriculture. One of the issues they have been very concerned about over recent times is the eradication of weeds. We have a weed in many parts of the Pearce electorate called Paterson’s curse. It is a huge problem and it has spread alarmingly throughout the electorate. These days, because of good transport routes, a lot of areas in my electorate have become closer to the city and hobby farms have been taken up by city people who are often not there all the time to manage the land as well as perhaps some of the people who have lived on the land all their lives and live on the land and work on the land 24/7.Paterson’s curse has been spreading and a number of constituents have been to see me and have contacted me about what they see as an increasing problem throughout the electorate. I know for them the $60 million that the government has set aside in this budget for weed eradication will be very welcome. The program will include research, biological control, community awareness and action. Assistance will be given to the livestock industry to introduce the National Livestock Identification Scheme for cattle, with work progressing on an identification system for sheep, although this is primarily a state government responsibility. Although there are cattle farmers in my electorate, the livestock farmers are predominantly sheep farmers and I know that these measures will be particularly welcome.In an electorate such as Pearce, which covers around 26,000 square kilometres, roads are a very big issue. We have been very pleased that our minister has committed large sums of money in the past to improve the two main arterial roads—the Great Eastern Highway, which connects my electorate and indeed, WA, to the eastern seaboard, and the Great Northern Highway, which runs through my electorate connecting the northern pastoral and mining areas to the city, the airport and the wharf at Fremantle. So they are particularly important roads. Over the years these roads have fallen into disrepair. It is also true to say that the volume and the extent of traffic traversing these roads has grown enormously, with a lot of large trucking, as you can imagine, coming down from the northern mining areas. These trucks have increasingly taken to the roads and the roads are just not adequate to deal with them. With the intersection of these two roads—one from the east one from the north-west—the works take on important dimensions for industries, businesses and tourism within the Pearce electorate.When we talk about roads we have to think about the mums and dads and the ordinary folk who have to use those roads every day to take kids to school, and we have to think about the school buses that run every day in a country electorate. It is of increasing concern to the general public that these roads are in a safe condition for all kinds of traffic. It is very pleasing now to see the work taking place to improve a very large section of the Great Eastern Highway between Sawyers Valley and The Lakes. That is a very welcome improvement to what has been a notorious stretch of road which has caused the deaths of a number of people. A further $3 million of the funding will be used to build the Clackline bypass in 2006-07. I know my constituents will be pleased with the news that black spot funding will continue, as it has been used on many occasions to deal with particularly dangerous conditions such as poor visibility, surface works and widening and alignment in particularly bad spots of the road—and there are many. Earlier in the year, $330,000 was allocated to improving a roundabout in the town of Northam, which I have spoken about as the town of the ecohouse, and an improvement to a section of the northern Cranbrook Road south of Beverly was allocated $250,000.I would like to put on record that I am grateful for the work of the local community groups and shires that keep me up to date with problem areas and assist me with presentations to our minister to ensure that the roads in the electorate are safe. I am often out on the road with community groups, looking at dangerous spots. They are always the eyes and ears of the electorate and I find it very useful to have these people alerting me to various difficult transport or road safety issues.Moving away from the subject of roads and the economy, can I say that it is heartening to see money being given to carers in this budget. That builds on previous budgets. I had the great pleasure of being the Minister for Family Services when the Howard government first took office. The Prime Minister took a very personal interest in the issue of carers. It was not until the Howard government came in that carers were substantially given a voice in this place. The Prime Minister recognised that many families in our communities care for chronically ill people, people with profound disabilities and the elderly, and that they were doing that with very little support from government a few years ago. In almost every budget, the government has sought to improve the situation for those many families around the nation who care for other members of the family. There is increased support for families and I know that it will be of great assistance to those who care for a family member who is chronically ill, profoundly disabled or ageing.Targeted funding to specific areas of health, including cancer care and dementia, are also welcome announcements. Cancer is a disease that touches the lives of most people at some time. Funding for screening, which allows early intervention, is a measure to save lives that is well known in the medical profession. I am also pleased to see health measures that will target young people, with a youth campaign to discourage young people from taking up smoking.In addition to that, we have had some important changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. I know that it requires people to make a small contribution to the cost of their medications. The Treasurer pointed out, and it is important for us all to understand, the cost of many life-extending drugs. The Treasurer used the case of Herceptin, which is used to treat breast cancer. The cost of that drug is around $50,000 to $100,000 per patient per year.Having established in this House an informal backbench group concerned about diabetes, I know that there are many advances in many areas of medicine and pharmaceuticals. These are often life-saving advances. If everyone makes a small contribution to the cost of the medications that they receive to enhance and improve the quality of their lives, it means that more drugs can become available to more people with serious illnesses and, hopefully, either sustain life or improve the quality of life. That is certainly the case with diabetes where there have been some very important advances in recent years with medications that can prevent the early onset of the worst aspects of diabetes, type 2 in particular. It is important that we ask people to make some contribution towards the cost of their medications so that we can ensure that all Australians have access to life-saving and life-enhancing medications.The Treasurer made the point, and I think it is true, that sometimes, if people get medications for nothing, there can be a tendency towards hoarding. That is quite well documented. Many people—I guess we are all guilty of it—have medications in their medical cabinet that are unused and that are subsidised quite heavily by government.With an ageing population and life expectancy increasing, dementia presents a considerable challenge to us for the future. I recently had the pleasure of meeting with Professor Martins, who is an internationally respected Western Australian researcher into Alzheimer’s disease. I have to say his presentation was compelling and disturbing, so I was very pleased to see some of our budget directed towards managing Alzheimer’s disease. The Treasurer allocated $321 million to increase extended aged care at-home places, and the package makes provision for dementia specific training for carers, community and residential care workers, and people working in services such as the police and transport and emergency services. This is quite an important step forward.One of the greatest threats to world peace and stability continues to be abject poverty. We live in a region where many people lack the most basic necessities of life. Opportunity for education and improved access to health care and the ability to become self-sufficient are crucial to tackling the worst ravages of poverty and, in turn, promoting greater community and regional harmony. No countries today live in a vacuum. We are all part of the bigger world. We are part of an important region, and some parts of that region are very poor indeed—you only have to look at some of the Asia-Pacific countries to see that. On Monday, I put a motion to the House with regard to the spread of HIV-AIDS in the western part of China on the border of Laos, north Vietnam and Burma. The number of new cases of HIV-AIDS that have been registered is very disturbing. It is also disturbing to hear from local officials that the spread to mothers and their children is also alarmingly high. So I am particularly pleased that the government does remain committed to playing its part to ease the burden of poverty on our near neighbours. It is in our national interest to assist our neighbours, and this government has been generous in its commitment to many countries in the Asia-Pacific region as well as other countries.However, the centrepiece of the budget is the tax cuts, and these have been made possible through the ability of the Howard government to manage the economy. We expect the economy to grow steadily at three per cent in 2005--06. Unemployment is now at a 28-year low, and it is anticipated that that will stay at a low level. A strong economy with low unemployment is one of the most positive ways to ensure that all Australians improve their circumstances. Having the opportunity to work is one of the best ways to avoid the poverty traps that so many families on welfare face and, along with tax cuts for all taxpayers, I am broadly supportive of the Welfare to Work measures and the money that the government has committed to assisting people to move from welfare to work. I say ‘broadly supportive’ because we must watch this support very carefully. Raising children alone is a very onerous task, and people with a disability have an added challenge in accessing the work force. These people need a lot of support. Adequate child care, decent wages, opportunities to improve education and skill levels, and access to transport and workplaces are all key issues for these people. It is my hope that we will closely monitor the implementation of this policy to ensure adequate support.In the short time I have left, I pause to address the issue of mental health. I have spoken to our government about the concerns I have for people with mental health issues and their access to the work force. Most of these people want to work and are very capable of working, but many of them have an illness which is of an episodic nature and sometimes renders them unable to work on an episodic basis. For them, finding consistent employment is sometimes quite a challenge. I think we have a deficiency in our response across the whole mental health system, particularly at the state level. It is important that we are mindful of some of the most disadvantaged and poorest in our community and that we always ensure that, in the implementation of the policies, these people are given fair access to supporting services.
