name: Byrne, Anthony, MP
content: —I rise to speak in this place this evening, during the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and related bills, about a subject that I have canvassed on many occasions. It relates to government and it relates to regulation. It relates to government’s role in regulating predatory practices by major corporations with enormous market power who exercise that power on a group of small businesses. This is an issue that I have raised over several years in the hope that the government would take some action to protect the rights of a number of small business people around the country. I am speaking about the motor vehicle insurance industry and its relationship with the smash repair industry. In particular I want to talk about the predatory behaviour of the motor vehicle insurance companies and the consequences of that predatory behaviour.I believe—and in this place I am going to cite an incident—that the practices of these major insurance companies are creating the preconditions for a potentially lethal accident. The practices that they are forcing crash repairers to indulge in are resulting in unsafe cars being put back onto the street. That is a disgrace. Government has a responsibility to ensure that predatory practices being perpetrated by the major vehicle insurance companies on the vehicle smash repairers are stopped, and it does have the capacity to actually do this.I am aware of the fact that there is a Productivity Commission report of an inquiry into the smash repair business, a report which is currently being considered by the Treasurer. I believe it was handed to the Treasurer on 18 March. My understanding is that he has 25 sitting days to form a response. I say to the Treasurer that, in contemplating his response to the Productivity Commission report, he needs to look at, potentially, a mandatory code of practice. There has been some form of discussion in the past about a voluntary code of conduct or practice. My belief, from the experience that I have in talking to smash repair businesses across the country, is that we have gone past the point where it should be just a voluntary code of practice. There are too many incidents where major vehicle insurance companies are using their market power to force unsafe working practices on smash repairers. From a personal perspective, I just do not think a voluntary code is going to be satisfactory. I think there needs to be some legislative instrument that can be used.The motor vehicle insurance industry, around the 2000-01 period, had revenues of about $5 billion in premiums. So that is $5 billion in the year 2000-01 out of a total insurance pool nationally of about $21 billion. It is interesting that more than 90 per cent of all motor vehicle insurance business is done by just four companies: IAG, Suncorp, Promina and Allianz. What that means is that there are four companies with enormous market share. They have a sort of symbiotic relationship with about 5,000 smash repairers across the country.I have raised in this place before some of my concerns about the insurance companies’ use of unqualified assessors. These are people who, in my experience and from what I have been told by the smash repair businesses, are sent by insurance companies to deduce the value of the insurance repairs required to put a car back on the road. The information that I have from some of the documents that I have cited quite clearly indicates that these people are simply not qualified to be making that assessment. In a sense, what they are also doing is creating artificially low assessment prices and then forcing the crash repairers to accept those prices.The other thing they are doing is using incentive programs to drive down the cost of a motor vehicle quotation by an assessor. This document from a major insurance company says, in writing, what happens if you meet certain benchmark standards or go underneath benchmark standards. You quote an average price for a vehicle. If in your overall pool of insurance assessment you meet a target where the quote falls below that, you get a bonus. This is a bonus for assessors to underquote on the real cost of smash repairs. When that happens, the smash repairers are forced to repair the car at a lower cost.These issues have been raised in the past and nothing has been done. But adding to that, and giving the Treasurer something to think about when he is contemplating this report by the Productivity Commission, are two further issues. One is the issue of cash settling. What has happened in recent times is that the insurance companies have basically asked the smash repairers to sign an agreement where they become a preferred repairer. That means that—particularly for someone who has been a preferred smash repairer for 20 or 30 years—if they sign the agreement with the insurance company and that preferred repairer is not on the list, then they have to pay in some cases an additional premium to access that preferred repairer. But what is also happening is that a lot of smash repairers are being forced into a very restrictive arrangement with these major insurance companies. If a vehicle is smashed and needs repairing, the person—under RACV, for example—is obliged to go to the preferred repairers nominated by the insurance company. That sounds really good, but I question the relationship between those preferred repairers and the RACV, particularly when these people are relying upon them for customers, given the market share they have.I want to read a particular insight from a smash repairer who had some dealings with this and was very concerned about being forced into a preferred repairer agreement with the IAG. I will just read onto the record—and he has asked me to do this—some of his concerns about this. The document is titled ‘Paying for freedom of choice’ and reads:IAG Insurance intends to include a new provision in Motor Insurance Policies from November 15th 2004.That has already been done. The document continues:The inclusion will allow the policyholder to have freedom of choice in regard to who will repair their vehicle after an accident.This freedom of choice will cost the consumer an estimated $69.30 on top of their normal Comprehensive Insurance policy.It would appear the idea behind this venture is to achieve something IAG have been working on for several years.Basically the consumer (who believes they won’t have an accident and only take out insurance to be responsible and in case of bad luck) by not taking out the freedom of choice levy will hand over complete control and the right for IAG to do as they wish with the policyholder’s vehicle.The majority of the Auto Body Repair Industry in Victoria and NSW have signed IAG’s associate smash repair contract. In doing so, they have had to invest on online imaging and claims handling systems, which was part of the requirements after signing. The repairers were promised that, after becoming an ASR repairer, the arrangement and new equipment would simplify assessments and generally make it easier to do business with IAG.The new so-called freedom of choice policy (unless the vast majority of IAG clients takes it out) will completely do away with all ASR arrangements and the investments made by repairers. As failure by the insured to pay the extra levy on a policy renewal will take anyone other than a preferred IAG repairer out of the equation and do away with the insured’s freedom of choice.This exercise by IAG is nothing more than an effort to take control of vehicles they insure by using smoke and mirrors and relying on motorists gambling on whether or not they will have an accident.Freedom of choice for the consumer is supposedly a normal and expected part of life in Australia and something the ACCC was commissioned to protect and uphold for both the consumer and business communities alike. And certainly not an issue that can be used by a large company to take control of smaller competitors and the consumer.The fact that IAG has proposed such a scheme—and it has been implemented—shows contempt for both the Auto Body Industry and consumers alike. Especially at a time when the Government inquiry into the Body Repairer and Insurance industry relationship is currently being held.… … …If this policy is rubber stamped by the ACCC, it will have a catastrophic effect on the Body Repair Industry and open the door for the Insurance industry to put in place other such methods of control.It is signed ‘from a cranky crash repairer’—I will not read out the exact words. In a sense, what you have is an enormous insurance company with enormous leverage and market power forcing smaller businesses into an arrangement which does not provide freedom of choice. What happens to significant crash repair companies that are reputable and have been in the game but do not want to do this? What happens is that they are subjected, particularly if they have had an agreement with the RACV, to an operation called cash settling.If you are a crash repairer and you do not want to be an approved repairer or to sign that RACV contract or be an associate repairer, they say, ‘If a person comes to you and is insured by us and wants to get the car fixed up, normally we would ensure a fairly smooth process but unfortunately we are going to pay the customer directly after some period of time and then they can pay you.’ This is a standover tactic by major insurance companies over small crash repairers.Most crash repairers are small businesses. On average they employ six or fewer people. I want to refer to some documents that I have received from some of these smash repairers who feel very uncomfortable about what they are being subjected to. I contend that it is an abuse of market power. I will read these into the record; I have been asked to do this by the people concerned. The first document reads as follows:To whom it may concernDelphic Cove Pty Ltd has been providing the RACV with panel beating services since 1983. In that time, we have served both the RACV and our clients who were insured with them with services that do not suffer from interruption, confusion or delaying tactics.In 2003 RACV implemented a preferred repairer scheme and invited Delphic Cove Pty Ltd to participate. After reviewing the agreement and obtaining expert industry and legal advice, we chose not to be contractually bound to the RACV.The consequences of this action have had adverse consequences for our clients. They have been threatened and inconvenienced in the following ways as set out in the table shown below. The table also sets out realistic times and conditions which clients should enjoy, in the absence of the tactics used by RACV to dissuade clients from exercising their right to freedom of choice.The table then describes the process in the cash settlement situation. Someone lodges a claim. Realistically that would be processed in about five minutes; with RACV it is a half-hour process. A book assessment process should be immediate; the RACV tactic is to take two weeks. An authority to proceed should generally involve no delay but it takes two weeks under the RACV. In a realistic situation, payment should take three days but it takes six weeks under the RACV. In a realistic situation a warranty should be for a lifetime, but under the RACV it is nil. There are also provisions for policy cancellation and other issues in terms of the individual I have just been referring to.Another assessment was carried out by Gerry Raleigh from Kerry Panels. Gerry is a person whom I regard as a person of integrity. He has been attempting to raise these issues of the abuse of market power for some time. He has asked me to read his statement to the House:The cash settling process used by RACV is nothing more than a spiteful effort to make those repairers who do not wish to sign an RACV contract conform.Cash settling by RACV means the consumer is inconvenienced, he will have to arrange the repairs himself, no warranty is offered by the Insurer, he must wait until he receives a cheque and then proceed with repairs.If his vehicle is not driveable then naturally he would probably buckle and use the RACV repairer.A repairer can have a working relationship with RACV for 20 years, but with the introduction of the RACV repairer contract if the body shop does not conform, a wedge is driven between himself and his customer.And that has happened time after time with this particular smash repairer. This person uses some fairly colourful language here and I read this advisedly:The RACV repairer contracts are akin to a Mafia protection racket, in other words we offer you nothing but if you do not sign we will make life very difficult for you.These are not my words. These are his words; the words of a small business person who has been subjected to this abuse of market power. He went on to say:A common practice is for the consumer who stands by his independent repairer to have his policy cancelled.Those are two incidents, and I have one more document that I need to read to the House. This document is important and it is from LP Bodyworks. The person who runs the business says:In these years of operating our business we have acquired quite a substantial customer base, for these reasons we have always tried to work with our industry affiliates such as the Insurance Sector. This is why I would like to express my concerns with some issues, in regards to the way “RACV” as we know is underwritten ... is conducting itself when they implement their “Cash Settling” process with, what they call their “Non Accredited” shops.I would like to make the forum aware that we have been affiliated with RACV in the past and ongoing processes for the last 10 years, but for obvious reasons we stopped our relationship with them two years ago when they decided to revamp their Preferred Repairer Network (PSR). We found that the way this particular Insurer was trying to influence or control the repairer processes, was not keeping the customer’s and the repairer’s views in mind, but simply at cost not quality and most importantly “safety and manufacturers specifications” when it comes to reinstating the consumer’s vehicle.And that is a concern. It continues:This method that the RACV has imposed is nothing more than a ploy to inconvenience and use the customer as a lever hold on the repairer, hoping that they will give in to the pressure and steer them through their own repair networks.That is the third small business. There are many more incidents and there are many more complaints that I have received about the RACV and that cash settling process. Clearly this is abuse of market power and it is something that should be investigated. I note that the ACCC’s Graeme Samuel has said recently that they want to be notified if there are any big businesses using standover tactics, and they are looking at utilising section 51AC of the Trade Practices Act. I am going to suggest that these small businesses start writing to the ACCC. Unfortunately, these small businesses have been saying that they have been raising their concerns with the ACCC and that no action has been taken. But I will be asking each of those people to make submissions to ACCC Chairman Samuel on the basis of the comments that he has been reported to have made in the media.Another issue with respect to the practice of insurance companies is colloquially called a ‘cut and shut’ operation. What does cut and shut mean? There are many cute names and technical terms, but it effectively means that if a car is totalled, if a car suffers extensive damage, if a car—like in the incident that I am about to report—has been half smashed away, the car is cut in half and half a different car of a similar model is basically welded onto it.I would like to talk about the case of a Holden Berlina which was owned by Mrs Sharon Hooper. In May 2004 the car was smashed into from behind and was extensively damaged. It was insured for the value of just over $17,000. It was probably overinsured, but the premiums the Hoopers had been paying for a number of years had been paid on the basis that the car’s value was $17,000. Its actual assessment value would have been less than that. When the car was taken to the RACV’s preferred smash repairer, an extensive quotation was given—it was in the order of $8,000—but the owner and the owner’s husband, Mr Richard Hooper, were basically saying: ‘This car has been totalled. It has been written off. We do not understand why you are attempting to repair this, it is in such a bad state.’ The insurer, RACV, insisted on the car being repaired. The car was repaired. But when Mr Hooper walked in to see what was happening with the car, he noticed that it had been cut in half. He was not even told that this was what was going to happen with the vehicle. When he walked into the premises of the approved smash repairer that had been referred by the RACV, he was told it was a ‘cut and shut’ repair.Mr Hooper picked up the vehicle but, after a short period driving it he realised that it was handling poorly and that the driver’s seat felt different. There is an extensive list of faults, with 31 faults being listed. He took the car back and said, ‘This car is not functioning properly,’ and that he wanted a proper, independent assessment. He left the car there. When he came back to see the progress being made, he found them trying to fix those very faults that he identified. He then demanded, legally, that an independent assessment be conducted. I have a list of 31 faults. It is absolutely extraordinary. The fuel tank was incorrectly fitted. The fuel lines were not appropriately secured. So this car was in fact a death trap. Seatbelts were distorted. The front seatbelts were incorrectly fitted. The fuel lines were incorrectly fitted. The vehicle was driving around right-hand turns; it was on an automatic right-hand turn. This car should have been written off. The insurance company should have had the integrity to have had this car written off.These cut and shut practices, not appropriately supervised, are a way for the insurance companies to cut costs. I will say to the RACV and other insurance companies: if you are going to keep on doing this, I am going to keep on raising it in parliament until you get it right. Stop screwing small independent business holders and start acting appropriately or I will urge the Treasurer, in considering the report from the Productivity Commission, to take the appropriate action and make a mandatory code of conduct.

name: Entsch, Warren, MP
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources
content: —I rise this afternoon to add my voice to the debate on the appropriation bills and to proudly associate myself with the achievements of this government, particularly economic achievements, over the past 10 budgets that we have had responsibility for. This year is no different. There is an $8.9 billion surplus—the eighth surplus since we have been in government. The unemployment rate is at its lowest level in some 28 years and we are delivering some $21.7 billion worth of tax cuts to the Australian people over the next four years. This is on top of the $14.7 billion worth of tax cuts provided in last year’s budget.Another very significant point in this budget is the fact that we have now paid off $90 billion of debt that we inherited when we came to office in 1996. To put that in simple terms, in 1996 we were faced with the challenge of having to find $9.6 billion out of tax funds just to pay the interest on the accumulated debt that we walked into in 1996, before a cent could be paid towards any services to the Australian people. We are now in the situation for the next financial year of having reduced that debt to less than $6 billion, which of course means that we will have in excess of $9 billion in additional funds available to spend on the Australian people. Of course, the more debt we pay off, the more we can commit to other things—it is not rocket science. As the Treasurer said, this is not by accident. It certainly was not a fluke. This is an outcome of very sound economic management.The budget has been extremely generous to my electorate of Leichhardt. I certainly appreciate the contribution to a number of projects, including the ongoing flood proofing of the Bruce Highway at Tully, south of Cairns. There was an additional $2.9 million to assist the state government in their planning works for this program. There was $1.5 million allocated last year to get these works underway and to prioritise them. Unfortunately, the state government have continued to drag their feet. The planning work was supposed to be completed next month for the work to be finished in 2006-07, but we have now discovered that the state government has not been able to achieve this outcome. We have allocated another $2.9 million to see if that can help light a fire under the state government planning authorities to get something done there. It is certainly a serious economic and social impediment in Far North Queensland. Unfortunately, even at this stage we are probably looking at 2008-09, if they actually get their act together, to get it to completion. I have to say that sending the shadow minister from Victoria up there to become a poor apologist for the state government did not do anything for achieving this outcome. I think he would do a lot better if he were to encourage his state government colleagues to start to do some work rather than make excuses for not doing it.Russett Park was another good example of a commitment from this government. Half a million dollars was committed to the Russett Park community and to the Mareeba Shire Council to put a three-metre causeway across a river. For many years the community, which is only about 15 to 20 kilometres from Cairns, has been stranded by that river. Unfortunately that river has taken two lives to date. In spite of a lot of huff and puff from the state government, with the money committed from the local residents, the council and the federal government, people will be able to drive onto a three-metre causeway. However, because of the state government’s reluctance to contribute, there will be quite a significant fall off one end because it is not going to be quite completed, and that is the legacy of the state government. I encourage the council and the residents to go ahead and do what they can to get as much of this completed as they can because, at the end of the day, if another life is lost in another wet season that will be squarely on the shoulders of the Labor state government.The Roads to Recovery program is another very successful one. In my electorate Cairns City Council will receive another $1 million-plus. There will be $700,000 for Cook Shire, a very large electorate; $166,000 for Douglas Shire; and $93,000 for Torres Strait. Since the Roads to Recovery program has come in the amount of bitumen that has been laid by local authorities is amazing. The money is going straight through to these local authorities and they are able to prioritise their work, keep their work force on the job—certainly not allowing anything to be cost-shifted back into the state government coffers—and you can certainly see the results.A good example of that was the opportunity I had the other day to open the new works at Aumuller Road, a four-lane highway. That work had been well overdue. Concrete slabs were laid by the American troops in the 1939-45 war and of course in the period since then the road has deteriorated significantly. The Roads to Recovery funding has allowed the Cairns City Council to upgrade this road to an excellent piece of infrastructure.The other thing in the budget which I was looking for and was very pleased to see was the additional $90 million in the black spot funding program. Again, this has provided vital funding in regional areas and, in my view, it has saved a lot of lives. You only have to drive on any of the highways in Cairns and outlying areas to see outstanding examples of work carried out under this program—work that certainly would not have been done if we were waiting for the state government to put their hands in their pockets.Another very successful funding achievement was $10 million for the Cairns Esplanade. This is on top of a $9 million spend that we had about three years ago, taking the total Australian government investment to some $19 million. The results of the work so far have been quite profound and not only for visitors to Cairns—although 40 per cent of its economy is reliant on tourism, and it is the second biggest international tourism destination to Sydney. The work that has been done on this esplanade area has certainly added to the experience of locals as well as to that of international visitors. It is amazing to see the number of locals who have come to love and enjoy this area. The additional $10 million is going to be able to finish the whole waterfront area of Cairns City and it certainly will make a huge difference to that area.Then there were the unsuccessful bids by the reef and rain forest CRCs last year. I remember that Senator McLucas was on her knees praying every night that they were going to fail, that they were never going to run, because that would give her something to criticise. She makes no effort whatsoever to get off her butt and do something about seeing if she can find an alternative. Instead, she uses political opportunism just to criticise or knock for the sake of knocking to try to build her own political stakes.But there are those in the community who realise that the bids that were put in by both of those entities were not appropriate—that they did not fit the criteria—and they are prepared to work with me to find an alternative. Again, I would like to recognise the outstanding contribution of Russell Reichelt, CEO of the Reef CRC; Daniel Gschwind, CEO of the Queensland Tourism Industry Council; and John McIntyre, who was with TTNQ. Rather than criticise and make cheap political shots, as happened with Senator McLucas, they realised that there were problems and that we had to do something different, and they sat down and worked with me. As a direct result of the contribution of those three outstanding citizens, we now have the Marine and Tropical Sciences Research Facility for Far North Queensland, which has been funded with significantly more resources than both the reef and rainforest CRCs combined. There has been some $40 million to establish this magnificent, world-first facility—it will be the best in the world—in both Cairns and Townsville. It will be the premium facility in the world for reef and rainforest research.It will certainly attract a lot of interest from both the conservation and scientific communities around the world. James Cook University have been very excited by this, because it gives them another opportunity in relation to expanding options that are available through their campuses. This is on top of a veterinary school. A few years ago we announced a medical school for James Cook University—again, provided through good economic management by this government and strong lobbying by me—and the member for Herbert, Peter Lindsay, played a very significant role in achieving that. So we had the medical school, and now we have a veterinary school—and the funding has been set aside for that. Of course, the vice-chancellor of James Cook University is very excited about the opportunities this will provide and some very significant and unique strengths and attributes will enhance the delivery of services of James Cook University.Another issue that has been of concern in my area—and, again, it has been addressed through this budget—is illegal fishing, particularly in the gulf and Torres Strait. Some 87 illegal fishing vessels were apprehended in northern waters this year alone, and we had to look seriously at dealing with the vessels that were impounded and held in the harbour, which was totally unsatisfactory. Residents on Thursday Island and Horn Island had concerns with regard to health problems and security. But $32.5 million has been set aside for the detection, detention and prosecution of illegal fishermen. A very significant amount of money has been set aside to build a purpose-built, 48-person facility on Horn Island to immediately process illegal fishermen with regard to their health et cetera and send them off to Darwin for prosecution. There will also be a purpose-built facility for the destruction of vessels that are taken in the area. That can be done in a way that is not going to cause any environmental problems. That will provide a significant number of jobs for local residents on Horn Island and Thursday Island, something that has been very much welcomed by that community. Given that, particularly in the Torres Strait, fishing is the only natural resource, other than tourism opportunities, it is absolutely imperative that we do everything we can to protect the integrity of that resource.We are also enhancing search and rescue in Far North Queensland. Some $54.7 million has been allocated out of this budget for the establishment of a new search and rescue service. There will be four turboprop aircraft, which are much faster than anything that is available now. Three will be flying at all times. One, I would expect, will be based in Far North Queensland—in Cairns, I expect. These are very high-speed purpose-built aircraft for search and rescue. Instead of taking Coastwatch off task to look for people who are lost in this vast area, these aircraft will be readily available. They will be fitted with the latest technology, including surface search radars and forward-looking infrared equipment, which will allow them to work at night time, and satellite communications, again offering another level of support and safety in our region.A range of other initiatives has also been made available through this budget. They are national initiatives, certainly, but they are initiatives that are going to be of great benefit in my electorate. There is $179 million for new Indigenous health measures. We know of the work that needs to be done there. There is an additional $40 million for primary health clinics in communities. There is over $102 million over four years to improve the health of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander mothers, babies and children and to reduce the impact of chronic diseases. There is $8 million to help deal with issues of petrol sniffing. There is also funding of some $10 million for government hearing services for Indigenous communities, and funding to help communities keep professional staff through an extension of the fringe benefits tax supplementation program for an additional four years.There is funding for bowel cancer. The prevalence of cancer touches all of us in the community. There is some $43.4 million for the national bowel cancer screening program and another $23.1 million over four years to help local groups and care providers offer better support for cancer patients and their families. This new funding will be used to fit out and equip premises for palliative care, pastoral care, counselling and family support. There is also $25 million to assist in tackling problems with young people who are starting to smoke at an early age—they have got to start at the source, particularly in relation to lung cancer. There has been additional funding for mental health, which is an issue I raise regularly in this place. There is some $69 million for youth mental health initiatives, appreciating that three-quarters of mental health problems begin before the age of 25. There is another $39.6 million for the national depression initiative, money certainly well spent and a direct result of responsible economic management by this government. Diabetes initiatives will also receive a boost of some $44.2 million and asthma will receive another $27.1 million. All in all, it has been an outstanding contribution to these areas.Another area which has caused some difficulty for the other side of politics, for the Labor Party, is the tax cuts, with the reduction from 17 to 15 per cent for our lower income earners and the lifting of the thresholds which has been quite significant. You always hear complaints, particularly from the other side, about the brain drain, about our intelligent young people moving overseas because of the high tax problems here. We are losing all those young people. What we have done is bring our tax system into line with those countries that attract these young professionals. It will mean that there is no longer a reason for them to travel overseas.I would have thought that the Labor Party would have offered congratulations, particularly given the skills shortages that we have in this country at the moment and our desperate need to retain those young highly skilled people. But, no, purely for the sake of politics they are out there jumping up and down, threatening to disallow this and coming back with a plagiarised mickey mouse alternative. From talking to my own business community, I know that there is a lot of confusion out there. They desperately want this to be introduced on 1 July. We have got to call on the Leader of the Opposition to stop blocking this, stop playing havoc with the employees in Far North Queensland and stop threatening to block these tax cuts. At the end of the day, all he is going to do is cause an unnecessary cost to business. I ask him to stop the nonsense and allow the tax cuts to go through. (Time expired)

name: Edwards, Graham, MP
content: —In speaking on the appropriation bills I want to defend Western Australia. It seems to me that the federal Treasurer and Liberal leadership hopeful Peter Costello wants to base his leadership push on proving just how well he can bully the states. The Treasurer’s recent attack on Western Australia is incredible and his threat to withhold GST revenues from that state is state bashing at its pitiful worst. The Treasurer has threatened to withhold GST revenues from WA unless WA drops more state taxes. It is interesting that the Treasurer would do this because on the one hand the government are saying that this is not a Commonwealth tax but a state tax, yet on the other hand it is a tax they want to control when it suits them. The other interesting thing is that it was a Liberal Premier who signed WA up to the GST.Because of the Treasurer’s threats, I went to the current Premier’s web site. I was very pleased to discover the following information, which I want to quote:In 1999 the then Premier Richard Court signed an agreement on behalf of Western Australia to receive a share of the GST revenue in return for abolishing three state taxes and reviewing a further six.Indeed, since 1999, as part of that agreement signed by Premier Court, WA has abolished three state taxes. It has abolished financial institutions duty and listed marketable securities duty, and debits tax is legislated to be abolished on 1 July 2005. WA has reviewed the other six and abolished three more taxes. It has abolished unlisted marketable securities duty, leases duty and cheque duty. Western Australia also abolished a further two taxes not listed on that agreement: stamp duty on workers compensation insurance and stamp duty on life insurance. In total, the WA state government has abolished eight state taxes, while the agreement only required the abolition of three state taxes. While the GST was signed up under the previous Liberal state government, the incoming Labor government has met those commitments, and I think the Premier’s claim that Western Australia has not only honoured its side of the agreement but exceeded it is demonstrably true.I also want to point out to the Treasurer—Australia’s next Leader of the Opposition—that my home state of WA contributes $2 billion more each year than we get back in federal funding. That is a $1,000 subsidy by every man, woman and child in Western Australia to the rest of the nation. In addition, up to 90 per cent of the royalties Western Australia receives from its resources are distributed to other states, yet the federal government refuses to adequately fund the necessary infrastructure required for mining and other resource development. Indeed, ABS figures show that the Commonwealth tax take is $10,462 per person, while just $2,503 per person is derived from state based revenue.I am grateful to the Premier’s office in WA for the above information. Something else that I have been pointing out in Western Australia for years is that in WA we are free from the plague of poker machines—and we thank successive governments for that. I would certainly call on future state governments in Western Australia to continue with that no pokies policy. We need to remind the federal Treasurer that we do not, unlike other states, derive income from those machines. Indeed, it is worth pointing out that New South Wales derives $1.311 billion from gambling and Victoria $1.324 billion. That puts WA behind the eight ball right from the word go. But I would rather have it that way than to allow Treasurer Costello to force poker machines into our state. They are not wanted and they are not required—and I think that is pretty well a bipartisan position in Western Australia.The other taxable revenue device we do not have in WA is road tollways. I am not sure what revenue is derived from road tollways, but it seems to me that this is becoming more and more a means of revenue in New South Wales and Victoria. I to say the Treasurer: ‘Thank you very much, but, just like poker machines, we don’t want any road tollways in Western Australia either.’I also noticed that the WA government in last week’s state budget scrapped the bank debits tax, freed up some 24,000 people from paying land tax, raised land tax thresholds and cut the middle land tax while abolishing stamp duty on mortgage refinancing for owner-occupiers and small business. Overall in WA the state government is returning some $870 million in tax relief over the next four years. This is on top of the $1.5 billion in tax cuts announced last year. In WA, the Gallop government is delivering $2.4 billion in tax and family relief. In addition, it is putting more investment into training teachers, building new schools, providing more police, generating more electricity and expanding and building new hospitals. At the same time, in partnership with the resource sector, it is investing in new infrastructure.Infrastructure is something the Howard-Costello government refuses to accept a fair responsibility for in WA, let alone show any responsibility for. On the one hand the Howard-Costello government is refusing to assist with infrastructure and resource development, but at the same time it wants to reduce state revenue and is saying to WA, ‘We want you to generate more income so we can confiscate that for Canberra.’ It is pretty obvious that both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, who both come from the eastern states—and I am not saying there is anything wrong with that—have little knowledge and appreciation of the fact that it is well-run and well-managed states like Western Australia that are hand in hand with the resource sector developing our nation, expanding our exports and building our economy. The Treasurer should get off the back of WA and get out of its path. He should stop being an impediment to Western Australia’s development and for a change he should support our state and our crucial resource sector.Mr Deputy Speaker, you would well know that prices of minerals fluctuate—there are peaks and troughs. There is no guarantee in the future that the prices you are getting today will be there in five, six or seven years time. Any state government which cut its funding and by so doing inhibited its ability to work hand-in-hand with the resource sector to explore and develop new prospects, fields or mining areas would be cutting the throat of the state in the long term. My advice to the Treasurer is that he ought to give WA a fair go. He should not be the goose that kills the state that lays Australia’s richest golden egg. If Western Australia allowed itself to be bullied by this Treasurer, this Prime Minister and this government, not only would we be killing the goose that lays Australia’s richest golden egg, but in view of the figures that I gave a little while ago—and in view of the revenue which is generated in Western Australia and distributed to other parts of the nation—we would be doing a great disservice to this nation. So the state government, with the support of all federal members, Liberal and Labor, should stand up to this Costello-Howard government and support the Premier of Western Australia. If they do not, they are turning their backs on the people of that great state.Having exposed the Treasurer for the reckless person that he is, particularly in relation to Western Australia, I have a number of other issues that I want to deal with. I want to turn tonight to another issue to do with the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs. I call on this minister to fix the incredible debacle which surrounds the issuing of military medals in Australia. We recently saw the very embarrassing situation our nation found itself in when the president of Indonesia awarded that nation’s humanitarian medal to the nine Australians killed in the Sea King disaster. It was an embarrassment to Australia—not that the medal was awarded but that we had nothing that we could give. It was a very emotional moment for most Australians when they saw those coffins coming back with the medals from Indonesia, and they were matched by a sprig of wattle, I think at the suggestion of the Governor-General.The government moved fairly quickly to arrange for our own humanitarian medal to be awarded to those people who were so tragically killed. They did that with this opposition’s support, and I think it was a fair and reasonable thing for them to do. But it is interesting in this context to remember that, some 11 months ago, the government announced a new Australian Defence Force medal, and they said applications for this medal would be called for by the end of last year. Interestingly, that announcement was made as a lead-up to the last election. Where have the medals gone? We have no idea where they are, what their design is, when they will be available, and what the criteria for these medals will be. That is despite this government having promised on more than one occasion that applications would be called for at the end of last year.Labor’s policy is very clear in this area. We announced it last year, and we have stood by that policy. We would award the Australian Defence Force medal to volunteers who have served their initial period of enlistment of three years or in some circumstances two years. You might remember back to the post Second World War era when some people who served in Korea only had to enlist for two years.We would also award the medal to next of kin of those killed on duty or to those who were forced to take discharge because of injury, or in the case of women because of situations where they were forced out because of marriage or pregnancy. A number of women served in the ADF for a period of four years or signed up for four years. Some of them had to get out because they were married or having a child. We would want to recognise the contribution that those women made.I believe that this government has made a farce of these new medals, and it is really high time that it got the house in order. But it does not end there. In July 2002 I, along with several other members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, visited our troops on the ground in the Middle East. Included in that was a visit to our SAS blokes in Bagram. While we were there we gave a commitment, as much as a group of members of parliament can give a commitment, to pursue the issue of a campaign medal to recognise the wonderful service that those people were contributing in that country. Indeed when we returned to Australia the committee wrote to the Minister for Defence seeking the government’s commitment to such a campaign medal.Last year the minister announced the medal and gave the impression to recipients that it would be available for them to have by Anzac Day this year. Not only has the Afghanistan campaign medal failed to materialise but there is now a story which causes some concern to me, and that is that the medals, yet to be manufactured, will be further delayed because the government is considering having them minted overseas. I do not want to divert from the real case, which is the fact that these people are entitled to their medals. But I do think that the minister should, if she is going to allow these medals to be minted overseas, be prepared to defend that decision, because there will be a fair amount of angst in Australia if that is the case.The real story here is that recognition delayed is recognition denied. In my view, and I know in the view of many former and current serving soldiers, the length of time they have had to wait for these medals is a fair reflection of the lack of appreciation that this government really has for the job that these blokes and these women did. The individual and personal challenges and dangers that these members of the ADF, as soldiers operating in difficult terrain, had to expose themselves to and the dangers of the elements as well as the enemy are exactly what campaign medals are designed to reflect. So I am going to pose the question: why are our Afghanistan veterans who were serving that country in 2002 and the Iraq veterans still waiting for their campaign medals so many years after the campaign, particularly in relation to the Afghanistan campaign? I think it would be very difficult for any member of this parliament to justify such a delay. As I said, recognition delayed is recognition denied. I want to call on the minister to demand some action here and to demand it now. These blokes are entitled to their medals. They should have them.

name: May, Margaret, MP
content: —The future prosperity of Australia, the continuing strong economic growth, the continuing high employment, the continuing low interest rates and low inflation and the record highs in consumer and business confidence are all due in no small way to the policies of the Howard government. In bringing down his 10th budget just three weeks ago the Treasurer called it a budget framed for the future. It was a budget framed for the future, a budget focused on future opportunities for our young people, a budget focused on care for our aged, a budget focused on the continued security of our nation, a budget focused on the health services that our citizens will need in the future, a budget focused on the continued strong economic growth of our nation that is synonymous with the Howard government.The coalition government, under the leadership of John Howard, have a great deal of experience under our belt. Our win at the last federal election has given us a unique opportunity of ensuring that the next three years of policy decisions really count. The agenda for Australia’s future has to be cemented further, given our ageing population. Level-headedness, maturity, commonsense and sound decision making are going to be needed more than ever over the next three years. The recent budget sets a blueprint for the next 12 months and lays the foundation for the fourth-term agenda of the Howard government.There has been a lot of talk about the future. Without continued strong economic growth, our future as a country and for our people would not be in the position it is in today. The Australian economy has performed impressively and that is not by accident. It has performed impressively because of sound economic management and a commitment to ongoing reform and policy decisions that have been taken by the Howard government.What does this budget mean to the people I represent in the federal parliament, the people of McPherson? What does it mean to our communities on the southern Gold Coast? How have we benefited and what will those continued benefits mean in the future to our young people, our young families, our aged and our city as it continues to grow at a rate unmatched anywhere else in Australia?Because of our prudent management of the Australian economy, the government will deliver further personal income tax cuts to all Australians. We are a government that believe in giving Australian taxpayers back their hard earned dollars with a budget surplus. It is now up to the opposition to pass on those tax cuts and to allow Australians to benefit from these tax cuts from 1 July. I say to the opposition: don’t penalise the Australian taxpayer by blocking this legislation. Vote with us and pass on the tax cuts.Under the proposed legislation, further personal income tax cuts are worth $21.7 billion over the next four years. These are tax cuts that will assist low-income earners, boost disposable incomes and reward participation and hard work. Australians will keep more of what they earn, and why shouldn’t they? There are now more incentives for Aussies to continue to work hard and reap the rewards of that hard work.With the support of the opposition, from 1 July this year the 17 per cent marginal tax rate will be cut to 15 per cent, and the 42 per cent tax threshold will increase from $58,000 to $63,000 on 1 July 2005 and to $70,000 on 1 July 2006. From 1 July 2005, the 47 per cent threshold will increase from $70,000 to $95,000 and on 1 July 2006 it will increase again to $125,000. In my view, these tax cuts and increases in thresholds are fair and well targeted. These changes ensure that more than 80 per cent of taxpayers face a top marginal income tax rate of 30 per cent or less over the forward estimates period, and from 1 July 2006 the top marginal rate will apply to only three per cent of taxpayers.In addition to the income tax cuts and the government’s ongoing plan to encourage people to save for their retirement, the superannuation surcharge will be scrapped altogether from 1 July 2005. The cut in the lowest rate of tax benefits also benefits seniors and means that senior Australians eligible for the senior Australian tax offset will now pay no tax on their annual income up to $21,968 for a single and on equal incomes up to a joint $36,494 for a couple. Once again I say to the opposition: pass the tax cuts. Allow all Australians to benefit from the personal income tax cuts from 1 July 2005. Australians should share in the prosperity of our nation and the economic benefits that have flowed from our strong economic management. I say to the opposition: act responsibly and pass the tax cuts.One of the most significant achievements of this government has been the continuing fall in unemployment rates. McPherson’s December unemployment rate hit a historical low of 5.2 per cent compared to the then national average of 5.5 per cent. It was the first time our unemployment rate was better than the national average. In the past McPherson has trailed somewhere between two and three per cent behind the national average. These figures were welcome news for the southern Gold Coast. It meant that more people had jobs and that young people had job opportunities. The results reflect the Howard government’s strong economic management once again and highlight the significant labour market improvements that are achievable when a government is prepared to reform the employment services market through the Job Network and make the hard decisions on workplace reform.Despite the fact that more Australians are in work today and that the unemployment rate has fallen to a low unmatched for 28 years, it is more important than ever that the opposition support the government’s workplace relations and work force participation reforms, which have the potential to make even further inroads into the level of unemployment. Another challenge for the opposition is to support key reforms in the areas of increasing work force participation and in the labour market.Part of the challenge for government in securing our future is increasing participation in the work force. Our 14 consecutive years of growth have been accompanied by low unemployment rates, low inflation rates and low interest rates but the future will see Australia come under increasing pressure as it competes in a freer global market environment, where competition will be aggressive, not just for our natural resources, manufactured goods and services but importantly for our greatest asset, our labour force. Participation in the work force, assisting people from welfare to work, is much more than statistics about unemployment rates. It is about people becoming financially secure and sharing in the wealth of this country. In many cases it is about people’s self-esteem and confidence. It is about people overcoming their social isolation. It is about recognising the value of a person’s contribution to our society. It is about people feeling worth while about contributing.As a government we have a responsibility to ensure all Australians who want to work and who are able to work are given the opportunity to participate. We have to ensure that there are programs that will assist in training and skilling people so that they can become productive members of our society. It is about assisting people from welfare to work. It is not about paying people a benefit every fortnight and forgetting about them. We have a responsibility to engage those people who are able to and want to work. It is about providing rehabilitation services and education and training opportunities that will give these people the best chance ever of participating.Employers will also be encouraged to employ people with disabilities. Schemes will be expanded to assist employers to take on these people. We will work with industry to identify the skill shortages and ensure we address those skill shortages with the appropriate training programs. We need to encourage as many people of working age as we can to join our work force, to become productive members of our communities.During the last federal campaign our government announced a commitment to 24 technical colleges to be built in regions around Australia. The Gold Coast has been identified as an area to receive funding for such a college. This election commitment provides for the establishment and operation of colleges for year 11 and 12 students to promote excellence in the teaching and acquiring of trade and craft skills at the secondary school level. Each college will be linked to and endorsed by industry and run autonomously by principals who will be able to engage teaching staff on a performance pay basis.We know today that one of the greatest challenges for business is finding people to take up skilled jobs. For too long success for young Australians has been equated to finishing year 12 and obtaining a university degree. This, of course, is a path that many young people aspire to and a path that should be supported. However, there is an attitude in the community that only a university degree will secure employment. In many cases it has become a status symbol and as a country we have paid a significant economic and social cost for this attitude. One-third of students who start university will not finish their studies.As a country we are facing critical skill shortages in the trades, including building and construction, metals, manufacturing and automotive. On the Gold Coast we are also facing shortages in the hospitality industry. We desperately need young people to take on traineeships or apprenticeships as chefs. We need people in this industry, both front of house and back of house. People need to be well trained and willing to work in this multimillion dollar industry, which supports our very strong tourism industry.This government is committed to revolutionising vocational education and training, through the 24 colleges. As a nation, we should value trades training as highly as any other form of postsecondary education. I look forward to the Gold Coast technical college becoming a reality and offering choices and another education pathway to the young people on the Gold Coast. I know a number of tenders have been presented from the Gold Coast. I wish each of the consortiums every success with their bids and of course look forward to working with the successful consortium in establishing the Gold Coast Australian technical college.Small business, as we know, is the backbone of the Australian economy. Businesses have been growing. They have had to become smarter. They are now part of opportunities in a growing global market that has become increasingly competitive. We need to ensure that our businesses are as productive and competitive as they can be, and that means we need to address impediments to business activity. There is an increasing need for industrial relations reform to increase work force participation. Legislation such as the fair dismissal bill will assist business in employing those extra people they need.The Treasurer announced $1.8 billion of tax cuts to enhance the competitiveness of Australian businesses. Already abolished is the three per cent tariff on imported business inputs which do not have substitutes manufactured in Australia. This will be a saving to business of $1.3 billion over the next five years.The tourism industry on the Gold Coast is made up of thousands of small businesses, and our tourism industry will be a winner from the extra $453 million being invested into attracting tourists to our country. Our local communities will benefit from the extra $7.5 million that will be spent on promoting tourism projects and encouraging visitors to stay on the Gold Coast longer, through the Australian Tourism Development Program.Tourism is big business for our local communities, and the Gold Coast is no exception. The industry provides thousands of jobs throughout Australia, and by boosting tourism in local areas extra jobs can be created and additional income earned by small businesses. I encourage all members and senators to take a trip north to Australia’s tourism capital. Everyone deserves the chance to experience our unique way of life, to take part in a fresh Gold Coast adventure that stretches from historic rural communities in the north to border towns and coastal centres on the southern Gold Coast, and to enjoy our beautiful hinterland—the green behind the gold—and our pristine beaches. We have it all.There have been many discussions over a number of years about the future of our great country—the future of our ageing population, the future of our environment, the future of our health system and, importantly, the future infrastructure plans for our road and rail systems. Through AusLink, many of these infrastructure plans will be funded. With this budget, an additional $150 million over five years will be provided to expand the Roads to Recovery program, and an additional $90 million will be provided to continue the Road Safety Black Spot Program.The Gold Coast City Council will benefit from these funds. An additional $14 million will be provided to the council for the Roads to Recovery program. There is no doubt that this funding is urgently needed on the Gold Coast to address the serious traffic problems we are encountering due to our rapid population growth. I know the council will also be applying for funding under the Road Safety Black Spot Program, which has been a successful initiative in the past.The establishment of the future fund is also a very welcome announcement. There is no doubt that we need to make provision for the future. We need to begin saving for the future to meet the costs of our ageing population. The future fund will be an independent fund with a statutory board of eminent people who are going to make an investment on behalf of Australia’s future. It will be a large fund and it is expected to accumulate earnings over a period of time, which will mean that the government can fund its liabilities and relieve future generations of the costs of the ageing of the population. These earnings will be safeguarded by legislation. The future fund will only invest in infrastructure projects that make commercial sense. The government expects the fund to be able to invest in listed infrastructure vehicles and listed property trusts. There will not be uncommercial, risky investments being made by the future fund that would risk the capacity for government to pay the superannuation liabilities.Since coming to power in 1996, the Howard government has managed to retire most of the $96 billion debt we inherited on coming to office. By reducing this debt, we can look to the future with confidence. We can be assured that our commitments, as a government, to all Australians will be met. The savings by government from the reduction of the debt will ensure that the future fund will meet the needs of our nation in the long term.There are many good news stories in this budget—for example, a one-off lump sum payment this year of $1,000 to eligible carers receiving the carer payment and $600 to those receiving the carers allowance. Carers in our community should never be taken for granted. They undertake a selfless task, often a lonely task, isolated from society because of the very nature of the task they have undertaken.Cancer is an insidious disease. I have recently lost two very close friends to this disease and have a very dear friend who is currently fighting the disease—Wal is being very brave, but I worry about his fight. The government is committed to a major funding package to improve cancer care through bowel cancer screening, dedicated cancer research, the training of cancer nurses, increased funding for palliative care, and $5.5 million over two years to raise national awareness of skin cancer and encourage action to prevent it. Another important program is the commitment to a national youth campaign aimed at reducing the number of young people who take up smoking. We all know that smoking is a killer. Early intervention programs hopefully will have the desired effect. The government has committed $25 million over four years to help discourage young Australians from taking up smoking.The budget also makes dementia a national health priority. The $321 million package will enhance the quality of life of dementia sufferers and their carers. As life expectancy increases, dementia will become more common within our communities. The funding package will offer more opportunities for dementia-specific training for carers, community and residential care workers, and people working in services such as the police, transport and emergency services. I particularly commend this initiative by the government. Dementia is a debilitating disease. Sufferers and their carers face huge challenges on a daily basis, and any help and assistance will be welcome, I know.Diabetes is also becoming a huge national health concern. The government has provided $44.2 million over four years to continue a national approach to improve the prevention and management of diabetes. There is no doubt that education on the effects of diabetes, and programs to assist Australians to recognise early warning signs, are positive steps in bringing diabetes under control.Balancing work and family and the daily stresses of life can have huge impacts on families. Often families need outside counselling to help keep relationships and families together. The government has announced funding over four years to establish a network of 65 family relationship centres across Australia. These centres will help couples access premarriage education and assist families experiencing relationship difficulties with information and access to family skills training and support that can be delivered through other departments and agencies. This initiative is another example of government support for and recognition of the importance of strong family relationships within our communities. Strong families build strong communities and ultimately a strong country.The Prime Minister has often referred to Australia as having a decent society, a tolerant society, a society that recognises and supports low- and middle-income families with dependent children. Through this budget, those families and children are being supported and encouraged now and for the future. I commend the bills to the House.

name: Emerson, Craig, MP
content: —I would like to concentrate my remarks on the budget primarily upon an economic analysis of the budget and the wider economic implications that flow from it. Members of parliament will be well aware of Labor’s critique of the government’s spending program that began before the previous budget, carried through the 2004-05 budget and then flowed into the pre-election campaign period. That critique was that the budget spending spree amounted to $66 billion and would put undue pressure on interest rates. Labor did not come to this view belatedly but said it consistently as the government went upon this spending spree.There was only one purpose behind that spending spree, and that was to get the government re-elected. It was clear it was going to give total priority to that and then, after the election, worry about the economic consequences. After the election the chickens did come home to roost, as Labor had feared they would: the OECD, the IMF and the Reserve Bank of Australia all expressed concerns about the management of the economy, including in their critique the $66 billion spending spree.In March 2005 the Reserve Bank had no choice left to it but to increase interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. The effect of the pre-election spending spree was to pour fuel onto the flames of already strong consumer spending. The government knew exactly what it was doing, but calculated correctly that it would be able to get away with it and deal with the consequences after the election. The interest rate rise itself has had an adverse impact on home borrowers. A quarter of a percentage point interest rate increase can be a significant increase when people are borrowed up to the hilt, as they are. If Labor’s critique of the pre-election spending spree of $66 billion was right, then surely a critique of a $103 billion spending spree would carry some weight. And that is, in fact, what the government has done in the 2005-06 budget—it has gone on a $103 billion spending spree. I have said consistently that I am concerned about the impact of this on further interest rate rises. The Reserve Bank’s task is quite straightforward—that is, to keep inflation within a nominated band. It is an independent Reserve Bank, that is its job, and if inflation increases beyond the upper limit of that band the Reserve Bank has little choice but to act.The pre-election spending spree was 10.3 per cent in real terms in 2004, which was the fastest in more than 20 years. It is interesting to cast one’s mind back to when such a pre-election spending spree last occurred. It was, in fact, by the Fraser government, when John Howard was Treasurer of this country, when they sought in vain to get re-elected by making very large and expensive promises. It did not work in 1983 because Labor swept to power, but it has worked in the most recent election. But the problem is that the spending that is going on in this economy has been at such a rate that the capacity of the economy to supply the goods and services that are being demanded is now very limited.The government has failed to invest, in its nine years, in improving the capacity of the Australian economy to meet the demands associated with strong consumer spending. When strong consumer spending smashes up against a capacity constraint, it spills over in one of two ways—in Australia’s case, in both. The first is into imports. It is a matter of record that Australia now has recorded 41 successive trade deficits and record current account deficits, and the figures released today put the current account deficit at 7.25 per cent of GDP. This is a horrendously high level, far in excess of the level when Paul Keating warned of the dangers in the mid-1980s of Australia becoming a banana republic, and yet this government is completely complacent about a record current account deficit—a chronic current account deficit—which, again, is feeding into Australia’s international debt. In 1995 when the government rolled out its debt truck, Australia’s international net debt was $180 billion. Today figures reveal that it has climbed to $425 billion, more than doubling since the time that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer promised to follow policies that would bring foreign debt down.At that time both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer warned that at some point—and they believe that point had been reached when debt was $180 billion—foreign lenders would apply a risk premium to the interest rate that they charge Australia for borrowing such large amounts of money. Again, the Prime Minister has been condemned by his own rhetoric, by his own belief. Now, with foreign debt at $425 billion, foreign lenders are definitely applying a premium, because Australia has the third-highest interest rates in the Western world.If that is not bad enough, we are now in a situation where we are at the peak of a commodity price cycle. Commodity prices can only go down from here. The Australian dollar is a commodity currency. If you track the movements in the Australian dollar with commodity prices you will find a very close correlation. As the commodity price cycle has peaked, the risk for the exchange rate is that it will depreciate. A depreciating exchange rate will increase the cost in Australian dollar terms of goods imported from overseas—and we have lots of goods imported from overseas as a result of the spending spree spilling over into imports. If that happens we have a new source of inflation in Australia through a depreciating exchange rate.In the last couple of years the prices of domestically produced goods have risen above the Reserve Bank’s range at which it would need to act to increase interest rates. But the impact of an appreciating dollar as the commodity price cycle has gone up has been that there has been an offset to domestic inflation from overseas such that the overall consumer price index has remained within the range. Therefore, with that one exception of March 2005, the Reserve Bank has not been forced to increase interest rates. But now that the government has failed to respond to the capacity constraints and has poured fuel onto the spending fire, the risk of a depreciating currency means that those strong domestic price rises will not have an overseas offset but will be exacerbated by inflation from overseas.In those circumstances the Reserve Bank will have no choice but to increase interest rates. Recessions in this country have been caused essentially by the Reserve Bank acting too late to dampen spending and then having to put the brakes on too severely. That has caused recessions. The preconditions for a recession now exist in Australia. Am I saying that there will be a recession? I am not making that prediction, but I am saying that this government has substantially increased the risk of a recession. Ask BIS Shrapnel, who earlier in the week were forecasting mortgage interest rates of nine per cent. Mortgage interest rates of nine per cent would smash the Australian economy because of the very high levels of debt of most Australians who are trying to buy a home.One of the indicators of the state of the economy at the moment is that the unemployment rate is the lowest since 1976. That suggests a tight labour market—in fact, it is proof of a tight labour market. Another is that job vacancies are the highest in the 26-year history of job vacancies; again, pointing to a very tight labour market. There are labour shortages. Business is reporting labour shortages as a constraint on output. That particular indicator is the highest in the 15-year history of the survey. Capacity utilisation has just fallen away little, but from a 15-year high. Interestingly, over the years I have found the survey of consumer sentiment to be a very important indicator. The survey of consumer sentiment had reached record levels and then, when the quarter of a percentage point interest rate rise came through, it fell away. But now that people have gotten used to that interest rate rise, consumer sentiment has gone up again. In parliament today the Treasurer said that the latest retail sales figures suggest that consumer spending has now perhaps peaked and is starting to moderate. But the retail sales figures were all adjusted as a result of the Australian Bureau of Statistics having another look at those figures, and they were all revised upwards in the previous month. So there is plenty of evidence around of capacity constraints and of strong consumer spending.In respect of the housing market, a fundamental cause of the very high house prices—it is true they have peaked—is the large immigration program, which I support fundamentally. But the underlying contributor to the pressure on housing prices is an immigration program which has continued to increase in this year. I do not complain about that, I simply point out that house prices are unlikely to collapse, that they are moderating and there is a very significant possibility that they will increase in the coming months, if not in a year’s time.Put all those pieces together and you see the preconditions for an interest rate rise. The reality is that the government knew this. It knew when it was bringing down the budget that this was a very substantial risk. If you look at the statement of risks in the budget, you will see that it points to these sorts of risks. Why? Because Peter Costello does not write budget statement No. 1. The people who write budget statement No. 1 are the Treasury. The Treasury need to cover all possibilities so that no-one can say that they got it wrong.

name: Melham, Daryl, MP
content: —It is an honest disclosure.
