name: Emerson, Craig, MP
content: —It is honest disclosure. They do not want to be in a position where we as parliamentarians can say, ‘Treasury got it wrong.’ If you go through the fine print, you can see in the statement of risks that Treasury are fully aware of the potential consequences of this budget.Late last year, Martin Parkinson, a senior Treasury officer, gave a speech to an economic forum where he pointed out that any budget is just a series of point estimates. By that I interpret him to mean that you can only make your best guess about each of those things, but around each point there is a substantial risk. I am saying that, around the budget estimates, there are very substantial risks associated with the settings of that budget. I do not want it to be the case that, if interest rates rise, anyone can believe that Labor supported the budget. We did not. We did not support the budget on the grounds of equity—that is, the fairness of the tax cuts. I am putting on record again tonight that we do not support the budget on the grounds of macroeconomic management either.I want to go on to some of the longer term opportunities that were lost in this budget. We are talking about capacity constraints, a reform-lazy government that has surfed on the record productivity growth generated out of the economic reform program of the Hawke and Keating years. Wouldn’t you think that a government would say: ‘Wow, what a gift! This is tremendous. Hawke and Keating have unleashed this productivity growth for us. We’ll make sure we keep it going by investing in the new sources of productivity growth in the country: education and new ideas in the form of innovation and infrastructure.’ But a reform-lazy government has failed to do that. Those hard-won increases in productivity as a result of the reform program have now turned negative. In the year 2004, productivity growth in this country not only slowed; it turned negative. Some of that might be statistical aberration or cyclical factors—any such possibility—but if you were a government that was concerned about the long-term economic management of this country, you would be very worried about productivity growth turning negative when, again, our competitors around the world are making sure that they are investing in the new sources of productivity growth.What does this government have against government in public investment in education—public investment in schools, vocational education and universities? The fact of the matter is that with the most recent fee increases—25 per cent increases in HECS and an expanded system whereby up to 35 per cent of places at universities can now be taken by full-fee paying Australian students assisted by a scheme called FEE-HELP—the private returns from a university education are now getting to a point where it is just not worth it. Is this short-sighted? Of course it is. How could a government be so ideologically obsessed with private provision and funding of university education that it simply refuses to invest in access to universities in this country?So it has failed on the score of investing in the skills of this nation and in the area of research and development. Under the Hawke and Keating governments business spending on research and development, as a share of gross domestic product, skyrocketed and started making us competitive with other OECD countries, where the gap between their spending on research and development and ours was narrowing. But one of the first acts of this government when it came into office was to cut the R&D tax concession, and business spending on research and development as a share of GDP fell year after year. More recently it has lifted ever so slightly, but not relative to the rest of the world. So on the second score of investing in ideas the government has gone missing, deliberately and wantonly refusing to invest in that public good that is innovation and investment in ideas.The third area, probably the most noteworthy in terms of public commentary, is infrastructure. The government blames the states for infrastructure bottlenecks. There is no national infrastructure leadership in this country. What we need is a national infrastructure advisory committee and council, and we need a national infrastructure plan. It does not mean that the Commonwealth has to be the sole investor in infrastructure. The states obviously must do so. The private sector obviously must do so. But the Commonwealth should be taking a leadership role. Labor has been advocating a national infrastructure advisory council now for about three, maybe four, years. But for reasons best known to the government, probably ideological ones or a desire to shift the burden of infrastructure spending on to the states and away from the federal budget, it will not take even that sensible measure.Finally there is the area of incentives. The government talks about the need to give incentive to high-income earners to do extra work. It has lifted the threshold for the top marginal rate of tax to $125,000 a year. The government has been saying, ‘These people need more incentive because 48½c in the dollar is such a prohibitive marginal tax rate.’ Yet many people on lower and middle incomes are facing effective marginal tax rates of at least 60c in the dollar. Many of them face at least 60c in the dollar. I say that if 48½c in the dollar is a disincentive to work then surely 60c in the dollar is a disincentive to work and to participate in the economy.To achieve what we need to do to sustain prosperity in this country for a fair Australia, we must invest in the new sources of productivity growth and increase work force participation. The government’s response to work force participation is to do virtually nothing about those high effective marginal tax rates for low- and middle-income earners but to pick on single mothers and say to single mothers, ‘You must get out and work when your child turns six.’ But the wives of millionaires are actually paid to stay at home. What sort of incentive is that? On all reasonable criteria—economic management, equity, any capacity to look beyond the next election and invest in the nation’s future—this government’s 2005-06 budget is an abysmal failure.

name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
content: —The member for Rankin always says so many things that I practically do not have to bring my own speech to this place. As a person who has got a PhD in something—I am not sure what—it is interesting to hear him make some remarks regarding various aspects of government policy and the effect of overseas debt. He says that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer frequently made promises to follow policies that reduced the overseas debt. If you as a government reduce your own debt by $90 billion, what better policy could you follow? What he is really suggesting is that Prime Minister Howard should go on the John Laws show, predict death and confusion and the banana republic, and deliver the recession we had to have driven by 17 and 20 per cent interest rates. The member for Rankin is suggesting that that is good government policy to reduce overseas debt.Women are going out and buying themselves remarkably cheap Chinese clothing. Qantas, which is booming as one of the few profitable airlines in the world, might go out and buy another few 747s or 777s or a couple of airbuses. Of course we will borrow money from the rest of the world. The evidence is that they are delighted to lend it to us. But they are lending it to people who are making personal decisions about business or consumption, not to the government. I heard Prime Minister Keating or Treasurer Keating tell us time and time again, ‘The government are not borrowing from overseas.’ No; they just soaked up every dollar in savings that was floating around Australia and drove everybody in the private sector overseas.The real factor pointed out by the Prime Minister today is the fundamental fact that there is a simple test of the risk of overseas debt, and that is how much interest is being paid on that debt as a percentage of the nation’s exports. I understand that you are economically dead if that hits 27 per cent. That is apparently a huge danger signal. I read that many years ago and I will stand corrected, but it is about 27 per cent. The Keating government—and this is why I read it—got up to about 20 per cent. There was an article in the paper that said, ‘mate, you’re knocking on the door.’ The Prime Minister informed the parliament today that the current figure is nine per cent. I would imagine that is comfortable.The member for Rankin also talked about the Hawke-Keating reforms. I think in many respects they were excellent. They frequently followed policies that were espoused by the coalition election after election, policies that were criticised by the then government. But the big deal was, when they put their hands up to float the currency, we came out and said: ‘Good on you.’ I wonder what the response of the present opposition would be if that situation confronted us today. If they were to support the process, it would be about the first thing they have supported in nine years.The same applies with tariff cuts. When you are too scared of your base constituency, or at least of those who have a huge influence on your preselection, you do not go out and write the appropriate industrial law that, as reported in the media the other day, puts up the wages of a dozer driver in the Pilbara by $20,000 and gives that dozer driver access to staff superannuation; you do not do that. You have to find something that confuses the proletariat, so you drop tariffs. It is a nice blunt instrument. I am all in favour of it in a properly ordered way. But the massive drops of the Whitlam and Hawke governments just sent a simple message to workers that said, ‘If you don’t do something and readjust your wage demands, your job will go to China or Thailand or somewhere like that.’Another difficult thing is the sale of assets. The member sitting opposite knows very well that if we as a coalition in opposition had tried one iota of mischief on the sale of the Commonwealth Bank it would never have gone through caucus. But, as I remind people constantly, whilst the previous government borrowed $80 billion in pursuit of retaining office, they also sold tens of billions of assets and spent that money too. That is not what we did.Having said those things, it is interesting that the member for Rankin wanted to talk about public investment in education. What is happening out there in Australia? People are voting with their feet. They do not want public education. Many of them—sometimes with extreme financial pressure to their family budgets—are moving their children to private schools. Now, in a last line of defence, the Queensland government is legislating to ban for-profit schools. If there are people in our community who think the best opportunity for their kids is for them to go and pay money to a for-profit organisation and if we as the taxing agent can get a bit of that money back as a consequence of any profits made, what is wrong with that? This is an important process. We live with this myth that, unless the government provides the service, the service will not be provided.Every state education budget now represents 50 per cent of revenue from the Australian taxpayer, which is half the cost of educating a kid in a state school. I keep asking why we cannot just send the equivalent of the Australian government’s contribution to education to parents by way of a voucher which would be restricted to being cashed at school. Similar things have been done in other areas. Why can’t we say that ordinary Australians do not need a nanny state? I am arguing with my side of politics. We apparently think that people are so deficient in numeracy that, when an airline puts in a newspaper prices of airfares that need to be added up to get a total, the government should do it for them. That is going to create a few problems for small business, who might make a mistake one day and find the ACCC dropping on their head. I have already received communication, which I have circulated today, from the liquor industry saying, ‘Just how do we do that with WET and GST and all the other things that we are supposed to incorporate, which we now put in separately and say, “This is our price plus”?’ As I said, if you want to keep people thinking, maybe you can give them the odd arithmetic problem.I close my remarks in response to the member for Rankin’s comments by saying that we keep being told that the tax rate for somebody re-entering the work force can be as high as 60c to 70c. That is true. But there are all sorts of people out there working—functional families, a husband and wife with a couple of kids, both parents working, both paying taxes. There now seems to be an argument that, when a job becomes available which could be filled by a person who is not working and who is receiving payments due to the generosity of the taxpayer, we should bribe them into taking the job. They are only moving into the same situation as another person who is working in that form of employment. They have not had a job so the government, on behalf of the people, says, ‘Here is assistance for you.’ Of course, that is the nature of Australia. But if someone rings them up or puts an ad in the paper and they take a job, should we add half the assistance that was provided for their previous circumstances, at the cost of other taxpayers, simply because they have taken a job? I do not think we should. I think it is a mythical argument that we have created, and we have got all sorts of people trying to put up solutions. Why not say to everybody on a low income, ‘Keep half the equivalent of unemployment benefits’? You would not do that. I do not think it is an argument we might have to have. I think we are all convinced about it. But it has started to come to me as, ‘Why do I have to pay people to go back into the work force to actually assume a benefit that is different?’I want to touch on a particular couple of issues in the budget. A lot of people have said things about the new tax rates, and I will spend time on that. I have looked at this Welfare to Work proposal and I congratulate the government on what they are doing. I have received quite a lot of correspondence from people who say that they are single mothers who have a responsibility to their children and that they could not fulfil that responsibility if they were in the work force. I have two married daughters and one daughter-in-law, who are all in the work force, as are their husbands. One has two beautiful daughters, who are very well adjusted and very bright. Another has a son and I think he is a bit like me; he is a bit harder to describe. He is a lovely boy; and his mother works. My third daughter, who is younger, is expecting and I am delighted about that. She is the chief vet of the Western Australian racing industry—a very demanding and highly regarded job. And her husband works.All these families have the problems of getting their kids to school, getting them home and worrying about them. Sometimes someone says to me, ‘Well, I don’t have to be like those other women who work.’ But why do they work? To get on—and to send their kids to private schools, I might add. These are the issues. It is unfair to say: ‘I’m different because I’m a welfare recipient. I’m different from all those who work.’ I do not think welfare recipients are different. But, in order to accommodate both functional families and other, broken families, I cannot see why government is not taking more initiatives to encourage business et cetera to create more opportunities to work from home.In my time as minister for local government, I gave local government a $30,000 grant simply to go out and see how many of their staff positions could operate from home with modern technology. As an example, I am told that in the country town of Bunbury, which is represented by the member for Forrest, there is a Centrelink call centre with 300 employees. Why don’t we decentralise that call centre? We are having a good season in my electorate of O’Connor, but with good broadband why can’t some of the farmers’ wives or farmers who are presently in drought conditions sit at home doing their shift in a decentralised call centre?I had a visit from the institute of planners, drawing to my attention the recognised great shortage of town planners. I mentioned this survey I had given money to local government to conduct and the fellow said, ‘If that were available now and people could work from home, there would be no shortage of town planners.’ There are people out there, taking the family option, who have the skills and qualifications to be town planners and, unless you have a face-to-face job in local government, you can do that from anywhere with modern technology.There is a challenge for government to look at opportunities for married women and single women, including women who are no longer with a spouse—or, for that matter, women who are supporting husbands—to work from home. If they work four hours a day at home, they will net as much money as they would from going to work for eight hours a day if they had to pay for child care and those sorts of things. I make those sorts of points as examples of where we can have our cake and eat it too.I have spoken on personal tax cuts at length in recent times. I welcome wholeheartedly the measures of this budget and these appropriation bills, but the quicker we get rid of 42 and 45 the better. There is a myth in society. An anonymous email was read this morning. Let me say to the Labor members present: I do not think the Labor Party realise how many of their constituents, particularly in this town, are in those wage categories. They are not pleased with you—not pleased with you at all. There is a view in the Labor Party that, when you earn $25,000-plus a year, you vote Liberal. In fact, in the modern day, very large numbers of people on very high salaries do not vote Liberal, but they are pretty interested in how much stays in their pocket. I have never employed any person who did not at some time say to me: ‘Thank you for that offer, but what do I get in the hand? How much am I going to take home to my family?’ That is of fundamental interest, and I do not blame them for it.In these higher salary groups, if the tax burden and the add-ons get too high, the jobs will go to India. Government is a major contributor to the cost of employing people. We had better be careful about it because, when you get some high-quality person in your office to an interview and you start talking wages, they want to know how much is left for them. If you have to build that with huge tax burdens, you will start to say, ‘Oh, I can ring up IBM and they will get me some bloke,’ or there are Indian companies running around Australia now. They are the problems. It is no longer a world where certain things are ours because you would have to send gold bars to England to buy the alternative product. If we do not take note of that, we will not do people any favours.I read the other day that if Malcolm Fraser’s arrangements for indexing the tax thresholds, which were implemented I think when I was here, had been retained, the top marginal tax rate would now commence at about $270,000. That is evidence of bracket creep. A little while ago I heard certain representatives of the frontbench of the Labor Party complaining about bracket creep and saying that we were screwing the public. I have to agree: I think we are. But we should not be having this debate about what some people earn, the tax cut they get in absolute terms and what somebody else gets. If you want to have that debate it has got to be in percentage terms.It used to be said, comparing an American with someone living in the United Kingdom, that when someone living in the United Kingdom saw someone in a Rolls-Royce they would say, ‘I will get that bloke out of that one day,’ while in America that they would say, ‘I will own one of them one day.’ I think the psyche of Australians today is that we all aspire to something better and we are not jealous about the person who has got it. We should not be trying to get this argument up again. I think it is bad policy. We are not doing it. We are only part of the way as far as I am concerned. I will not go any further into how we can retain a reasonable budget.In that regard, the back page of the Financial Review quoted a Dr Sinclair Davidson of RMIT, who pointed out that the lowest 25 per cent taxpayers contribute 3.1 per cent of the tax collected, the middle group of taxpayers contribute 32.8 per cent, while the top 25 per cent of taxpayers contribute 64.1 per cent. People who earn over $100,000 or more account for 3.5 per cent of the population yet pay 25 per cent of all net income tax. I am not sure that that is entirely fair and I am not sure that it is smart. I do not know why we keep getting dragged into that particular argument and, for those who think it might give them a political advantage, I do not think it is resonating with the Australian people. I favour these tax cuts and I will go on arguing that the best way to get out of all the tax schemes that often trap people is to harmonise the company tax rate and the highest marginal tax rate. There are ways of achieving that. When we get to that our society will be better off. Someone made the silly remark the other day in Queensland that a flat 15 per cent for rural workers would be a good idea. There are not too many rural workers who pay a flat 15 per cent. That is further evidence of it. (Time expired)
Speaker: N/A

name: Ripoll, Bernie, MP
content: —I rise today to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and cognate bills. It is amazing that, when we get to these appropriation bills, which are bills about taxes and the things that the government has done in the budget, government members—and I have listened to quite a few of them speak—barely mention the budget, the tax cuts and the details of how good it supposedly will be for their own constituents. There may be an explanation as to why government members are not spending a lot of time explaining how good the tax cuts are. It may be because they are not really that good at all. They talk about looking at it in percentage terms and in dollars. I do not really care whether government members raise it in percentages, in dollars or whatever. The reality is that a lot of people are realising that what they are getting is basically a couple of stubbies worth of a tax cut while people in the top bracket are getting a full buffet, a bottle of wine and a sixpack as well. I am also yet to hear many government members talk about how good this is for them, but I will get to that a little later.This budget was meant to be about Australia’s future. It was meant to be about trying to make Australia a more productive and efficient country and a better place for everybody, where people who work hard are rewarded more. I agree with a lot of the sentiments put forward by government members, by our members and by a lot of people who say, ‘Reward for work, reward for effort.’ I have no issue at all with that principle and that concept. The Labor Party is based on the principle of reward for effort and reward for work. But we do not see that in the budget. What we see are two principles, two ideologies. One ideology within the budget is very clear: it is the argument from the government and from Peter Costello that, to give people at the top end of the brackets the incentive to work harder, you need to give them bigger and bigger tax cuts and to reward them more.We just heard the member for O’Connor talk about what he believes to be middle and high and low, and he has it all over the place. These days when we talk about ‘the middle’, we are talking about anyone on $30,000, $40,000 or $50,000, right up to $80,000 or $90,000. The world has changed, and maybe a few government members should have a closer look at what people are earning in the middle. The ideology of the government in the budget with regard to the middle to lower end is that, to get them to work harder, you need a bigger stick: ‘We’re going to take more off you and we’re going to make it harder for you, because that’s the only thing you understand.’ That is what the government says to people.People will work this out. People will feel this, as the tax cuts start to come through from 1 July. People will start to understand that they are not really getting much of a difference. It is very little. It is always welcome; there is no doubt about that. I am being sensible about this: of course people welcome tax cuts. They would welcome it if you gave them one dollar, but it does not mean they are overly happy about it. It just means you are giving them back a little in return for the masses you have taken from them. In the history of this parliament, there has never been so much money, so much revenue, come into these chambers as now. It is the rivers of revenue that flow into Canberra in unprecedented proportions that can feed the huge surpluses and that can go back in the form of tax cuts. I would have been much more impressed with the tax cuts if they were more about tax reform. I think that is where we should have gone.The issues I have just spoken about are what the budget is about. It should have been about Australia’s future but it was really all about Peter Costello’s future. It was about him putting forward an agenda to demonstrate to his party room colleagues that he is the man to lead; that he as the Treasurer is the person who can deliver massive tax cuts—in terms of the totality, nearly $24 billion—and give the majority, the biggest bulk, the biggest chunk, to high-income earners. Those who are rewarded the most are people who sit in this chamber. I as well as everybody else in this chamber will get the biggest windfall out of this budget, and people will work this out. They will understand that the people who won out of this budget more than anybody else are those on the highest of high incomes—in that top three per cent, as the member for O’Connor said. Only three per cent of taxpayers in Australia earn more than $125,000 and yet they will by far get the largest chunk of the tax cuts.In this budget, Peter Costello’s focus was not on the Australian economy. It was not on efficiency; it was not on productivity and growth or fixing up bottlenecks. It was not on any of those things. It was not about making us a stronger, more robust, resilient economy into the future for the next 15 years. It was all about him, the Treasurer. It was about his personal ambition. It was about him making a statement to his backbench that he will make up for things that might have been lost in previous times.I am not the only person to have that view. Government members opposite might not be surprised at this, but former Liberal Party leader Dr John Hewson had this to say in the Australian Financial Review on 13 May 2005:This budget was much more about Costello attempting to build broader political support for his claim on the leadership than it was about setting a detailed medium-term policy agenda ...In short, the Treasurer was paving the way, with the rivers of revenue from taxpayers’ hip pockets, for his tilt at the top job. We know it is a little quiet in the Liberal Party at the moment but it is not too far away. The Treasurer really does not have too many choices, does he? He can be just a complete wimp on this issue and just not bother—why did he even drag people to this point?—or at some stage he has to make a move. We are all watching. We will watch this space.As I said, this budget and this government were about the tax cuts in themselves; they were not about tax reform. Tax reform is what the business community has been asking for, and that is what people on middle, low and high incomes have been asking for. Let us have a look at a real agenda to make the economy stronger and make our tax system a fairer tax system, and let us reward effort and work. Let us do it through a better tax system.There is an unprecedented amount that is being spent, but what is also unprecedented is the unfairness of that which is being spent on tax cuts. People need to remember that the reason the government is giving back such a chunk is that they have taken more than they have ever taken before, and it is not about to end. Future predictions of revenue to government through taxes are phenomenal and like nothing we have seen in the past. It is simply an unfair, unbalanced budget, and I believe that Australians deserve a better, fairer deal and that it can be easily achieved. In the words of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, they deserve a new deal. They deserve a new deal, because they deserve more than the $6.I know government members will laugh, but let me put it to you in these terms, which are quite simple. For the same impost on the budget, the same money—no extra—and without putting a burden or upward pressure on interest rates, you can deliver real tax reform to ordinary Australians, people earning up to $70,000, $80,000, $90,000 a year. You can give them not just $6; you can double it and give them $12. But that is only if members of parliament on the government side—the Liberal and National party members—are prepared to slightly cut their own tax cut. I just cannot see that happening. I cannot see that out of the goodness of their hearts they will walk into this place and say: ‘Hang on; these guys have actually got a point. Rather than pocketing $65, I’ll still get a fairly big tax cut, but a little bit less will be enough to redistribute down to the people who need it. There would be a decent impact on the economy, and it would give them double. I think that is a fair trade; I think that would actually work pretty well.’ They could do that.We are not opposing tax cuts. Where did the government get that crazy idea? We are putting forward a better, new deal on tax cuts—a $12 tax cut. We are saying to the government, ‘Support Labor’s agenda on tax cuts and give people $12 not $6.’ We are not about delaying or somehow making it harder in terms of tax; we want the tax cuts. We want to make it fair, and we want people to get a decent tax cut of $12, not $6, and at the same time deliver some genuine tax reform.People mention all that stuff about bracket creep and they talk about how any real gains we are getting are being whittled away. This is not even to mention what the Reserve Bank, the IMF, the OECD and a range of other credible institutions have said. They have made it quite plain and clear that delivering a $24 billion injection into the economy through these types of tax cuts will put upward pressure on interest rates. So one week people will get a $6 tax cut in their back pocket and the following week the Reserve Bank of Australia will be moving to put up interest rates and they will lose more than they will gain. Does the government believe that is fair? Those tax cuts will be eaten away in two ways: one, through interest rate increases and two, through bracket creep and inflation. There is no real incentive in terms of a decent tax cut for people from this government.I believe that a much fairer and more reasonable position would be to service the vast majority of Australians. I will give you some examples. This one is quite simple. In my electorate of Oxley the government are denying around 92 per cent of my electors a decent tax cut of $12 just because they want to keep their own tax cuts in their own pockets. I could go around this chamber and name almost every member in this regard—except, perhaps, three in the wealthier suburbs on the North Shore of Sydney who would not be in that category. Most government members are denying around 80 per cent to 90 per cent of their constituents fair and decent tax cuts.Again I want to turn just briefly to what Dr John Hewson had to say in terms of where the government is in relation to this budget and tax cuts. He said:Although the government would claim to be a tax reforming government, it has not really bitten the bullet of genuine tax reform. It has just danced around it.That was in the Australian Financial Review on 13 May 2005. So somebody of standing in the business community and in the Liberal Party such as Dr John Hewson also confirms that there just is not any real tax reform. This government claims to be the government of great tax reformers and so forth, but when you look at its record it does not stand. Where is the tax reform? Where are the great changes that will need to be made? It smacks of a lack of leadership. What we have seen is a lack of leadership. This economy and this country need solid leadership into the future.It is not by accident that we enjoy good economic times under this government. It was not the making of this government. They inherited it from the previous government. Any economist will tell you and anybody who is worth their weight in salt will show you that the easy figures on this 15-year economic growth did not come from the nine years of government from this mob. This mob inherited it. Even the Prime Minister said in 1996 that it was an economy ‘better in part than most’. He inherited a decent economy, an economy that had the fundamentals and the principles right. It was an economy built for sustainability into the future. It was built for growth and built to deliver the sorts of returns the government can now enjoy.It takes a very brave and courageous government and people with some fortitude and vision to take the hard decisions. They will hurt and often you will pay a political price for taking tough decisions. Tough decisions never come cheap. Sometimes the political price is losing office. But the reality is that you set the course for the next 20 years, a generation away from where you are today, for the future. That is what this government should do. I would not bemoan it if this government came into this place with a decent reform agenda on taxation. They would probably be very surprised. They would get a very supportive attitude from our side, from Labor, because we are trying to push for reform. The business community wants reform and I can tell you that taxpayers certainly want reform, but we are seeing no leadership in this area.There is another area where we see no leadership. A great opportunity has been missed in budget after budget, and we wait in hope. People wait in hope for leadership in terms of infrastructure. Infrastructure is a bit of a buzzword around the place and I do not want to overuse it in this chamber. But the reality is that Labor has been talking about infrastructure for years—to deaf ears in the government, I have to say. We have been talking about all sorts of infrastructure that drive our economy. But what have we seen from this government? The best they could come up with was AusLink, commonly known around the traps as ‘AusStink’ because there is not much in it. It is $12 billion, a substantial amount of money, but let us put that into context. Let us weigh up ‘AusStink’ on one hand with what the Queensland state government is doing in just one part of Queensland. I see the member for Maranoa in here and I do not think he could disagree with me if I said to him that a $55 billion state infrastructure plan legislated for—the first of its kind in Australia—actually delivers certainty. It actually gives the economy in Queensland a decent place to go into the future. It gives us direction.

name: Ripoll, Bernie, MP
content: —But it is the south-east Queensland infrastructure plan. So if the member for Maranoa wants to interject and tell me it is about the south-east corner, I would say to him: you are right because it is called the south-east Queensland infrastructure plan.
Speaker: N/A

name: Scott, Bruce, MP
content: —What about the rest?
Speaker: N/A

name: Ripoll, Bernie, MP
content: —He must not read the newspapers because the rest is simple. It is $55 billion on top of everything else the state government is spending. It is a decent and large investment in the Queensland people and in the Queensland economy. It is about roads, bridges, ports and airports. It is about ensuring a future for Queensland. Anyone who looks at the Queensland economy will agree that it has a very bright future. If only we could convince the leader of this country, the Prime Minister, to take on board some sort of comparatively weighted infrastructure plan for this country. If south-east Queensland alone—and, as I said before, I will take the interjection of the member for Maranoa—can spend $55 billion and have a 20-year strategic plan, why can’t Australia do that? Why can we not see this country take some leadership on some of these issues and give us some comparatively weighted infrastructure?I have heard the Treasurer, Peter Costello, bleating to us many times in this place about Dalrymple Bay. But what does he offer? One day we hear him bleating about it and then he comes into the chamber today and says, ‘Oh, they’ve actually done something about it and they’re going to have it done in two years time.’ Can the Treasurer do it faster? I do not think so. Has he offered any money? No. Has he offered any concrete criticism, anything positive, anything we can do to make Dalrymple Bay a more efficient port? No, he has not. All he is offering is criticism. He is not offering a solution.What do we hear John Anderson, the Deputy Prime Minister, say? He goes off and bleats about Dalrymple Bay without knowing what he is talking about. He starts talking about regulation and bringing in the ACCC. The same day he cops a backhander from the Prime Minister and has to apologise to the whole country and recant on what he said. Do you know why he had to recant? He had to recant because he did not know what he was talking about. I was completely offended by the Deputy Prime Minister talking about Dalrymple Bay, something he knows nothing of. All he knows is that 40 ships are sitting off the coast. Anyone could tell you that because they are sitting out there. But it is a much more complex and involved issue and, if people looked at it more closely, they would understand what has been taking place.Yes, I have some criticisms about what has been taking place, but something is being done. It did not take the federal government to do it; it took the Queensland state government to do it. They are working towards a solution now with prime infrastructure. But all we get from this government is criticism. You do not get a positive outcome. You do not get a solution. You do not get some sort of suggestion saying, ‘Okay, let’s work together. Let’s work in a partnership. Let’s find what we need to do to make this economy stronger and grow.’ No.

Speaker: N/A

name: Ripoll, Bernie, MP
content: —All we get is a whole range of criticism and government members talking about their embarrassment. I would be embarrassed too if I were a government member on this. I will take the interjection from the member for Cook. I would be embarrassed too if I were he, a government member, because he knows nothing of what is happening in the ports around this country—and he should know something. But we get the Treasurer speaking about it and we get a whole heap of people talking about it from the government side, but they offer nothing.In contrast to that, Labor does have ideas. We have a plan. We have a way forward for this country. One plan is in the form of infrastructure Australia, a national body which would coordinate work in partnership with the states. It would form part of a standing agenda item on the Coalition of Australian Governments. It would give us a point of reference, a peak body, to work in conjunction with the states.

name: Ripoll, Bernie, MP
content: —Again government members like to interject when I talk about the states, but what more could this country do but work in partnership with the states? Is there something wrong with working in partnership or is it just because the states are Labor? So you do not really care about the people; you just care about the politics—is that right? Is that what government members are telling me? It is not about the people of the states; it is about the government of the states. So you are more concerned about the politics than you are about the issues. It is really disappointing that members of the government have that view because I think there is a real opportunity for us to work with the states and with the federal government regardless of their political colour and personal ideologies to make a difference for this economy, to show leadership, to give us infrastructure reform, to lead the way and not just talk about it but provide some action. That is what we need in this country.

name: Scott, Bruce, MP
content: —I rise tonight in the budget debate to talk about the further privatisation of Telstra. It has been on our agenda since we were elected in 1996, and at subsequent elections we have gone to the people of Australia saying that we continue our policy of looking to the further privatisation of Telstra. I will seek to table some documents during my address. I have checked with the opposition and they are quite happy. The documents I wish to refer to and table during my speech follow my study trip to New Zealand looking at the issue of privatisation of Telstra—what has happened in New Zealand and the comparison between the regulatory regime in New Zealand and Australia. There is quite a clear document which identifies the differences between the two regulatory regimes. Also there are some press clippings in relation to some of the things I will refer to tonight.Many in this House would know that the electorate of Maranoa is primarily a rural electorate. It is important that all of us in this House represent the concerns of our constituents. After all, they sent us to Canberra and it is our duty to make sure that their concerns are raised in whatever forums are appropriate, including our party forums. I will be raising some of those issues in my address tonight.To begin with, who could forget the state of affairs this government was left to deal with when we came to government in 1996, after 13 years of Hawke and Keating Labor government? I want to remind the House that in 1996, when the coalition came to government, not only were we left with a $96 billion debt, high interest rates and high unemployment but Labor had also deserted regional, rural and remote Australia, particularly in relation to basic telecommunication services and infrastructure. The Labor government had not only neglected the Australian economy but also abandoned the people who live in rural and remote parts of Australia.Telecommunications is an essential service for all Australians. It enables families to keep in contact with each other and allows businesses to conduct their day-to-day operations more efficiently. With the latest telecommunications infrastructure, school students can research their assignments on the internet. Tourists are more likely to visit if they can stay in touch with their families. In reality, the list of benefits from quality, world-class communications infrastructure is endless. Unfortunately, people in rural and remote parts of Australia are simply not always privy to—and have not been in the past—the same essential services that are accessible to people in urban and suburban parts of Australia. An inequity exists between city and country with regard to communications, and we as a government have been trying to close that digital divide.We all know that profits are the bottom line. That is the nature of any business; we understand that. Since Telstra were made a government business enterprise, they have had to make sure that they did not undertake any unviable business propositions. That was one of their responsibilities when they were corporatised in 1991. Telstra will still freely tell you today that, whatever they invest in, it is going to have to show a business return to Telstra in the near future. Sometimes that is four or five years away, but they have seen that as one of their very important charters since corporatisation. Unfortunately, this will all too often become the catchcry of a fully privatised Telstra. It is for this sole reason that the government must safeguard the people of the bush prior to the full sale of Telstra.Since coming to government we have done a great deal. I want to outline some of those things tonight. Many people in rural Australia have vivid memories of the privatisation of government business enterprises in the past. The Labor Party privatised the Commonwealth Bank and TAA, and they were necessary reforms, which we supported when we were in opposition. For that very reason, the people of rural and remote Australia know that when it happens it is all about the business bottom line. You have to make sure when you do that—and in this case when Telstra is fully privatised—that you put in place regulations to ensure that future services will not deteriorate. That is the fundamental concern that people of rural and remote Australia have. They know that we have done a great deal since coming to government. They know that it is our duty, and my duty as the member for Maranoa, to make sure that we future-proof communications services and grant access to new technologies as they become available in the future.I remember also that when Labor was in government they abolished, in law, a perfectly good mobile phone technology—the analogue service. It was working well. It reached further than many of our newer technologies because of its power and the type of system that it was. That technology was abolished by law without there being a replacement. I said earlier in my address that the people of rural and remote Australia are still well aware of the Labor government’s record, not only in their management of the economy but also because they took away a perfectly good mobile technology and did not have any plan to replace it or to provide funds to make sure that a new technology was rolled out.Since coming to government we have assisted in closing the digital divide that exists between city and country in telecommunications in Australia. Among other achievements we have had the Besley and Estens inquiries. Following the Besley inquiry a major fund was established called Networking the Nation. The Estens inquiry brought forward many recommendations which we as a government are still rolling out today and the money for which has been provided in the budget to ensure that communications advances continue to be made in rural, regional and remote areas of Australia. Following both those inquiries and the money that we have provided, we have seen substantial improvements in telecommunications infrastructure and I want to mention a few of those tonight.We have been able to inject some $1 billion of capital into infrastructure and the roll-out of new technologies. My own electorate has seen the roll-out of the extended zone contract for untimed local calls. When we came to government there were still 40,000 subscribers—and I know you had some in Tasmania, Deputy Speaker Quick—who still paid for timed local calls. So often I would hear people say, ‘All Australians have access to untimed local calls.’ That was wrong. Telstra needed money to put in new infrastructure so that those communities who for generations had timed local calls were able to access untimed local calls, like 99.9 per cent of Australians. That came as part of the extended zone contract. Being the successful tenderer, Telstra added value to their competitive tender by making available to those communities a two-way satellite which gave them access to the Internet, which was otherwise unavailable. That was a tremendous contract and a great step forward in technology for those many subscribers in rural and remote parts of Australia.The roll-out of the CDMA technology for mobile phones has been a magnificent replacement for analogue. The funding from the federal government enabled the roll-out of this technology in areas where the analogue system used to be. That roll-out has been expanded because of an injection of federal government capital into areas where mobile phone coverage was previously not available.The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts recently visited my electorate to view the latest communications technology in action. This technology has been made available following the Besley inquiry and the injection of more than $1 billion into communications infrastructure around Australia, particularly rural and remote parts of Australia. The minister was terribly impressed with what she saw. When she visited at a property north of Longreach in my electorate she saw three small children participating in a school lesson. What was so exciting about this was that, while it may be commonplace in the city to see children participating in a school lesson, I can assure you that it has not been a normal scene in rural parts of Australia.These three small children were located some 80 kilometres north of Longreach on their family property and were conducting their school lessons via the internet. The internet was connected via the two-way satellite. As I mentioned earlier, that came as part of the extended zone contract at no cost to this family or those who got connected through this technology. And they were using the telephone that comes through the wireless local loop as the clear voice signal. The wireless local loop, the CDMA technology, replaced the DRCS. The telephone call was a local untimed call to the Longreach School of Distance Education. So here were these students doing their school lessons 80 kilometres away from where the teacher was. There were students a further 200 kilometres away on the other side of Longreach, connected via the internet, via two-way satellite, using a clear voice signal. It was magnificent, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker Quick—I am sure you can appreciate the scene.How it has changed, and only in the last few years. These students for decades and decades, until only a few years ago, did their school lessons over an HF radio system. On HF radio only one person could talk at once, and sometimes when atmospheric conditions were poor they could not even make contact with their teacher. This is a magnificent example of how the government’s communications fund money has been used to tremendous advantage to bridge that digital divide. To see young children being able to utilise world-class technology to gain access to education was certainly invigorating.There is still a long way to go to bridge this divide between city and country. In some parts of my electorate people still have a single-channel radio service as their main trunk route. What this means is that this technology does not have the capacity to allow for the installation of mobile phones in these communities. There is not the bandwidth capacity to be able to put mobile phones in places like Birdsville, Bedourie, Windorah and Jundah. In fact, you might have heard of those at question time today. The Minister for Small Business and Tourism answered a question from me today about how tourism is growing in these remote parts of Australia. She talked about the jobs that are being generated because of the tourism growth in this part of Queensland. I know it is similar in many parts of Australia. It is not just confined to the western part of my electorate. Those communities will not be able to have hand-held mobile phones while ever a single-channel radio system is their connection to the main trunk routes into the main network across Australia.

name: Hall, Jill, MP
content: —Thank you very much. Listening to you talk about the single-channel radio and the problems that your constituents have with mobile phones, I was wondering: have they expressed any opinion to you about the sale of Telstra? What strategies will you have in place to ensure that they have the proper coverage that they need once the government sells Telstra?
Speaker: N/A

name: Scott, Bruce, MP
content: —That is exactly the question I am addressing in my budget address-in-reply speech tonight. I have certainly been out with them. I am talking about what we have done to bridge that digital divide and to replace the analogue service that was legislated by a Labor government to be abolished, what we have replaced it with and what we have done to bring modern communications into these small rural and remote communities. I said a moment ago that we have got more to do, that our job is not over. My job as the member for Maranoa is not complete, hence my speech tonight.Telstra Country Wide has been one of the most wonderful things that Telstra have done. I am sure that you found that in your home state, Mr Deputy Speaker. They put the face of Telstra back into the communities. They had walked away from those communities. They thought that people of rural Australia and those remote communities would always be loyal—they could go to Brisbane, Sydney and Hobart, and people would always stick with them.I can assure you that the people out there were very disappointed when that happened. It happened over many years, including under previous governments. But we have addressed that by law to make sure that Telstra has a face, which is one of the recommendations of the Estens inquiry—that they have a physical presence in 39 regions around Australia. They understand the geography and they understand the people, and that is why I have to say that Telstra Country Wide has done a magnificent job. My time is going to run out if I do not move very quickly to what I saw in New Zealand; hence I seek leave to table the documents in relation to the reports on what I saw in New Zealand.Leave granted.
Speaker: N/A

name: Scott, Bruce, MP
content: —In New Zealand, I found exactly the same circumstances as exist in Australia. There are about 10 to 15 per cent of subscribers who they flag as non-viable business market opportunities. In other words, they have to be covered by a universal service obligation just as ours have to be in Australia, but many of these are in my electorate and rural and remote parts of Australia. There are many concerns from farmers who are living in these non-commercially viable markets in New Zealand, and that concern also resonates here in Australia. That is covered in the reports of my visit to New Zealand.What we have to do as we move to the further privatisation of Telstra is give confidence to the people of rural and remote Australia, wherever they live, that we are going to ensure that, through future proofing, they are not left behind again. They have been left behind before—not just by something that previous governments might not have done; it dates back in history, and I do not want to point the finger at anyone in that regard—and we have a responsibility to make sure they are not left behind in the future.The challenge confronting the government is that there are parts of Australia where commercial markets will not provide for new and improved services and infrastructure, because it is simply not a good business proposition for the carrier. The same applied in New Zealand. My fundamental concern as the member for Maranoa is to ensure general parity of pricing and equity of services between city and country post the full privatisation of Telstra. This includes connections of new services currently covered by price averaging and should include the cost of satellite internet infrastructure.I would require a minimum of three pillars to ensure future parity, with the first to establish a trust fund using the proceeds from the sale of Telstra for future technology upgrades. This fund would be dedicated to providing for any future upgrades to technology and/or infrastructure in rural and remote Australia and would be made available through a competitive tender. The second would be the establishment of a rural and remote independent telecommunications advisory board, which would need to report annually on service levels and conduct regular reviews on the standards of service every three years or when deemed necessary. Furthermore, I would like to see Telstra Country Wide being required by law to maintain a physical presence in rural and remote Australia as a condition of licence. (Time expired)

name: Hall, Jill, MP
content: —The Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and cognate bills we are debating here in the House tonight are related to a budget of missed opportunity, a budget under which the people of Shortland have fared very badly. It always makes me feel very sad when I rise in this House and see legislation that has been brought to the parliament that disadvantages the people I am elected to support in this House. There were just a couple of things that I thought the government could have provided to the people of Shortland that would not have been too big an impost for them.For a very long time, we in Shortland have been fighting for the government to reopen the Medicare office in Belmont. I have submitted somewhere in the vicinity of 20,000 signatures supporting the reopening of that office. It is in an area that supports an elderly population. It is in an area where there is a low level of bulk-billing. It is in an area where people really need to be able to access a Medicare office. But, unfortunately, the government was not prepared to move beyond its political agenda and provide that to the people in an area of great need—where 40 per cent of the people actually vote for the government.I think sometimes the government forget that there are a significant number of people who live within Labor electorates who actually vote for the government. If they have the mentality of only supporting and looking after those people who vote for them then they are ignoring the 40 per cent of the people there whose votes they got. I find it unbelievable that in this parliament the government can totally ignore people in an electorate that is not a Liberal held electorate.The problems that have existed at the University of Newcastle are well known in this House. They are problems that the minister has chosen to ignore. The University of Newcastle has three campuses: two in the Hunter and one on the Central Coast, the Ourimbah campus. I recently attended a meeting at the Ourimbah campus. That is in the electorate of the member for Dobell. I was really surprised when I found out that he was not in attendance at that meeting. Those young people attend an institution in the electorate that he represents, and I have not seen him standing up in this parliament fighting for that university to be assisted in its time of trouble.The third electorate-specific issue I will quickly touch on is Energy Australia Stadium, the home of the Newcastle Knights—a stadium that the Howard government has continually refused to support in any shape or form. It is interesting that it can find money to support a stadium at Penrith, a perceived marginal electorate, in the lead-up to the last election, but it totally ignores the needs of the people of the Hunter—people who are absolutely football mad, devoted to their team—and is prepared to let them have a second-class facility. It is very selective. Once again, it is a government that looks after its mates but totally ignores all other Australians, and I will go through a few issues here that will highlight some of my concerns.I started my contribution by saying that this is a budget of missed opportunities. It is a budget that ignores the fact that its answer to solving the skills shortage has been to import 20,000 workers from overseas. The problem we have had with the skills shortage has been in existence for some time. Towards the end of last year, I spoke on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill. In my contribution to the debate on that bill, I highlighted how the government’s inaction over a long period of time had resulted in this enormous skills shortage. I went through a report prepared by the Australian Industry Group which highlighted the shortages that existed in the Hunter and how small to medium businesses were having a great deal of difficulty in attracting the kinds of workers who had the skills to address the shortage.This situation has been allowed to develop over a long period of time. The government has actively allowed our training system to run down. One of the first acts of the Howard government was to rip money out of the TAFE system in all states. The result of this is a situation where you have fewer and fewer people able to access training.In this contribution, I have referred to the DEWR skill vacancy index of 2003-04 to look at some of the areas where there are skills shortages and some of the occupations where vacancies just cannot be filled. There has been a 38 per cent increase in the number of vacancies in the electrical and electronic trades. There has been a 21 per cent increase in the number of vacancies in the metal trades, a 45 per cent increase in vacancies in the printing trades and a 17.9 per cent increase in vacancies in the construction trades. That is an enormous increase in the number of vacancies that cannot be filled. It was also appropriate at that stage—and it is appropriate to do so again—to put on record that there has been an 8.9 per cent increase in vacancies in the last 12 months. In the Hunter, 61 companies reported a total of 805 vacancies in 2004, and 85 per cent of the companies surveyed were experiencing severe skill shortages; 633 vacancies were recorded at a trade level and above.I put that on the record because I think it goes to the core of the problem that we see before us. I believe that the budget that was brought down does absolutely nothing to address that issue. The government will be importing 20,000 skilled workers from overseas, but really we need something a little more proactive and a little more far-reaching. We do not need a government that will continue to attack our universities. We need a government that will ensure that every child that has the ability to attend university has the opportunity to do so. Currently under this government a situation is evolving where it is not your ability to attend university that determines whether you manage to go there; rather, it is your ability to pay. I do not think that is good enough.I know so many young people within my electorate who would really like an apprenticeship. I have actively pursued apprenticeships for some of them. I have contacted employers and contacted unions, and in a couple of cases I have been successful. However, generally speaking, the support that employers need in order to offer apprenticeships just is not available.While I am talking about skill shortages and issues relating to employment, I will put on the record a conversation that I had at one of the shopping centres in my electorate last Saturday morning. An employee of one of the Job Network providers came up to me on three occasions because she kept thinking of issues she needed to bring to my attention. She said that she was very worried about the government’s philosophy; she was very worried about the availability of places, of suitable jobs; and she was very worried about the government’s proposed changes in the area of disability support pensioners and single parents. She highlighted that there were not enough child-care places, there were not enough out of school hours places—I acknowledge the fact that the government provided more out of school hours places in the budget, and that is very welcome within my electorate—and there were very limited training places.She said that Job Network providers are having a lot of pressure placed on them to breach job seekers, and she found that particularly hard. She said that they are being asked to jump through more hoops more often and that the hoops are being raised higher and are more frequent. She said that, when they are working with job seekers, they go out of their way to create a relationship based on trust and that this pressure tended to undermine that. She also highlighted workload issues and how the breaching of job seekers adds to their workload and prevents them from doing the job that they are being asked to do, which is to find jobs for workers.When she was talking about people on disability support she highlighted to me a case of a 59-year-old woman whom she had managed to place three times. This woman was deaf. It took three failed placements before she realised that people with hearing impairment need special support. I can support that as well. Before I became a member of parliament I worked as a rehabilitation counsellor. My occupation required me to assist people with disabilities to enter the work force. The first point I need to make is that the way to get people to enter the work force is not to punish them but to give them a lot of support.I worked with hearing impaired jobseekers and I know how difficult it is to place them successfully and then to enable them to keep that job long term. I worked with one young woman for 10 years. We placed her in a job and even as a member of parliament I intervened a couple of times with her employer to give support and to negotiate to ensure that she maintained that employment. Finally, when there were some management changes she lost her job and is now unemployed. She is a very intelligent young woman but she has problems that are very specific to people with hearing impairment. Any member of this House who spoke to this young woman would see a very intelligent young woman with a lot to offer. However, when it comes to the placement in the workplace, it is not as easy as members opposite think.Another issue that was raised with me was casual work and requirements for casual workers on Newstart to actively seek a job. Someone working casually has to go out and look for a job as well and attend job training seminars et cetera. I was given the scenario of someone who works at the Job Network provider and delivers a session on job seeking in the morning but in the afternoon is required to go and attend the same session because she is only a casual employee. The issues of lack of stability and the inability to obtain finance to buy a house or to plan for the future were also highlighted.While I was at that shopping centre a gentleman came up to me and spoke about his young grand-daughter. He went to ALDI to collect an application form for a job for her. When he got there, they were out of application forms. There was one job and 5,000 people had already applied for it. That is why I believe that the government needs to be realistic about where it is going with these reforms. The government’s welfare to work changes are very punitive. The government is not fully aware of the issues that surround people with disabilities. It is just another way of creating a different category of people who are, to use government terminology, on the dole. It will result in peoples’ incomes being slashed by up to $215 a week.If you have a disability, you have special needs. Quite often you are taking medication. The government’s policy will just add to their hardship. It will make it more and more difficult for people with disabilities to even afford to look for work. If you have a disability and you decide to look for work, there is a risk. If you fail, where do you go from there? You could end up a lot worse than you were before you made the attempt to enter the work force.As for supporting parents and single parent families, I believe that the government is once again attacking some of the most disadvantaged people in our community. The member for Sydney gave an example that I thought was very good. She described a woman who is getting extra money through the family tax benefit because she is a stay-at-home mum. On his way home from work one night, her husband has a motor accident and is killed. Then she is a single parent and she has the family tax benefit reduced. I do not think that is fair, I do not think that is caring and I do not believe that the government has the real interests of people at heart.I looked at some figures today on the break-up of people on disability support pension, and that answered some of the questions for me. The 20 electorates that had the least people in receipt of disability support pensions were all government held electorates. So I suppose that members on the other side of this House feel that, if it is not going to affect the people living in their electorates, they can afford to attack those people who are most vulnerable and most disadvantaged within the community.I would like to mention quickly a paper released this week by St Vincent de Paul which highlighted the great divide between those people that have and those people that have not. This questioned the statistical data that was being used by the government and highlighted the fact that there is greater inequity within the community now than at any other time in Australia’s history. The divide between those people that have and those people that have not is getting greater. This shows that it is harder and harder for people on low incomes to survive. With the cost of living constantly increasing, those people at the bottom end of the income scale are constantly disadvantaged.The only thing that this budget delivered to age pensioners was an increase in the cost of their medication. As of this year, pensioners—and everyone else for that matter—will have to pay for an extra two prescriptions before they reach the safety net. I highlighted pensioners and veterans because they are two groups that are more reliant on prescriptions and medication than other people in the community. I was speaking to some partners of veterans today, and they are absolutely disgusted about the carers allowance. They are staying at home looking after their veteran partners who are extremely disabled, but they are ineligible for the $1,000 carers payment because they are not on the carers allowance. They feel they are being discriminated against. The other area as far as veterans’ affairs is concerned is the fraud that the government is putting out into the community. There is no new money. All the money in the budget in the area of veterans’ affairs is natural growth. In fact, there is an $82 million saving with the toughening up of the safety net.This is definitely a budget that ignores those people in need. I do not know how the member for Dobell can go back to his electorate and tell the majority of his constituents that they are getting a tax cut of $6 a week while he is getting $65 a week. I do not know how he can go back to his electorate and say to all those people on disability support pensions and single parent pensions that he is not going to support them or fight for them. And I do not know how he can say to all those young people who attend the University of Newcastle that he is not going to fight for them and for their futures. (Time expired)
