name: Jensen, Dennis, MP
content: —Yes, I am certainly aware of that issue. It is an issue that you brought up in a speech, if I recall correctly, about two months ago.Domestic utilities would be able to sell the additional water that they get at about 45 per cent above cost. The water cost to the agricultural sector would be cheaper than it is for irrigation purposes now. Let us have a look at the state of affairs on this. In 1975, an acre-foot of water cost approximately $35. Currently, it is approximately $326. Clearly, looking at this, we can see that water rights would be an appreciating asset.How will farmers afford water rights? Reliable water will increase the value of the land, as I have stated. The idea is that in order to gain a loan from the bank, the landowner will purchase, in effect, an intention to purchase a water right for a cheap price, whereafter the farmer can go to the bank with a strategic business plan and obtain a loan. There is potential, as well, for any excess water—and as the member for Kingsford Smith said, there is variability in the rainfall in the areas; there is variability everywhere—in the years where there is an abundance of water. It could be purchased and fed into the Murray-Darling catchment, with the potential to assist farmers in the catchment area as well and still enable the Murray-Darling system, particularly the Murray, to have a healthy flow at the mouth of the Murray River.I commend this proposal to the House. I believe it is an excellent proposal to consider, given that, as I mentioned, there are a few different methods in which you can attack the water problem. As I have said, I do not think that moving people to where the water is will work. Reducing water consumption clearly works, but there are limitations. As far as recycling is concerned, it can only be used to a certain extent—there are limits—and with desalination there are significant environmental and energy costs. In terms of the Western Australian proposal, you are talking about 10 per cent of the base load electricity, which will be used for the desalination plant in addition to the chemicals that are put in the front end and are going to go into Cockburn Sound, which is not a well-flushed waterway. In conclusion, the way to do it is to get water where it is needed. I believe that this is an excellent proposal that really deserves consideration in terms of helping to alleviate Australia’s water crisis and to give many farmers some surety as far as water supply is concerned.

name: Tanner, Lindsay, MP
content: —This budget sees the end of the Howard battlers and the triumph of the Costello silvertails. The government is awash with money; it is literally drowning in revenue. Spending is out of control. It has delivered tax cuts that are heavily skewed to high-income earners, and it has made virtually no serious hard decisions on spending or on tax reform. There are punitive changes regarding the disability pension and sole parent pension, and there is a very limited strategy towards seriously lifting work force participation. There is an entirely unnecessary future fund which effectively involves the government borrowing to play the stock market, a new, subtle socialist strategy on the part of the Howard government—government ownership by stealth—to tackle what is really a minor problem: public sector superannuation obligations into the future. There is minimal action to address very serious structural economic problems such as capacity constraints and infrastructure difficulties; investment in education and training; excessive borrowing and consumption, which are clearly underpinning to the current growth we are experiencing; declining non-commodity exports, which are a crucial component of our soaring current account deficit; declining productivity; and the absence of any serious reform agenda on competition and productivity.The Howard government is literally drowning in money. It has had the good fortune to be in office during a demographic peak. We reached a point—roughly about 2002-03—where about 47 per cent of the population were in the work force, but after about 2010 that will start to drop dramatically. It has also had the good fortune to experience an enormous commodities boom, which has had a massive impact on tax receipts, and, of course, it continues to benefit in varying degrees from bracket creep.Since the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook papers in December, we have seen that the projections for company tax for the forthcoming financial year were upgraded by $5 billion and the projections for income tax upgraded by $2 billion. That is just within six months. To give a more stark illustration of the massive increase in projected revenue, the 2003 budget projection for company tax proceeds for the 2005-06 year was $36 billion. That has been upgraded in the 2005 budget for the same financial year to $47 billion. There has been an $11 billion upgrading of the assessment of company tax revenue for that financial year. Had there been no new policy initiatives after the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook papers in December last year, the surplus in the forthcoming financial year would be $15 billion, not the $8 billion that is projected. So in effect the government in this budget has given away a further $7 billion on a giant spending spree that started in the 2004 budget and of course was continued during the election campaign.In 2004 the Howard government had a 10.75 per cent real increase in its own-purpose spending, which is the fastest growth rate for federal government spending since 1983. It was fuelled, of course, by the notorious 1982 budget, which just happened to be the last budget with John Howard as Treasurer—but at least he had the excuse of being in the middle of a recession and the need to pump prime the economy. So there has been a giant increase in federal government spending. Roughly three-quarters of the revenue windfall that the government is experiencing as a result of this economic good fortune is effectively being given away over the forward estimates period.Add to that fact that all recent budgets except the 2001-02 budget have hugely underestimated the revenue and cash balance outcomes, what that amounts to is a picture of a government literally drowning in money. There has been virtually no action on spending in this budget. The only significant spending reductions have been the backflip on the Medicare safety net and minor tightening of the PBS safety net, saving in effect only an average of $400 million per annum over the forward estimates years. There has been no action regarding the outrageously wasteful and politically driven Regional Partnerships program, nor the vast array of similar spending programs that are politically driven that are using enormous amounts of taxpayers’ money for naked political purposes.This budget has rightly been described by ANZ Chief Economist Saul Eslake as involving ‘the biggest budget giveaways in history’ and creating a ‘distinct possibility of further interest rate increases’. The budget is leaving the Australian economy enormously vulnerable to the prospective impact of future falls in commodity prices, which will have a significant impact on taxation receipts, capital gains tax receipt reductions and things of that nature. Added to that we see very wasteful new spending that is completely off the track in terms of the appropriate structural reforms required, such as the absurd technical colleges proposal—the government directly invading areas that are the province of the states.The government has used its largesse to shower tax cuts on the better off. If you look at Budget Paper No. 1 on page 1-10, you will see that over the three sets of tax cuts in 2003, 2004 and 2005, some of which come into effect in 2006, for those earning between about $60,000 a year and $100,000 a year there is an effective 12 per cent reduction in their income tax burden. But for those earning around $40,000 to $50,000 a year over those three budgets there has been only an effective three to four per cent reduction of their income tax burden, a very serious skewing of the distribution of tax cuts in favour of higher income earners.The budget papers also suggest that a lot of this is simply the returning of bracket creep. If you look at Budget Paper No. 1 on page 10-9 you will see that revenue from income tax is projected to grow from $111 billion in 2005-06 to $133 billion in 2008-09, effectively a 20 per cent growth or five per cent per annum. By 2008-09 it is projected that income tax collections will in fact be a slightly higher percentage of GDP than they are projected to be in the immediate future. In other words, the tax cuts are trimming cream off the top but not really restructuring the tax system, except to shift the burden away from higher income earners and in effect increase the burden on lower income owners. That is what this is all about.The government’s response to this is to talk about the politics of envy. That phrase is what you hear when there is a rich person’s hand in a poor person’s pocket. It is the last refuge of the political scoundrel. If the economy deteriorates and we need serious surgery on the tax scales, if there is a serious need for fiscal repair, you can bet your life that the Howard government will not be reimposing the burden on higher income earners who are benefiting from its largesse. It will hit people lower down the scale.The budget does nothing serious to deal with the participation issue, which is one of the biggest challenges facing the Australian economy. We have nominally record levels of participation in our work force but, when part time and full time are factored in, it is at a much more modest level. We are still only 12th in the OECD with work force participation rates and we are below the OECD average for people over 55. We need a real effort to make it easier for people to get into the work force. Instead, we have had a nasty punitive assault on those on the disability support pension and sole parents, punishing them and diminishing their entitlements.The tightening of the disability test for DSP applicants means that we will now have three categories of people on the DSP: those who have been on it previously, those who go on to it between May 2005 and June 2006—to whom a 30-hour work availability test will apply at the start and thereafter a 15-hour test—and finally those who apply for the disability support pension after June 2006. Those who are already on it will have an enormous incentive not to look for work or take work because, if they do, they will be taking an enormous risk: if they take a job and then lose it or they find they are unable to cope, they may not be able to get back on the disability support pension.There is a range of other changes of very dubious purpose. Sole parents whose children are above the age of six will be forced on to Newstart and, therefore, will face a substantial increase in their effective marginal tax rates from 40 per cent to 60 per cent. There is a $504 million increase to Job Network for welfare to work purposes, but it is counteracted by a $457 million cut to general Job Network funding. The criteria for the highest level of Newstart assistance have been made tougher. Wage subsidies are being reintroduced for disadvantaged job seekers, which—as has been the case in the past—will be wide open to employer rorting and churning. The different indexation arrangements between pensions and other entitlements will mean that the gap between Newstart, on the one hand, and the disability support pension and sole parent pension, on the other, will continue to grow, making the problems I have referred to previously even worse. We will see sole parents losing access to the pensioner education supplement. There is very limited new child-care money, most of it coming on stream only in 2008. We will see nothing new for long day care funding and only about 20,000 training places for the hundreds of thousands of DSP and sole parents whom we aim to get into the work force. There is minimal action on the biggest problem in the Australian taxation system: the effective marginal tax rates. Labor’s alternative proposes a serious assault on that problem.The budget proposes a future fund, which effectively involves the government borrowing to play the stock market. To keep the bond market alive, the government is refusing to repay government debt. That is similar to what has been occurring with the government having had enormous amounts of money on deposit at the Reserve Bank—up to $16 billion in recent times earning 5½ per cent—while at the same time paying similar amounts and in some cases higher on outstanding government debt. Keeping the bond market alive, for whatever is the government’s purpose, would have to qualify as perhaps the most bizarre industry assistance scheme Australia has ever seen: an employment creation scheme for bond traders. The future fund proposal is effectively the equivalent of a person getting a substantial pay increase and, instead of paying off their mortgage or paying for their kid’s education, putting that money away in a bank account to cover their next 30 years of council rates. That is the equivalent of what is happening with the future fund.The public sector superannuation issue is a minor problem. It cost the public purse $3.4 billion in 2003-04, which is less than two per cent of total outlays. It can easily be carried on a pay-as-you-go basis and it will decline over time. There is no doubt that eventually, sooner or later, The Nationals will get their grubby paws on the money in the future fund and it will be there as an additional pork-barrelling source. The money should be given back to taxpayers and in the most effective way, which is into individual occupational superannuation accounts. That means that the money would go into investment and not consumption. In addition, because fluctuation in future surpluses is unavoidable, it is not locked in as a permanent tax cut. It would help fill the retirement savings gap and could become a permanent part of the reform of superannuation tax.This budget does very little to tackle the enormous structural problems in the Australian economy: capacity constraints, skill shortages, excessive consumption, household debt, deteriorating export performances and declining productivity. There are many worrying signs of these problems in the budget papers. For example, there is the absence of serious new skills and education initiatives, with the exception of the absurd and wasteful federal technical colleges proposal. The OECD data in Budget Paper No. 1 at 4-24 shows that Australia is lagging the OECD very seriously in post-secondary non-university education—that is trade and TAFE. We are well below the OECD average.Demand growth has been 5.6 per cent over the past three years while GDP has averaged only 3.1 per cent. In other words, we are spending the largesse that the terms of trade change have delivered to Australia; we are not investing it. Since 2000, the vast bulk of the increase in nominal household wealth has come from housing prices rather than productivity improvements, compared with between 1992 and 2000, where it was the reverse. From the figures for 2004-05, the year we are about to complete, we can see that GDP growth has been contributed to more by household consumption and public expenditure than it has by business investment.We have a serious current account deficit problem that is well known. It is running at seven per cent plus for the first time since 1951-52 and the government’s half-baked justifications about the ratio of debt servicing simply do not address the key structural problem, which is our abysmal recent exports performance. Exports as a percentage of GDP are falling sharply. Imports are soaring. And it is predicted that we will have a seven per cent growth in exports in the forthcoming year, off the back of a prediction this year of eight per cent when the outcome is going to be two per cent. There will be virtually no changes in volumes. The explanations in the budget papers for the appalling export performance in manufactured exports and services exports are thin. They talk of the Australian dollar appreciation, the maturing of some of Australia’s manufactured exports, more intense competition from China and other countries, and health and security concerns re international travel.When we look at the actual evidence though we see that there are a lot more serious concerns here. The Australian dollar appreciation only gathered pace in late 2003, early 2004. The trade weighted index only managed to get back up to the June 2000 level in early 2003, so in fact we had several years of very positive position with the Australian dollar. It was lower than it had been in 2000 for nearly three years. Australia was highly competitive during that period of global slowdown. Disaggregating the data for elaborately transformed manufactures, simply transformed manufactures and services shows big variations across specific categories which are not explained by the government’s excuses. There are big drops in exports of precious stones, basic non-ferrous metals, textiles and yarns, and the total drop in simply transformed manufactures over the four-year period from 2000-01 to 2003-04 was from $12.2 billion to $9.5 billion. There was a similar experience with elaborately transformed manufactures, big drops in non-metallic mineral manufactures, big drops in office and telecommunications equipment and in machinery and transport equipment. The total drop in elaborately transformed manufactures was from $20.5 billion in 2000-01 to $18.1 billion in 2003-04. Services exports have been pretty static over that period.It is significant that the Commonwealth Bank’s analysis of the budget states that in the past five instances of recovery from bad current account deficits the bulk of the recovery has come from higher export volumes. In a classic piece of understatement, the Commonwealth Bank says, ‘A rise in export volumes is elusive’ and, ‘Progress in sorting out the current account deficit problem will be slow.’ Contrast the budget papers where it is suggested that the problem is a saving problem. We have an exports problem and the government is doing very little about it. If we do face a very serious economic correction as a result of the giant structural imbalance in the global economy caused by the US current account deficit there could be a major problem for Australia, possibly even a serious recession. The prospect of that is gradually mounting, as the OECD has warned, and indeed even the budget papers acknowledge it. It is unclear what the implications would be for Australia but, because of our huge current account deficit, our very weak export performance, our big consumption and debt overhang and the huge increases in government spending, we are seriously exposed to some very negative consequences if that global realignment occurs.Now is the time for serious action on productivity and participation, not the cosmetic touches and ideological crusades that we have in this budget. As Saul Eslake correctly pointed out, the budget has ‘no comprehensive productivity growth agenda’. Productivity is now declining, which means real wage costs are increasing, even when wage growth is constant. Since 2002 we have fallen behind the OECD average on productivity after outperforming it from the early 1990s until 2002. Since 1998 our percentage level of productivity compared with the US has been declining. It hit 86 per cent; it is now back to 81 per cent, which raises a big question about how effective the Peter Reith industrial relations reforms have been in increasing productivity.Tackling exports and productivity decline is fundamental to grasping the emerging opportunities that Australia faces. To do this, we need a serious economic reform agenda. We should not waste the best opportunity Australia will ever have in the current benign circumstances, as the Howard government is doing. Instead of out-of-date ideological obsessions such as imposing individual contracts on low-paid workers, we need serious reinvigoration of competition reform and fiscal consolidation. Nothing is happening on these issues. That is why exports have stalled, that is why productivity is going backwards and that is why government spending is soaring.My challenge to the Howard government is to develop and implement a serious economic reform agenda to do the things it should have been doing over the past few years. It should broaden the income tax base and lower the rates by eliminating concessions and deductions, by tackling the effective marginal tax rates problems and by integrating the payment system and the taxation system. The government should slash wasteful government expenditure, in part to help it to finance serious tax reform on superannuation taxes. It should invest the fortuitous surpluses that it has been gaining and pay them into individual occupational super accounts rather than the absurd future fund. It should accelerate the roll-out of broadband, which is an absolute disgrace in Australia. We are way behind most of the developed world, and this is the economic foundation for the 21st century.The government should seek a total realignment of the federal and state divisions in health, education, aged care and various other responsibilities to eliminate the enormous duplication and waste that characterises those areas. The government should use drought assistance to ensure genuine reform of farming practices—where farms are located and which land is farmed. The government should institute sweeping genuine competition reforms in the areas that nobody talks about—telecommunications, so we have stricter regulation of Telstra and stricter separation of its functions; broadcasting, to accelerate the uptake of digital television and radio by sweeping deregulation; aviation, so we can have genuine competition for Qantas on the LA route. Qantas is happy to play the little Aussie battler when it seeks protection from competition but is all about exporting Australians jobs. Qantas wants a global labour market but protection from global competition. We need more competition for pharmacies, with the PBS growing to nine per cent per annum on real returns. We should invest seriously in R&D and develop a major participation strategy to ensure that we have genuine work force reform. (Time expired)Debate adjourned.

name: Murphy, John, MP
content: asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 17 February 2005:Can she confirm that the Government provides full medical support to all totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) Veterans with service related injuries and disabilities; if not, why not.Can she confirm that the daily care fee for Prisoners of War receiving low-level hostel nursing care is fully subsidised; if not, why not.Does the Government provide low-level, or similar, non-means tested nursing care for TPI Veterans; if so, what are the details; if not, why not
Speaker: N/A

name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
content: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Yes, the Australian Government does provide full medical support to all totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) veterans. All TPI veterans hold a Gold Card, which entitle them to treatment for all medical conditions. TPI veterans may use the Gold Card to access any medical service listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS). The Gold Card also provides access to a number of support services such as Allied Health and Community Nursing Services, Veterans Home Care, the Rehabilitation Aids and Appliances Program, the Repatriation Transport Scheme and the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.Yes, daily care fees for Australian ex-Prisoners of War receiving low-level (hostel) residential aged care in Australian Government funded facilities are fully subsidised.The Government does not provide low-level or similar non-means tested residential aged care for TPI Veterans. The Government believes that people, including TPI veterans, should make a reasonable contribution towards the cost of their aged care if they can.
Speaker: N/A

name: Murphy, John, MP
content: asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 17 February 2005:Can she confirm that from May 2005 totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) Veterans will (a) no longer be able to obtain their free or subsidised footwear from a podiatrist and footwear supplier of their choice and (b) receive free or subsidised footwear supplied by a company nominated by the Department of Veterans’ Affairs; if so, why.What are the details of the company or companies nominated by her department to supply footwear to TPI Veterans from May 2005.
Speaker: N/A

name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
content: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:The Department of Veterans’ Affairs (DVA) is making a number of changes to the supply arrangements for medical grade footwear services, with the overall objective being to improve the quality of the services provided to all eligible veterans with a clinical need for medical grade footwear, including TPI veterans. However I must emphasise that these changes are administrative only, as there has been no change in policy in relation to the provision of these services.It is important to the Department that veterans receive high quality medical grade footwear services. To ensure this happens, the Department has undertaken a procurement process to find footwear suppliers which are suitably qualified and have a good understanding of the special clinical footwear needs of veterans. The list of DVA approved suppliers will be those which participated in this recontracting process and which have been assessed as meeting the high standards set by DVA.Details of the new contracted suppliers are currently being finalised. Podiatrists and other footwear prescribers will shortly be able to advise eligible veterans which supplier/s in their local area are contracted to DVA to provide MGF services from May 2005.

name: Ferguson, Martin, MP
content: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in writing, on 10 March 2005:With respect to the decision by SBS to televise the Ashes cricket series on free to air TV, what ‘prodding’ was undertaken by the Minister and Prime Minister of SBS and whom did that ‘prodding’ involve.What is the value of the television deal and did any discussions take place between the Government and SBS management concerning a possible additional financial contribution by the Government to SBS to assist in securing the television rights.
Speaker: N/A

name: McGauran, Peter, MP
role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs
content: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:The Minister deals with the representatives of the commercial and national free-to-air broadcasters on a regular basis as part of her role as Minister for Communications. Prior to SBS’s acquisition of the rights to the Ashes matches the Government indicated repeatedly that it hoped a free-to-air broadcaster would acquire the right to televise the 2005 Ashes series. However, the Government also indicated that it considered the matter to be a decision for each of the broadcasters.SBS has advised that the value of the rights is subject to confidentiality provisions in the agreement with the rights holder.Discussions between the Government and agencies relating to financial matters are subject to Budget confidentiality. However, SBS has advised that its capacity to acquire the Ashes was not dependent on securing additional funding assistance.
